abstract: HORSE TAMING. -- Mr. CALOM WITTY on Wednesday exhibited his power over the horse before a select party of invited guests, at a stable in Flatbush-avenue, to show that he could do all that Mr. RAREY does with that noble animal, and also that Mr. RAREY is a humbug, in so far as he professes to cure vicious horses. Mr. WITTY tried his skill on several horses with more or less success, as regards "going through the motions," but did not fully satisfy his audience that horses could not be reformed under Mr. RAREY'S treatment.
lead_paragraph: HORSE TAMING. -- Mr. CALOM WITTY on Wednesday exhibited his power over the horse before a select party of invited guests, at a stable in Flatbush-avenue, to show that he could do all that Mr. RAREY does with that noble animal, and also that Mr. RAREY is a humbug, in so far as he professes to cure vicious horses. abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Judge McCUNN, Jacob Miller, convicted on the previous day of arson in the second degree, was sentenced to Sing Sing for twelve years and three months. The prisoner complained that his counsel had forced him to an immature trial, and he asked for a new one, on the ground that he could prove, upon the testimony of fifteen respectable citizens, that he was elsewhere on the night of the fire.

abstract: THE CASE OF MRS. BEARCHELL. -- Coroner SHIRMER yesterday closed the investigation of the circumstances attending the death of Mrs. MARGARET BEARCHELL, who was believed to have been the victim of violence at the hands of her husband. It was shown by several witnesses that deceased habitually indulged her taste for liquor, and on several occasions within a few days had received serious injuries in consequence of falling in the street while intoxicated. The testimony failed to corroborate the anonymous note received by the Police to the effect that the bruises on the body of deceased had been inflicted by her husband, and he was released from custody. Dr. GEORGE BORTON, who made the post-martem examination of the body, testified that in his opinion death had been caused by compression of the brain, resulting from a clot of blood having former upon it in consequence of a blow upon the head, and the case having seen given to the jury, a verdict was rendered of "Death by violence received in some manner to the jury unknown."
lead_paragraph: THE CASE OF MRS. abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- Last evening DONIZETTI'S "Lucretia Borgia" was played for the purpose of introducing Signorina ELENA to a New-York public -- or to that very small portion of a New-York public which experiences the fashionable necessity of attending the opera; a necessity which we may here add seems to be less pressing this season than at any other period in our recollection. The opera has been sung better, both by the artists whom we know, and by many representatives of the heroine. Signorina ELENA -- the dibutante -- we are informed, labored under an attack of indisposition which was sufficient, under ordinary circumstances, to justify her withdrawal from the programme, but business being in a critical condition, she sang, and perhaps did great injustice to herself. We shall reserve our opinion for another occasion, briefly stating that Signorina ELENA is a lady of prepossessing appearance, who evidently is familiar with the business of the stage, and everything else, except voice, that a prima donna depends on.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- Last evening DONIZETTI'S "Lucretia Borgia" was played for the purpose of introducing Signorina ELENA to a New-York public -- or to that very small portion of a New-York public which experiences the fashionable necessity of attending the opera; a necessity which we may here add seems to be less pressing this season than at any other period in our recollection. The opera has been sung better, both by the artists whom we know, and by many representatives of the heroine. Signorina ELENA -- the dibutante -- we are informed, labored under an attack of indisposition which was sufficient, under ordinary circumstances, to justify her withdrawal from the programme, but business being in a critical condition, she sang, and perhaps did great injustice to herself. We shall reserve our opinion for another occasion, briefly stating that Signorina ELENA is a lady of prepossessing appearance, who evidently is familiar with the business of the stage, and everything else, except voice, that a prima donna depends on.

abstract: The present price of the best of Southern State stocks shows the public estimate of the danger to which property in these States is exposed. We do not have to go far back to find quotations for Virginia Sixes at 115,40 per cent, above the present price! The same bonds ought to be selling to-day at 140 and ...
lead_paragraph: The present price of the best of Southern State stocks shows the public estimate of the danger to which property in these States is exposed. We do not have to go far back to find quotations for Virginia Sixes at 115, 40 per cent. above the present price! The same bonds ought to be selling to-day at 110, and would, but for secession. So with Tennessee, the bonds of the former are selling at 74, the letter at 71. In other words the best of all kinds of Southern property, the bonds of the Sovereign States, for which the whole means of all the people in them are in honor pledged, has lost more than 25 per cent. of its value, owing to the apprehended political action of these States.

abstract: The fears entertained in Washington that a serious collision was about to take place at Pensaco la are gradually giving place to a belief that such a catastrophe has been avoided, and this belief is strengthened by the fact that no advices have been receiveed from there, notwithstanding the necessary time has elapsed for the Brooklyn to make the voyage. There seems to be no ...
lead_paragraph: The fears entertained in Washington that a serious collision was about to take place at Pensacola are gradually giving place to a belief that such a catastrophe has been avoided, and this belief is strengthened by the fact that no advices have been receiveed from there, notwithstanding the necessary time has elapsed for the Brooklyn to make the voyage. There seems to be no doubt that both the Brooklyn and the Macedonian are instructed to aid the garrison of Fort Pickens to the last extremity. The rumored new misunderstanding between Gen. SCOTT and the President is now no longer doubted. It has grown out of the vacillating policy pursued by the President recently towards the Disunionists. Gen. SCOTT was yesterday before the Special House Committee appointed to investigate the matter of the threatened attack upon the Capital. He testified that, although there was no positive information of any conspiracy for that purpose, there was sufficient knowledge in possession of the Government to warrant the precautionary steps which had been taken. Col. HAYNE, it is understood, will present his communication to the President to-day. It is much the same as announced in the telegram from Charleston, published a few days ago. The Government of South Carolina proposes to purchase all the fortifications in Charleston harbor, provided the Administration will withdraw the garrison of Fort Sumter. As there is not the slightest probability that the proposition will be entertained, Col. HAYNE expects to leave Washington very soon.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN, Charles O'Niel, indicted for assault with intent to kill, pleaded guilty to an assault with intent to do bodily harm. His counsel presented affidavits of provocation having been given by the complainant to the prisoner; also that the prisoner was an industrious man and was the only support of an aged and decrepid mother. The sentence of the Court was six months in the Penitentiary.

abstract: John H. Foote vs. The North Western Insurance Company. This action was brought by the plaintiff to recover $800 and interest on a policy of insurance issued by the defendants upon the plaintiff's store at Madison, in the State of Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: John H. Foote vs. The North Western Insurance Company. -- This action was brought by the plaintiff to recover $800 and interest on a policy of insurance issued by the defendants upon the plaintiff's store at Madison, in the State of Wisconsin. The store of plaintiff was destroyed by fire in June, 1857. The defence is that the Company did not receive any notice of other insurances, which were on the property at the time their's was effected; and that they were not indorsed upon the policy, as required by its conditions.

abstract: The progress of secession has already had the effect to confirm beyond cavil the commercial supremacy of New-York.
lead_paragraph: The progress of secession has already had the effect to confirm beyond cavil the commercial supremacy of New-York. The City had previously monopolized the domestic export trade in breadstuffs and provisions, and in doing so had achieved the most remarkable success of this kind ever recorded. All her immense commerce is the creation of a well devised system of public works, controlled and directed by an enlightened and liberal policy. Thirty-six years ago, it cost $100 the ton to transport a ton of merchandise over either of the three routes between New-York and Lake Erie. Over the Erie Canal the cost per ton the past year, between the same points, averaged only $3. The effect of such reduction in transportation charges, was to enlarge in an equal degree the area of the trade of this great work. With a cost of $10 per ton this area would be described by a line drawn only a few miles from the shores of the Great Lakes. Every cent below this rate pushed this boundary in every direction further inland. The reduction of a dollar in transportation charges between Buffalo and New-York has the effect to increase the radius of this boundary 50 miles. Assuming the previous length of such radius to have been 200 miles, the extent of territories made tributary to the canal, and to the trade of the City, would equal 35,000 square miles. The reduction of another dollar per ton on cost of transportation would annex another area, equal to 45,000 square miles. This has been the method of the aggressions of New-York on the trade of the interior. By a constant reduction in the cost of transportation, she has steadily removed further and further from herself the line of debatable ground between herself and her rivals, till in the northwest she may be said to have driven every competitor from the field. The produce of upper Minnesota, after a circuit of more than 2,000 miles, helps to swell the vast volume which is now flowing into her harbor. But for our public works, the produce of this distant region, soon to become one of the most valuable auxiliaries to our trade, would have had no commercial value whatever.
headline: {'main': 'The Internal Trade of New-York.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Internal Trade of New-York.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Late on Thursday night John Jackson, William Robinson, John G. Jones and Richard Donovan, sailors, entered the drinking-place No. 203 South-street, and finding there another sailor named Stephen Goodwin, commenced to banter him, evidently with the object of causing a fight.
lead_paragraph: Late on Thursday night John Jackson, William Robinson, John G. Jones and Richard Donovan, sailors, entered the drinking-place No. 203 South-street, and finding there another sailor named Stephen Goodwin, commenced to banter him, evidently with the object of causing a fight. Goodwin sought to avoid his tormentors by leaving the place, and was passing down Pier No. 35, East River, directly opposite the saloon, to go on board the ship Charles Hill, where he was employed, when the four men overtook him and beat him in a brutal manner. Having become tired of pounding the poor wretch with their fists and feet, the ruffians produced knives and stabbed him three times, -- once in the breast and twice in the side, -- causing wounds which there is no hope he can survive. The assailants fled as soon as they had satisfied their malice, and with considerable difficulty Goodwin dragged himself to his vessel, where he made his misfortune known. One of his shipmates went ashore to inform the police of the matter, and meeting Roundsman Rode and Officer Blair, of the Fourth Ward, he started them in pursuit of the assailants, whom, in a very short time, they found and arrested. As quickly as possible the injured man was removed to the New-York Hospital, where he received medical attention, but yesterday afternoon his condition was so unfavorable that Coroner SCHIRMER was summoned to take his ante mortem deposition. The prisoners having been placed before him he unhesitatingly pointed out Robinson as the man who had stabbed him, and Jackson as an accomplice in the assault. The Jury having heard the wounded man's story brought in a verdict against the accused, who were examined by the Coroner in the prescribed manner. Both men, however; denied the truth of the charge, and stated that they had never seen their victim before. The Coroner committed them to await the result of the injuries they had caused, and the two other seamen, Jones and Donovan, were held as witnesses. Goodwin is a native of Newburyport, Mass., 33 years of age.

abstract: The Democratic State Convention, called to throw its weight into the seale in favor of the Union, was gathered to its constituency yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic State Convention, called to throw its weight into the seale in favor of the Union, was gathered to its constituency yesterday. The fruit of its labors survives in the nomination of a conciliatory Commission, in its indorsement of Mr. CRITTENDEN's plan of compromise, and its protest against "coercion" -- that is, against the enforcement of the laws, the collection of the Federal revenues, and the recovery of Federal property. As affecting the great national question in a beneficial way, we must confess our doubts whether the restoration of order and unity is in the least likely to be promoted by such imperfect and contradictory suggestions. Nothing is more obvious than that if the Constitution lacks vigor to defend and perpetuate itself, and secure obedience to proper laws, it is not with the trouble of patching and tinkering with perishable compromises; and we may as well suffer the Union which rests upon so unstable a foundation to perish at once, as to totter to a tardy fall through another half century. And there are other no less palpable objections to this coupling of fidelity to the Constitution with impunity to treason. At the present moment six States of the Union are in arms, threatening the Federal Government, and demanding concessions so enormous and impossible, as to astound with their unspeakable arrogance. Opposed to these, is the great body of the American people, resolute to fight over again, if necessary, the battles which gave birth to our political system, and rendered its blessings possible; and by a firm vindication of the supremacy of law, to discourage any repetition of such seditious experiments. To the latter class these Democratic resolutions address themselves. They propose to have the defenders of the Constitution lay down their arms, in the presence of their armed adversaries; and accept such conditions as the ultra Southern party may prescribe, the victors to the conquered. For if there is no reason to believe that Mr. CRITTENDEN'S plan is acceptable to these reckless men, even when the alternative of civil war lies behind it, there is evidently the best reason to think that an assurance of peace in any event would put any such moderate basis wholly out of the question; and make reconciliation impracticable. If any doubt existed upon this point, the anxiety of Senator MASON, on Thursday, to ascertain Mr. SEWARD's view of coercion as the alternative of compromise, may set it at rest; especially if connected with WIGFALL'S subsequent declaration that no imaginable terms can now win back the seceded States. Without an absolute certainty of compulsion in the background, all schemes of conciliation are in fact futile.

abstract: In a recent article we exposed the evidently dishonest devices by which an effort is now making to secure to CYRUS H. McCORMICK the right to levy an onerous tax upon the farmers of the country for another seven years.
lead_paragraph: In a recent article we exposed the evidently dishonest devices by which an effort is now making to secure to CYRUS H. MCCORMICK the right to levy an onerous tax upon the farmers of the country for another seven years. We pointed out the suspicious fact that this scheme of patent extension is sought to be smuggled through, in advance of the proper time for its consideration, and just at the close of a bankrupt and ruined Administration, unequaled in history for the peculations and official knaveries perpetrated in its name, and under its responsibility. The Patent-office Bureau, while under the administration of Hon. JOSEPH HOLT, now Secretary of War, escaped the general epidemic of corruption, -- and it is sincerely to be hoped that the Executive will not allow the apprehended stain to be fixed upon that office also, in these last hours of the official year. Having established the proposition, that whatever may be the merits or demerits of Mr. MCCORMICK'S application, as an independent question, the only purpose of pressing it to a decision at this time, is dishonestly to anticipate, for improper purposes, the consideration of the subject by the incoming Administration, to which it properly belongs, we proceed now to demonstrate that the patentee has already received an abundant reward for his invention, and that henceforth it ought to be free to all the world.

abstract: We have of late had frequent occasion to notice a growing improvement in the style in which standard authors are presented by our book manufacturers to the public.
lead_paragraph: We have of late had frequent occasion to notice a growing improvement in the style in which standard authors are presented by our book manufacturers to the public. The recent editions of BURTON'S Anatomy of Melancholy, of D'ISRAELI'S works, of CHARLES LAMB, of MONTAIGNE and some others, leave nothing to desire on the score of print or paper. They are unsurpassed by any of the issues of the foreign Press. The difference between these and their American predecessors is in the matter of taste as well as actual quality. The material and workmanship are better; but there is abundance of good material and good workmanship, which is sadly wanting in effect for lack of nicety in the preparation. A little wider margin, a little more finish in the binding and lettering, a slightly different tint of paper, make all the difference between a simply manufactured article and a book which is a book. It is like the cut of a coat, -- the cloth may be the same, the buttons may be the same in two garments and both may fit, while in the one case you look like a gentleman, in the other like anybody else. The majority of books are turned out, like so many blocks, by machine-work, with no suggestion of human art or handicraft about them. They have the appearance of being simply stamped or cut, so vilely mechanical are they, like the wooden books seen sometimes in public libraries or showcases. But the true book, worthy to put on the shelf of a private bookcase, and look a man in the face, in the sacred retirement of his library, should wear a different aspect. It should bear unmistakable indications of the skill of the binder, and the fidelity of the paper-maker and printer; its lettering should be clear and neat, its covers firm; -- in fine, if there is worthy authorship inside of it, it should wear the air of a gentleman, not of a plebeian.

abstract: It is a long time since the Roman Catholic Church has been honored by a determined opposition from a leading Government.
lead_paragraph: It is a long time since the Roman Catholic Church has been honored by a determined opposition from a leading Government. The more intelligent minds of every country have united in tacitly treating it as a fast vanishing quantity, while the very panics occasionally awakened among the multitude have continued the impression that the real power of its priests was in the groundless fears of their enemies. But the official, or officially indorsed pamphlets and other works which have for nearly three years been published in France, show that in the nineteenth century the once great prop of the Church, now for a long time untrustworthy, has at last been turned as a battering-ram against her gates. A complete history of this literature would be an invaluable "side-piece" to the history of Italy during the past decade -- and unless we are very much mistaken, ten years hence it will be found of even more importance in solving that of France.

abstract: It will be seen by reference to our Washington dispatches that the Floridians consider themselves already in a state of actual war with the United States.
lead_paragraph: It will be seen by reference to our Washington dispatches that the Floridians consider themselves already in a state of actual war with the United States. Lieut. JAMES E. JONETT, attached to the steamer Crusader, has reported himself to the Navy Department under peculiar circumstances. He had occasion, while temporarily employed on the Wyandotte, to go ashore at Pensacola, when he was immediately seized by the State troops as a prisoner of war, but was subsequently released on parol of honor, with the understanding that he was not to bear arms against the State of Florida. He was then furnished with a passport, with which he left the State and proceeded to New-Orleans, where he was again threatened with arrest; consequently he took the shortest route to Washington, where he awaits the commands of the Secretary of the Navy. This outrage of the Secessionists, however does not compare in magnitude with one contemplated at New-Orleans, but which was happily frustrated by the caution of those most immediately interested in its defeat. The Crusader itself, it seems, was to be siezed by the city authorities, while the officers were being entertained in a friendly way on shore. The bait did not take, and the Crusader still remains in the service of the Government. There was a general expectation in Washington, last evening, that exciting intelligence would soon be received from Charleston, but what this expectation was based on does not clearly appear. It probably grew out of the knowledge of the fact that Col. HAYNE has received his dispatches from Gov. PICKENS, relative to the proposed surrender of Fort Sumter, in connection with the fact that preparations are constantly going on in Charleston for an attack on that fortification. The Diplomatic Corps, it appears, are generally of opinion that a collision cannot now be avoided, and they have forwarded dispatches to their respective Governments to that effect.

abstract: Hon. ANDREW EWING made a powerful appeal to the friends of the Union at Nashville, Tenn., on the 28th. He declared himself alike opposed to immediate State, secession and to coercion. He is in favor of the Crittenden Compromise, and of presenting it fairly to the North, waiting such a time as the people of the North may have an opportunity to express their ratification or rejection of it at the ballot-box. It they ratify, then the Union is saved. If they reject then, Mr. EWING thinks the Border and Middle States will go out of the Union with the South, carrying with them such Northern States as are willing to fellow.

abstract: On Saturday afternoon, the office of Mr. Theodore Chase, No. 13 Cooper institute, was broken into by forcing open a window, and a package containing $1,000 in bank bills carried away. The prize, howev
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, the office of Mr. Theodore Chase, No. 13 Cooper Institute, was broken into by forcing open a window, and a package containing $1,000 in bank bills carried away. The prize, however, was scarcely worth the trouble expended in obtaining it, for the notes happened to be all counterfeit, and one of the thieves, in shattering the window glass, cut his hand very badly. A few hours after the robbery had become known. Officers McCahill and Kinnersley, of the Eighteenth Ward, arrested three young men, named Thomas Killalea, John Burns and George Miller, on suspicion of having stolen a schooner's yawl, and a windlass belonging to a canal boat, both of which articles were found in their possession. On searching Killalea, $13 of the bogus money which had been taken from Mr. Chase's office, was found in his pockets, while Miller's hand exhibited marks and cuts, produced by broken glass. The prisoners had not been long in custody before they acknowledged themselves guilty of the offences charged. Justice CONNOLLY committed them pending an examination.

Strong. -- This was an action brought by the publisher of Vanity Fair against the publisher of Yankee Notions for an injunction to restrain him from infringing the plaintiff's copyrights, and for damages for such infringement. The alleged infringement consists in the defendant having published three of Artemas Ward's letters, viz.: His Visit to Brigham Young; his letter on Forts; his Visit to Old Abe, and his account of his seeing Forrest, for all of which the plaintiff claims to have a copyright.

abstract: Yankee land, represented by Boston-town, is so conveniently at hand that it is continually benefited by the generosity of Gotham.
lead_paragraph: Yankee land, represented by Boston-town, is so conveniently at hand that it is continually benefited by the generosity of Gotham. To that snow-covered region have recently been consigned the unclad forms of DUBUFE'S Adam and Eve, and the sweet rendering of the bare-footed Cinderella by VAN LERIUS. The solid men are welcome to all they can extract from the lifeless figures of our unwise progenitors, but we beg them to close their eyes to the beauties of Cinderella, and send her back again. There is one consolation, the picture is not very large, and that is enough to damn it in the eyes of the habitues of the Atheneum. In the GOUPIL Gallery the statue of the Lotus-eater, by Miss STEBBINS, attracts great attention. It represents a good-looking youth, who, with listless air and a sort of a devil-me-care expression, leans cross-legged against the stump of a tree, around which grows the lotus. On his head, placed with evident care is a garland of the treacherous plant, in his hand lies unclasped, a sprig of the same, which serves to call the attention of the beholder to the fact that the figure is undraped, while trailing upon the ground are various vines, on all of which are clusters of the oft-sung lotus. The anatomical execution of the work is exact, and it would be difficult to suggest any improvement in that department. One's idea of a Lotus eater, however, does not allow us to agree with the artist, in the desirability of so muscular a leg, more befitting a youthful Hercules, than one whose energies are sapped; whose muscles are relaxed; whose fire is gone; whose life is spiritless, and whose very existence is but a dream. The face is very beautiful; and to our mind, fully conveys the idea of a drowsy, half-conscious, self-satisfied, listless content, such as doubtless those gentry who indulged in the seductive berry were wont to experience. The stomach would not seem to indicate data from which such a bodily state could be deduced -- no hearty meal reposes therein, and were it not for the expression given by the other portions of the body, one would not conceive that L.E. had partaken of his dinner. The limbs are exquisitely modeled, and the feet are gems such as are not often found amongst those who subsist on heartier food. Miss STABBINS has succeeded, there is no doubt on that point, and we are pleased to learn that duplicates of this figure have already been ordered by several of her fellow-countrymen and admirers. At this same gallery the French and Flemish pictures, which have been so rare a treat to New-Yorkers during the Winter, will be sold at public auction on the evenings of Wednesday and Thursday next. There are few pictures in the collection, that are not very good, the majority of them being productions of the most distinguished living artists. Inducements have been offered to the agents to have the sale deferred, but for reasons of imperative necessity it will be held as advertised.

abstract: A very sharp political contest in the Republican ranks was decided at Albany on Saturday night by the nomination of IRA HARRIS to be Mr. SEWARD'S successor in the United States Senate.
lead_paragraph: A very sharp political contest in the Republican ranks was decided at Albany on Saturday night by the nomination of IRA HARRIS to be Mr. SEWARD's successor in the United States Senate. It rarely happens that a question of this sort is so sharply contested as this nomination has been; -- but it had the usual fate of all such domestic controversies, and was settled by compromise.

abstract: March, 1713, it was expressly stipulated by King PHILIP that the English should have an exclusive privilege for furnishing the Spanish West Indies with negroes, according to the assiento contract. It was stipulated in this treaty that from the 1st of May, 1713, to the 1st of May, 1743, a British company should be allowed to transport into the colonies of Spain 140,000 negroes, or 4,800 per annum. Agreements were made with other States, seeking to advantage the British flag, and forts were erected by Great Britain on the African coast to protect the shipping engaged in this nefarious traffic. The slaves have multiplied in the Anglo-Saxon colonies since those days, and have become an institution; and their emancipation is now surrounded with many difficulties and vast prejudices.
lead_paragraph: March, 1713, it was expressly stipulated by King PHILIP that the English should have an exclusive privilege for furnishing the Spanish West Indies with negroes, according to the assiento contract. abstract: On Saturday we reprinted from the London Times some speculations on the future of the United States when they shall be divided into two independent Confederations.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday we reprinted from the London Times some speculations on the future of the United States when they shall be divided into two independent Confederations. The writer drew the line of separation along the present boundary of the Free States, and apparently with no better guide than the mere inspection, of the map, proceeded to predict a career of rapid and uninterrupted prosperity for the Slave States; a government of great strength and efficiency over a compact and easily defensible territory; and a command of the commerce of the world, secured by a monopoly of the cotton crop. For the Free Confederacy a less encouraging prospect was anticipated. A narrow belt of territory, straggling irregularly from the Atlantic to the Pacific, in a rigorous climate, where agriculture is difficult, and the arts pursued with indifferent energy; a disjointed empire as defective for commercial intercourse or military purposes as the Kingdom of Prussia; there is nothing for the Northern States, according to this sagacious authority, but a protracted struggle with unkindly Nature, varied by contests with unfriendly nations, who will pour in at once upon their defenceless coasts and frontiers. While, therefore, the South will sweep into its generous bosom Mexico and Central America, the North, hemmed in between Virginia and Canada, must perish either from inanition or foreign wars.

abstract: Absurd and inadmissible as is the doctrine which claims for any State the right of secession from the Union at its pleasure, it would still furnish no ground of justification for one at least of those which have ventured upon the desperate and dangerous experiment.
lead_paragraph: Absurd and inadmissible as is the doctrine which claims for any State the right of secession from the Union at its pleasure, it would still furnish no ground of justification for one at least of those which have ventured upon the desperate and dangerous experiment. Whatever may be said in palliation of the conduct, of South Carolina, Georgia. Alabama, Mississippi and Florida, no theory of constitutional construction can make good the demand of independent existence on the part of Louisiana. The acquisition of the country around the mouth of the Mississippi River was held by all parties sixty years ago to be absolutely essential to its free navigation, and to the public peace; and so deep-seated was this conviction, that President JEFFERSON, though imbued with a passionate admiration of and attachment to the French nation, hesitated not a moment to declare that it must be acquired at the hazard of a war with that great Power, at the highest period of its military glory, under BONAPARTE. JEFFERSON, who was the head and founder of the school of politicians which holds to a strict construction of the Constitution, freely admitted that no power existed in the Government to purchase Territories, or to admit States to be carved out of Territories lying beyond the limits of the Union, as defined in the Constitution itself. But recognizing the higher law of necessity, in the exigency before him, he hesitated not to take measures for the acquisition of Louisiana, in violation of the fundamental law, and trusted to the magnanimity of his country for his justification, and for the subsequent grant of power to make the treaty of purchase.
headline: {'main': 'Reasons for the Acquisition of Louisiana by Jefferson good for Retainingit by Lincoln.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Reasons for the Acquisition of Louisiana by Jefferson good for Retainingit by Lincoln.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A gentleman who arrived recently from Florida, has called at the TIMES Office, and furnished us with some interesting items of news. He corroborates the accounts that we have from time to time published in regard to public opinion at the South. Secession in Florida was not effected by the...
lead_paragraph: A gentleman who arrived recently from Florida, has called at the TIMES Office, and furnished us with some interesting items of news. He corroborates the accounts that we have from time to time published in regard to public opinion at the South. Secession in Florida was not effected by the vote of the people -- on the contrary, every effort was made to prevent an honest vote being taken. The Legislature, which directed that a Convention should be chosen, only allowed five days to intervene between the notice and the election. The consequence was that the country people, who were opposed to secession, had no opportunity to vote, and the people of the towns had it all their own way. No one in Florida entertains a doubt that a majority of property holders are Union and conservative, -- for a proposition made in the Convention to allow only property-holders to vote, was not entertained for a moment. The Secessionists of Florida are those who have everything to gain and nothing to lose -- and, for the present, they rule supreme. As an instance of the spirit that prevails, it is related that a Floridian, within the last month, entered the store of a Northern man and stabbed him four times, without any provocation whatever. Rushing out into the street, with the dripping weapon in his hand, he shouted, "This is the blood of a G -- d d -- n Yankee; let us serve them all so!" For this brutal murder the perpetrator was elected to the Florida Convention. Our informant, though himself as owner of negroes, and an advocate of the institution of Slavery, was twice fired at for wearing a Union cockade. A man in Florida who openly protesses loyalty to the Union, is called an Abolitionist, and is lucky if he escapes being lynched.

abstract: It will be seen by our Washington correspondence that there is good reason to believe that Maj. ANDERSON has received a very considerable accession to the forces under his command.
lead_paragraph: It will be seen by our Washington correspondence that there is good reason to believe that Maj. ANDERSON has received a very considerable accession to the forces under his command. Our correspondent states that he has reliable authority for stating that ten or twelve officers and about three hundred men have been introduced into the fort within the last fortnight. They are supposed to have been taken down by the Brooklyn, and to have been landed at night in small boats, with muffled oars. This, if true, will account for the reports which from time to time have emanated from Charleston of small boats having been seen at night rowing in the neighborhood of the fort.

abstract: FATAL RESULT OF A FRACAS BETWEEN WOMEN, Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest, yesterday morning, upon the body of CATHARINE KINNEY, a native of Ireland, 55 years of age, lately occupying a room in the tenement-house rear of No. 326 East Thirteenth-street, whose death occurred on Friday night, in consequence of injuries received on the 30th of last December.
lead_paragraph: FATAL RESULT OF A FRACAS BETWEEN WOMEN. -- Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest, yesterday morning, upon the body of CATHARINE KINNEY, a native of Ireland, 55 years of age, lately occupying a room in the tenement-house rear of No. 326 East Thirteenth-street, whose death occurred on Friday night, in consequence of injuries received on the 30th of last December. It appeared from the statements of the witnesses that deceased was of very intemperate habits, and having indulged herself to excess on the night of the 30th of December, she became turbulent and cross, venting her anger upon a woman named JULIA MURPHY, living in the opposite apartment to that occupied by herself. For a time Mrs. MURPHY paid no attention to the abuse, but finally losing her temper in consequence of deceased having thrown a heavy stone jug several times against the door, she snatched a bowl from the table and threw it, striking the drunken woman on the forehead and knocking her down. The neighbors called in a physician who removed several small fragments of the bowl from the forehead of deceased, but she subsequently became delirious, and having lingered in much suffering until Friday, her death resulted. A post mortem examination of the body was made by Dr. WOOSTER BEACH, jr., who found that death had occurred from an abscess in the brain, produced, in his opinion, by the injuries received, and the case having been given to the jury, a verdict against Mrs. MURPHY was rendered. The accused, who has been in custody previous to the inquest, was then examined. She stated that she was 38 years of age and a native of Ireland, adding that the charge of having thrown a bowl at deceased was untrue -- she had not hit her with anything. The Coroner committed her to the Tombs to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: No dispatches from Major ANDERSON have been received by the War Department for several days, and the belief is gaining ground in Washington that an attack has been made on Fort Sumter by the South Carolina troops.
lead_paragraph: No dispatches from Major ANDERSON have been received by the War Department for several days, and the belief is gaining ground in Washington that an attack has been made on Fort Sumter by the South Carolina troops. If such is the case, the attacking party have perhaps met with a warmer reception than they anticipated; for, according to our Washington dispatches, it is not improbable that, in spite of the boasted watchfulness of the investing forces, the garrison of the coveted fortification has been reinforced. This, it is intimated, has been done through the instrumentality of the steamer Brooklyn, by means of small boats with muffled oars, which passed the batteries on Morris Island in the night time. We shall probably have exciting news from Charleston ere long. Col. HAYNE, it is expected, will leave Washington to-day, though he has not yet received any acknowledgment of the reception of his communication to the President, which was sent in on Friday evening, and which was considered by the Cabinet on Saturday. The document will most likely be submitted to Congress. The delegates appointed from the various States, in accordance with the suggestions of the Virginia Legislature, assemble to-day, to deliberate upon the condition of the country, and if possible to fix upon some plan which will be likely to satisfy all those States, at least, which still remain true to the Union.

abstract: Despite the auguries of false prophets, the sneers of broken-down managers, and the discreditable indifference of our New-York public, the associate artists at the Academy of Music are doing well.
lead_paragraph: Despite the auguries of false prophets, the sneers of broken-down managers, and the discreditable indifference of our New-York public, the associate artists at the Academy of Music are doing well. They are even experiencing the unaccustomed pleasures of full pay. Delightful as it would be to boast of this triumph as of a New-York triumph, and to say something smart and cutting at the expense of Philadelphia -- that peculiarly decorous city which Mr. DE CORDOVA wickedly and maliciously describes as "the Paris of America," and where, it will be remembered, the opera was not too fortunate -- the praise of making the fashionable amusement successful must be handed over to the Brooklynites. To their liberality, indeed, we are fairly indebted for the two performances with which we were favored last week, neither of which, taken by themselves, paid, or half paid, the expenses, and either of which would have been sufficient to bring the season to a close if there had been no good and faithful Brooklyn to fall back upon. The receipts on Wednesday night in the last-named city nearly reached $2,000; the receipts at the Fourteenth-street house on the following night (Thursday) -- and with a new prima donna, too -- scarcely exceeded $300! In view of these statistics, were we wrong in stating that our Academy of Music, as a place of public resort, is "played out?"

abstract: This State seems to be prospering since the war with Peru and the undisputed accession to power of Gen. FLORES and Don GARCIA MORENO.
lead_paragraph: This State seems to be prospering since the war with Peru and the undisputed accession to power of Gen. FLORES and Don GARCIA MORENO. The Convention to frame a new Constitution met at Quito on the 6th inst. MORENO, who is now Governor of Guayaquil, is the most prominent candidate for the Presidency, although some think the President will be Gen. FLORES. Trade in Guayaquil is very prosperous, the merchants all making money. Gov. MORENO is giving great satisfaction, having broken up the gangs of thieves and river pirates, by hanging and shooting several of the chief sinners. Lately he ordered 100 lashes to be applied to the back of an old General for some offence, 50 of which were administered.

abstract: Such a wonderful stir in the market as the advent of Prof. WOOD'S RESTORATIVE CORDIAL AND BLOOD RENOVATOR. In it we have all the Scientific Medical Skill acquired in a close study of thirty years or more. The cures it has performed are so numerous ...
lead_paragraph: Such a wonderful stir in the market as the advent of Prof. WOOD'S RESTORATIVE CORDIAL AND BLOOD RENOVATOR. In it we have all the Scientific Medical Skill acquired in a close study of thirty years or more. The cures it has performed are so numerous and striking as to arrest the attention and confidence of the most intelligent all over the country, and thousands will bless the day that their attention was called to such an article. But, as the reader will see is our habit, we prefer to let others, and those who are disinterested, tell the story. We cannot publish all, so we select the following, and say read, and doubt if you can.

abstract: The issue of a writ of habeas corpus, in the case of ANDERSON, by the English Court of Queen's Bench, has fallen like a bomb-shell upon this community.
lead_paragraph: The issue of a writ of habeas corpus, in the case of ANDERSON, by the English Court of Queen's Bench, has fallen like a bomb-shell upon this community. There was an unwillingness to credit the telegraphic account; but the arrival of the detailed report of the case yesterday set all doubt at rest. Probably no similar attempt has been made within our day to encroach on the liberties of a free people. Canada, a great self-governing community, with a commercial tonnage more than twice as large as that of France, is compared to the Isle of Jersey and the Isle of Man, neither of which has a population larger than that of Toronto. The precedents quoted are well enough for a crown colony; but it so happens that Canada possesses a Court of Queen's Bench expressly vested with powers co-ordinate with those of the queen's Bench in England; and if that Court can be ignored and set aside by an Imperial tribunal, where is the guarantee for our liberties? If the judicial branch of our government may be trenched upon, in this summary manner, who is to guarantee the executive and legislative functions of the government from invasion? These questions force themselves upon every mind as the report of this extraordinary case is read.

abstract: In this Court, on Saturday, Judges BROWNELL, BERNNAN AND STRERS disposed of the calendar as follows: Of fifteen persons charged for assault and battery, six were dicharged by non-appearance of witnesses, two by request of complainants, three by acquittal, one obtained a postponement, and three were acquitted. One person charged with embezzlement ...
lead_paragraph: In this Court, on Saturday, Judges BROWNELL, BRENNAN AND STEERS disposed of the calendar as follows: Of fifteen persons charged for assault and battery, six were dicharged by non-appearance of witnesses, two by request of complainants, three by acquittal, one obtained a postponement, and three were acquitted. One person charged with embezzlement was acquitted. Of five persons charged with petty larceny, one was discharged by non-appearance of witnesses, one was remanded, one obtained a postponement, one was fined, and one acquitted. Most of the cases were for petty larcenies or trivial assaults, and had no interest except to parties concerned.

abstract: A cloud of witnesses assembled at the Academician doors, on Saturday afternoon, resolved to assuage the tears of the widow and the orphan by the well-filled tiers of that classic spot.
lead_paragraph: A cloud of witnesses assembled at the Academician doors, on Saturday afternoon, resolved to assuage the tears of the widow and the orphan by the well-filled tiers of that classic spot. Charity covereth a multitude of sins, according to an old and respected saying; and if we may judge of the amount of iniquity hidden by the demonstration at Mr. RAREY'S farewell matinee, we should say the world must have been purged to a remarkable extent. Mr. RAREY having put money in his purse with wonderful case and celerity during the past few weeks, felt it his duty to wind up with a grand furore and go off in a blaze of glory. This he has succeeded in doing, and we need no surer proof of his tact, than was evinced in the affair of which we write. One half the net proceeds of the performance, it was announced, would be given to the Asylum for Widows and Orphans, and as a natural consequence all those people who had been desiring for the Winter past, to donate half a dollar or so, and who at the same time felt a natural curiosity to see the horse of the day, thronged in vast numbers to the place. The building was densely crowded and the best of humor pervaded the entire audience.

abstract: George F. Clark vs. Thomas A. Davies. This cause was referred, in January, 1855, to Albert
lead_paragraph: George F. Clark vs. Thomas A. Davies. -- This cause was referred, in January, 1855, to Albert Matthews, to hear and determine the several issues therein; and now comes before this branch of the Court, upon an appeal from the findings of the Referee, the appeal having been taken by the defendant. The facts, as they appear from the pleadings and the findings of the referee are substantially as follows: Some time during the year 1843, the plaintiff and defendant entered into a partnership arrangement, by which they were to carry on the business of contracting for and erecting buildings in this City. By that agreement, the plaintiff, who was a practical builder, was to contribute his skill and knowledge as such, and the defendant, who is a practical architect, was also to contribute his skill and knowledge as such, and the two were to share equally in the profits of their enterprise. At this time it appears that the sum of $1,000 was contributed between them, but previous to the month of February, 1844, the defendant having become possessed of $12,000, it was further agreed between the parties that that sum should make up a part of their working capital. They then varied their former agreement so far as the same was to be applicable to the undertakings hereinafter mentioned. To-wit: that the said parties should on joint account, and as partners procure from the Ministers, Elders and Deacons of the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church of this City, leases of lots of land known as and by the Nos. 49 and 51 John-street and 3 Dutch-street in this City, for the purpose of erecting buildings thereon. In May 1844 they obtained a lease of said lots of the Dutch Church Corporation and commenced building thereon. These buildings, it is averred, rented for more than sufficient to pay for the ground rent and all other incidental expenses. The plaintiff sets out that under this agreement his share of the net profits up to February, 1843, is the sum of $2,541 69. In May, 1846, the defendant, it is alleged, made an agreement in writing with the plaintiff, in consideration of his services in erecting the buildings on this leasehold property to pay one-fourth of the sums of money that the said defendant should receive from the rents of said buildings during the term of ten years from May 1, 1844, after the deduction of expenses. The Referee found the facts substantially as above set forth; and further found and decided, that between the plaintiff and defendant, in respect to the leasehold property, there existed no partnership; that the written agreement of 1846 merged and extinguished all other agreements between the parties; and that said written agreement was a valid subsisting agreement between the parties.

abstract: A few days since Mr. Dominico Chisachi, recently proprietor of a hat, cap and fur-store, at No, 146 ...
lead_paragraph: A few days since Mr. Dominico Chisachi, recently proprietor of a hat, cap and fur-store, at No, 146 Bowery, lodged a complaint before Justice OSBORNE against Geo. W. Markham, a broker, at No. 8 Pine-street; Dorrance Davis, engaged in a similar business at No. 19 Nassau-street, and another person, known as John M. Hodges, charging them with having conspired to defraud him of $1,600. It is alleged in the affidavit of the complainant that about the 10th of last month he advertised his store, including good-will and fixtures,) for sale. The defendant, Markham, had an interview with him and represented that he had been commissioned to purchase the property for a gentleman, named John M. Hodges, residing at No. 29 Fifth-avenue. With reference to payment, Markham stated that his principal was willing to buy for the sum asked, ($1,600,) but that instead of paying cash, he would give his promissory note, payable in three months, with collateral security in two bonds on the Mount Vernon Railroad Company, Illinois, valued at $800 each. Mr. Chisachi not appearing to be satisfied with the proposed terms, was referred by Markham to Davis, the other defendant, for information concerning Hodges and the Railroad Company. Calling upon Davis, he was told that what Markham had said with reference to the value of the bonds was perfectly true, and the latter added that they had been issued upon the security of 100,000 acres of land, valued, according to location, from $4 to $50 per acre, recently granted the Railroad Company by the State of Illinois. Davis also indorsed the representations which had been made about Hodges' wealth, whose note, he said, was negotiable, and would be taken anywhere without collateral security. Believing these statements Mr. Chisachi accepted the note and bonds, made his business over to Markham, and felt contented. He did not, however, remain many days in this happy condition, for he learned that as soon as Markham took possession of the store he sold the goods at auction and closed the place. His suspicions being thus awakened, Chisachi went to the bank where Hodges' note was made payable and was informed that no account was kept there in that gentleman's name. Next calling at the reputed residence of Mr. Hodges, in Fifth-avenue, his growing belief that he had been victimized received confirmation from the fact that no such person as the man he sought lived at the house in question. He subsequently ascertained that the Mount Vernon Railroad Company only existed in the imaginations of the accused, and therefore no invoked the law to redress his wrongs. Markham and Davis were yesterday apprehended by Sergeant Cropsey, of the First District Court, and to-day they will be examined on the charge.

abstract: The message of Gov. HOUSTON to the Legislature of Texas, now assembled in extra session, comes to us in the Galveston News, of Jan. 26.
lead_paragraph: The message of Gov. HOUSTON to the Legislature of Texas, now assembled in extra session, comes to us in the Galveston News, of Jan. 26. The Governor reiterates the position which he has so often taken,-- that the insults of which the South complains have been put upon her by the people of the Northern States, and not by the Federal Government, and the question must be decided whether it is better to claim constitutional rights or to abandon the Union. He appeals to the Legislature not to forget the long years which have been necessary to bring the Government to its present position, urges its members to take no step hastily, but to show their confidence in the judgment of the people by referring to them the action of the Convention. Texas has gone through one revolution with her people united, and they can be united again, if occasion requires, but they must remember that they will, themselves, have to raise the millions necessary for defending the frontiers of the State, if they declare in favor of secession, and that provision must be made at once for the thousands whom short crops have brought so near starvation. In conclusion, Gov. HOUSTON urges the necessity of maintaining inviolate the credit of the State, says that he has hopes for the Union still, and warns the legislators that between Constitutional remedies and anarchy and civil war, he can see no middle ground.

abstract: The brief but pithy charge of Recorder HOFFMAN to the Grand Jury of the Court of Sessions, delivered yesterday, will be read with interest.
lead_paragraph: The brief but pithy charge of Recorder HOFFMAN to the Grand Jury of the Court of Sessions, delivered yesterday, will be read with interest. It has in it no ad captandum points -- no special professions of purity -- no strongly worded promises that justice, and only justice, shall be administered from the Bench during his term of administration. Very probably Mr. HOFFMAN may think his previous character a sufficient guarantee that his judicial duties will be faithfully discharged; -- while in addition to this, it may perhaps be noteworthy that the Recordership is an office established by the Constitution and therefore not within the power of the State Legislature either to abolish or modify. This, therefore, may make him less eager for the immediate and sudden capture of public esteem -- his experience very likely teaching him that all violent passions are apt to be transitory, and that early professions of a too highly colored description are often fated to be painfully contrasted in the future with actions not in the least able to stand the test of comparison.

abstract: The delegates to the Peace Convention, called at the suggestion of the Virginia Legislature, assembled at Washington yesterday, and effected a temporary organization, by the selection of Mr. J. C. WRIGHT, of Ohio, as President, and Mr. H.E. WARD, of Maryland, as Secretary.
lead_paragraph: The delegates to the Peace Convention, called at the suggestion of the Virginia Legislature, assembled at Washington yesterday, and effected a temporary organization, by the selection of Mr. J.C. WRIGHT, of Ohio, as President, and Mr. H.E. WARD, of Maryland, as Secretary. A Committee of one from each State represented was then appointed to arrange for the permanent organization, and the Convention adjourned until to-day. A motion to allow the representatives of the Press to attend the sessions was defeated, and the Convention is to sit with closed doors. It is understood that the delegates from Virginia will demand as their ultimatum the "equality of the South" in all the territory which may hereafter be acquired, as well as in that which is now held by the United States, and it is intimated that she will be joined in this demand by Kentucky, Maryland and Missouri. It is expected that Ex-President TYLER, of Virginia, will be permanent President.

abstract: The present position of the Italian movement gives a signal contradiction to the doctrine of a progressive school of historical philosophers, that events obey a general tidal movement, in which the individual element sinks into insignificance.
lead_paragraph: The present position of the Italian movement gives a signal contradiction to the doctrine of a progressive school of historical philosophers, that events obey a general tidal movement, in which the individual element sinks into insignificance. For nothing is clearer than that the prospects of Italy are now most intimately associated with considerations of a purely individual character. Impersonated in GARIBALDI and CAVOUR, in fact, stand confronted the two lines of policy -- the revolutionary and the constitutional -- on the triumph of the one or the other of which, it is no exaggeration to say, turns the whole cast of Italian affairs. It has been happily so ordered that, during the wonderful drama of national regeneration which has now run through two years, these two elements, so destructive apart, so omnipotent united, have been directed to a common end; and the union has been crowned by achievements that beggar fable. But the inherent antagonism of these methods of action, brought out into sharp relief on the question of Venetia, threatens, not indeed to frustrate the Italian movement, (for that has deeper holdings than any personal influence,) but to dissipate, in scattering and unsure attempts, forces which should be concentrated on bringing to completeness the work so gloriously begun.
headline: {'main': 'Italian Prospects.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Italian Prospects.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The regular meeting of the Board of Supervisors will be held to-day, and up to the present writing no official communication has been received from the Mayor as to the fate of the County tax-levy, which has now been before him since Wednesday of last week.
lead_paragraph: The regular meeting of the Board of Supervisors will be held to-day, and up to the present writing no official communication has been received from the Mayor as to the fate of the County tax-levy, which has now been before him since Wednesday of last week. It is surmised by some, and openly asserted by many, that he will exercise the prerogative conferred on him by the Charter, and interpose his veto, and for two potential reasons -- first, the ordinance as submitted by the Comptroller, and adopted by the Board, contains no provision for the payment of the claims presented on account of the new Harlem Bridge; second, because the ordinance does contain an appropriation to meet the additional expense to be met by reason of the passage of an ordinance increasing the Police force, and which was met by a veto from the Mayor. As, however, the veto messages have been invariably and unanimously overruled, the presumption is fair that the forthcoming message will share the common fate, and the only damage inflicted will be the delay of the ten days before the subject can be brought up for reconsideration.

abstract: This vessel is kept constantly under steam, at a safe distance from the reach of enemies, and in readiness to cooperate in the defence of the fort.
lead_paragraph: This vessel is kept constantly under steam, at a safe distance from the reach of enemies, and in readiness to cooperate in the defence of the fort. In case of an emergency she will be at hand ready to receive on board the garrison, should they be overpowered and obliged to abandon the fort to the enemy. There are arrangements by which the entire forces will be able to escape through a covered way to the beach, where they can take to boats and go on board any vessel that may be in waiting to receive them. In such an event it will probably be blown up.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Before we utterly condemn the public of New-York for neglecting the musical opportunity now afforded them by the Artists' Association at the Fourteenth-street establishment, it may be well to inquire if the entertainments there provided are altogether what they should be.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Before we utterly condemn the public of New-York for neglecting the musical opportunity now afforded them by the Artists' Association at the Fourteenth-street establishment, it may be well to inquire if the entertainments there provided are altogether what they should be. We have had occasion recently to speak in not very favorable terms of two last performances, the "Trovatore" and "Lucrezia Borgia." These efforts, although in a beaten track, were decidedly below the average. They were gotten up with absolute disregard to the great requisite of opera -- a perfect ensemble -- and depended, for what little applause they received, on the accidental popularity of the principal female singer. With new artists like Miss HINKLEY and Mdlle. ELENA, it may be rapid business policy thus to depend on the kindness of an audience, but the liberality of throwing every thing on the weak shoulders of a debutante is a matter that may well be questioned. VERDI's "Trovatore" was given without proper rehearsal; DONIZETTI's "Lucrezia Borgia," whether with rehearsal or without, was simply slaughtered. To the list we must now add ROSSINI's "Barbiere di Siviglia," played last night scandalously by every member of the Artists' Association except Miss HINKLEY. We cannot speak of the performance in a critical way, because in every musical respect it was utterly beneath notice; a merely idiotic exhibition of vocalistic vagary. Miss HINKLEY was the only member of the troupe who tried to do justice to the composer's meaning. And when we say this, we mean no disrespect to the lady's ability, (which, happily, was manifest notwithstanding her wooden surroundings,) but on the contrary a compliment to her will and endeavor to do what was right and proper. For the rest, it was simply a contest between buffoons; a struggle for the ascendency in all that was absurd. The "Barbiere," we are aware, is an opera which admits of comic expansion, but when men like BRIGNOLI, SUSINI and COLLETTI, indifferent to the composer's, music, try to be colloquially funny, what have we to dread? The first gentleman gave us an occasional bellow; the second an idiotic gabble of words; the third a growl. If even these things had been done with decent or ordinary, dramatic skillfulness, there would be less to object to; but blurted out as they were last night they seemed like the cheap resorts of mediocrity. Signor FERRI -- a true artist under ordinary influences -- endeavored, and occasionally with success, to struggle against the stream of general indifference to propriety, but in the concerted pieces was carried away by the current and became an obstruction like the rest. With this partial conciliation to a male artist of the caste we may dismiss the remainder with the remark that on any second rate European stage they would have been hissed from the presence of the public. Can we wonder at New-York indifference with these three illustrations of inefficiency before us?

abstract: For three months events of startling magnitude have so closely followed, one upon the heels of another, that our whole time has hardly sufficed for their record. We have been too much entranced by the phenomena to study their origin or law.
lead_paragraph: For three months events of startling magnitude have so closely followed, one upon the heels of another, that our whole time has hardly sufficed for their record. We have been too much entranced by the phenomena to study their origin or law. Astounding robberies and defalcations; the most shameless abandonment of public trusts; the treachery of civil and military officers; the surrender of the forts, armaments and munitions of war of one-half the Confederacy; the disarming of one portion of it to arm the other; the conspiracy in the Cabinet to destroy the Government, in which the facile BUCHANAN has been so much involved as to completely demoralize the man, and destroy all ability for prompt and independent action -- events and developments so unforeseen and incredible, have occurred with such rapidity, that we could only regard them with mute wonder.

abstract: We have been hoping that the selection of Judge HARRIS to be United States Senator might avert, at least for the present, that "irrepressible conflict" which threatens the disruption of the Republican Party in this State. The manner in which it is greeted by the ...
lead_paragraph: We have been hoping that the selection of Judge HARRIS to be United States Senator might avert, at least for the present, that "irrepressible conflict" which threatens the disruption of the Republican Party in this State. The manner in which it is greeted by the Tribune, however, does not confirm these hopes. Our neighbor exults in the result as indicating the complete overthrow of "Seward and Weed" influence in our State politics. It denounces with the utmost vehemence that portion of the party which opposed Mr. GREELEY's nomination, as being influenced by the most corrupt and unworthy motives, and regards their failure to elect their own candidate as proof of their utter humiliation and extinction, so far as any political influence in the future is concerned.

abstract: The various organs of the Democratic Party throughout the Northern States devote them selves mainly, in this crisis of our national affairs, to calling upon the Republican Party to adopt some compromise which shall satisfy the South. We have already more than once expressed our opinion, that the first duty of men of all parties, Democrats and Republicans, ...
lead_paragraph: The various organs of the Democratic Party throughout the Northern States devote them selves mainly, in this crisis of our national affairs, to calling upon the Republican Party to adopt some compromise which shall satisfy the South. We have already more than once expressed our opinion, that the first duty of men of all parties, Democrats and Republicans, -- is to lay aside all their political differences and rally to the support of the Constitution and the Union, -- to insist that the Union shall be preserved, not as a matter of favor but of duty: -- and that when this result has been secured, it will be in order to consider what new guarantees or concessions are due to the South and essential to the public peace. We are still of this opinion. We would yield nothing whatever to exactions pressed by threats of dissolution, either to States that have already seceded, or to others which propose to follow their example unless restrained therefrom by compliance with their demands. If any of the Southern States desire the preservation of the Union on account of its value to them and to the world, let them declare that wish. Let them proclaim their loyalty and then the North will be ready and eager to arrange all differences of interest or of sentiment upon a perfectly just, and therefore a perfectly satisfactory basis.

abstract: Several weeks ago, a resolution was adopted by our State Legislature, calling upon Comptroller HAWS to make a complete return of the amounts paid out of the City Treasury during the last ten years for Street-opening Commissions the names of all the Commissioners, and the amounts paid to each for his services.
lead_paragraph: Several weeks ago, a resolution was adopted by our State Legislature, calling upon Comptroller HAWS to make a complete return of the amounts paid out of the City Treasury during the last ten years for Street-opening Commissions -- the names of all the Commissioners, and the amounts paid to each for his services. To this resolution the Comptroller replied by furnishing all the information within his power, extending back to 1855, -- the street-opening Commissions, previous to that time, having been under charge of the Street Department, and their records consequently not within the Comptroller's reach. This document, we learn, is a very voluminous one, covering more than "fifty foolscap pages;" but, strange to say, since its receipt at the State capital, not one word has been heard concerning it, nor have the most active newspaper correspondents been able to hunt up its items.

abstract: After the presentation and reference of sundry petitions and bills, the monthly statement of the Comptroller as to the City and County finances was received, and ordered printed at length on the minutes.
lead_paragraph: After the presentation and reference of sundry petitions and bills, the monthly statement of the Comptroller as to the City and County finances was received, and ordered printed at length on the minutes. The annual report of the County Treasurer, of the Commissioners of Charities and Corrections, and other reports, were similarly disposed of. A resolution to consider the propriety of asking the Legislature to amend the act for the collection of taxes, so as to have them collected at an earlier period of the year, was adopted, it having been recommended by the Comptroller in his annual report. Also a resolution of inquiry to ascertain the probable cost of publishing in six papers having the largest circulation, all the reports, proceedings, &c., of the Board. The use of the chamber of the Board was, on motion of Mr. ELY, tendered to the Judges of the Court of Appeals, and ordered to be prepared for their occupancy, in case of their acceptance.

lead_paragraph: A public meeting in behalf of the Fourth Ward Reading and Coffee room, No. 26 New-Bowery, which, under the superintendence of ORVILLE GARDNER, has been the means of reclaiming many intemperate men, was held at Cooper Institute on Monday evening. abstract: The Peace Convention at Washington adheres to the resolution to sit with closed doors, but we are, nevertheless, enabled this morning to give an account of the proceedings.
lead_paragraph: The Peace Convention at Washington adheres to the resolution to sit with closed doors, but we are, nevertheless, enabled this morning to give an account of the proceedings. The Committee on Organization, appointed on Monday, reported in favor of Ex-President JOHN TYLER, of Virginia, for President, and J.C. WRIGHT, of Ohio, for Secretary. The report was unanimously concurred in, and Mr. TYLER, on taking the chair, made a speech, which had the happiest effect on the Convention. At its conclusion he was generally congratulated, and most of the delegates announced their readiness to follow where Virginia would lead. The regular business of the Convention was not proceeded with, the excuse being that the Delegates from several States had not yet arrived.

abstract: On Thursday afternoon, James Avery, a colored man of confiding temperament, residing at No. 288 Church-street, became acquainted with a young person named J.H. Berkett, also a descendant of Ham, whom he met at a Dutch grocery in Leonard-street. Having indulged in several social glasses together, Mr. Berkett finally became unpleasantly demonstrative in displaying his regard for Avery. The latter, desiring to avoid such disagreeable attention, ran into the street, where he was followed by his affectionate friend, who overtook and fondled him in a very loving way. Suddenly Berkett departed, and immediately Avery discovered that he had been robbed of a gold watch, valued at $75. He made known his misfortune to Officer Horbelt, of the Fifth Ward, who arrested the thief, and yesterday Justice OSBORNE committed him for trial.

abstract: If Virginia has elected a Convention in which the Union men have a majority, we may regard the crisis of the secession movement as having passed.
lead_paragraph: If Virginia has elected a Convention in which the Union men have a majority, we may regard the crisis of the secession movement as having passed. Her action will undoubtedly decide that of the other Border States. If she declares for the Union, they will do so likewise. And we shall then have a basis for an adjustment of all pending differences upon which the North can stand, and which the great body of the reasonable and considerate men of the South will regard as satisfactory. This is really the turning point of the whole controversy, and we shall await, therefore, with anxious interest the full returns of the election held on Monday for delegates to the State Convention.

abstract: "An English gentleman in New-York" has been writing to a friend in South Carolina on the state of sentiment in this City.
lead_paragraph: "An English gentleman in New-York" has been writing to a friend in South Carolina on the state of sentiment in this City. He finds, he says, but three parties -- the Abolitionists of the Wendell Phillips school, who are "bent on enforcing the laws as they call it, with fire and sword immediately;" the moderate Republicans like Mr. SIMEON DRAPER, "who ask for trying what mild counsels will do first;" and finally the Democrats, who not only warmly sympathize with secession, but who "will fight your (the Secessionists') battle with the sword if necessary."

abstract: the District-Attorney, J.W. SCUDDER, was engaged most of the day in summing up in the case of WM. ABSON, charged with killing his wife by poison. Mr. SCUDDER reviewed the evidence which had been produced by the prosecution and the defence, and detailed the causes which had led to this investigation, from 1857 to Nov. 9, 1860. Gen. E.R.V. WRIGHT then summed up for the defence. His theory was -- 1st, death by suicide; 2d, a mistake by Dr. BOOTH by administering wrong medicine, and 3d, a mistake on the part of Mrs. ABSON in taking poison procured by herself, instead of medicine intended for other purposes. Gen. WRIGHT closed summing up at 6 P.M., and the Court adjourned. A.O. ZABRISKEE will sum up for the defence to-day, occupying five or six hours. Attorney-General DAYTON will follow for the State, and the charge to the jury will probably be delivered, by Judge OGDEN, on Thursday morning.

abstract: A lady like Mrs. DELANY, who was born under the Stuart rule of "good Queen ANNE," in the year 1700, and lived to see the French Revolution, and was the intimate friend of the Hanoverian George the Third and his Queen, who was the ...
lead_paragraph: -- A lady like Mrs. DELANY, who was born under the Stuart rule of "good Queen ANNE," in the year 1700, and lived to see the French Revolution, and was the intimate friend of the Hanoverian George the Third and his Queen, who was the niece of the nobleman immortalized by POPE as "Granville, the Polite," and the friend of Dean SWIFT, who said that his strictest scrutiny could discover "nothing wrong" in her, -- must naturally have much to relate worth listening to. But, unfortunately, the Editor of her Autobiography and Correspondence, just issued under the editorial care of her relative, Lady Hanover, is modeled on what SYDNEY SMITH called the antediluvian scale of book-making, when people could spare a hundred years to lounge over a favorite work. Three large volumes, weighing several pounds avoirdupois, are sufficient to deter readers in the present "go-a-head" days, and will make it still a sealed book to the multitude. Some beautiful engravings from old family miniatures and enamels, decorate the work, including a new portrait of Lady M. WORTLEY MONTAGU, CATHARINE HYDE, Duchess of Queensberry, (PRIOR's "Kitty, beautiful and pretty;") staid and decorous Mrs. ELIZABETH CARTER, renowned for Greek; a charming "Lady Scudamore," yet unknown to fame, and other belles and beaux of the last century. The Court gossip, personal anecdote, and pictures of past life and manners, give a charm to the work which HORACE WALPOLE would have thoroughly enjoyed.
