abstract: Stephen Goodwin, a sailor on the ship Charles Hill, lying at the foot of Catharine-slip, East River, died at the New-York Hospital on Monday morning from knife wounds received on Friday morning last in an affray with two seamen named William Robinson and John Jackson, whom he encountered in Duryea's drinking-place, corner of Catharine and South streets. Coroner SHIRMER held an inquest in the case yesterday morning and the particulars of the affray as developed by the testimony are as follows: About 12 1/2 o'clock on Thursday night four seamen named Donovan, Robinson, Jackson and Jones went to the saloon where deceased was sitting and called for drinks; while the men were standing at the bar, deceased approached them, making the remark to Donovan, that he had been on board the Charles Hill that morning for the purpose of shipping as a sailor; Donnovan told him that he was mistaken, but said, "Never mind, take a drink with us;" deceased assented, and then Robinson stepped toward him, saying, wish an oath, "So, you're mate of a ship, and treat sailors like dogs, do you?" following the interrogation with a blow; deceased stepped toward the door to avoid further trouble, but Robinson and the others followed him to the sidewalk, where he was beaten and stabbed, as he alleged in his ante-mortem deposition, by Robinson and Jackson, while Donovan and Jones witnessed the assault; the men all went into the porter house again after a minute's absence, and deceased made known to the bar keeper that he had been, stabbed in the breast; he went out again immediately, however, and making his way to his vessel, informed a shipmate of what had occurred, who won't after the Police and caused the apprehension of the assailants. Upon this testimony the jury brought in a verdict charging Robinson with having given the fatal wound and implicating Jackson as an accessory in the assault. The accused are both men about 24 years of age, and natives of Ireland. Each denied in emphatic terms the truth of the charge, adding that they had never seen deceased before. The Coroner committed them to the Tombs pending action by the Grand Jury, and Jones and Donovan were sent to the House at Detention for witnesses. Deceased was 36 years of age and a native of Newburyport, Mass.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Goodwin, a sailor on the ship Charles Hill, lying at the foot of Catharine-slip, East River, died at the New-York Hospital on Monday morning from knife wounds received on Friday morning last in an affray with two seamen named William Robinson and John Jackson, whom he encountered in Duryea's drinking-place, corner of Catharine and South streets. Coroner SHIRMER held an inquest in the case yesterday morning and the particulars of the affray as developed by the testimony are as follows: About 12 1/2 o'clock on Thursday night four seamen named Donovan, Robinson, Jackson and Jones went to the saloon where deceased was sitting and called for drinks; while the men were standing at the bar, deceased approached them, making the remark to Donovan, that he had been on board the Charles Hill that morning for the purpose of shipping as a sailor; Donnovan told him that he was mistaken, but said, "Never mind, take a drink with us;" deceased assented, and then Robinson stepped toward him, saying, wish an oath, "So, you're mate of a ship, and treat sailors like dogs, do you?" following the interrogation with a blow; deceased stepped toward the door to avoid further trouble, but Robinson and the others followed him to the sidewalk, where he was beaten and stabbed, as he alleged in his ante-mortem deposition, by Robinson and Jackson, while Donovan and Jones witnessed the assault; the men all went into the porter house again after a minute's absence, and deceased made known to the bar keeper that he had been, stabbed in the breast; he went out again immediately, however, and making his way to his vessel, informed a shipmate of what had occurred, who won't after the Police and caused the apprehension of the assailants. Upon this testimony the jury brought in a verdict charging Robinson with having given the fatal wound and implicating Jackson as an accessory in the assault. The accused are both men about 24 years of age, and natives of Ireland. Each denied in emphatic terms the truth of the charge, adding that they had never seen deceased before. The Coroner committed them to the Tombs pending action by the Grand Jury, and Jones and Donovan were sent to the House at Detention for witnesses. Deceased was 36 years of age and a native of Newburyport, Mass.

abstract: Since the days when ROSCIUS combined military ardor with dramatic excellence, we have had no such inspiriting incident in the history of the stage, as the spontaneous formation of the company of New-York actors now playing a brief engagement at the Varieties Theatre, New-Orleans, into a military organization.
lead_paragraph: Since the days when ROSCIUS combined military ardor with dramatic excellence, we have had no such inspiriting incident in the history of the stage, as the spontaneous formation of the company of New-York actors now playing a brief engagement at the Varieties Theatre, New-Orleans, into a military organization. Thalia and Melpomene descending from their classic pedestals and practising the goose-step, is a noble spectacle. The metamorphosis of first low comedy man into second lieutenant, danseuse into vivandiere, and property man into regimental tailor, are worthy of being sung by OVID. There is something truly gratifying in the knowledge that the heroics of the stage are not all mock, and that a manly heart may beat under the buff waistcoat of Mr. Robert Acres.

abstract: THE LATE CUSTOM-HOUSE FORGERY ARREST OF THE SUSPECTED DELINQUENT. Some time in September last, Messrs. GOODRICH WALKER, of Broadway, near Exchange-place, imported an invoice of silks and placed them in bond.
lead_paragraph: THE LATE CUSTOM-HOUSE FORGERY -- ARREST OF THE SUSPECTED DELINQUENT. -- Some time in September last, Messrs. GOODRICH & WALKER, of Broadway, near Exchange-place, imported an invoice of silks and placed them in bond. A few days ago, upon application having been made for the goods, it was found that two cases, valued at $9,000, had been taken out of the United States Bonded Warehouse, on the 27th of December, upon the strength of a forged order, and to accomplish the fraud the delinquent had shown himself well acquainted with the mode of doing Custom-house business. Beside giving the name of the vessel in which the goods had come, describing the packages, and forging the consignees' names, to obtain possession of the property, it was necessary to imitate no less than seven different signatures of Custom-house officers, and also to counterfeit the oblong stamp of the delivery clerk, all of which was accomplished in so perfect a way that the order was accepted and duly honored. The Police were informed of the fraud, and Detectives MACDOUGAL and BENNETT have since, been searching for the forger. Yesterday they learned enough, in their judgment, to warrant the arrest of a young man named EUGENE COYLAY, on suspicion, and the prisoner is detained at Police Head-quarters pending the result of a further investigation.

abstract: Foreign clearances from the ports of South Carolina are now managed as follows. The principal vessels trading directly from South Carolina are the lines to Liverpool and Havre. They are medium-sized vessels, with the exception of the ship Alliance, which rates about 1,200 tons. These vessels are principally owned in Charleston. The plan is to have the commanders pass their examination at Lloyds, and to have the vessels registered as English bottoms, and sail them under the English flag. One of these Captains, in order to pass muster at Liverpool, remained over one voyage, to brush up his "navigation." He succeeded in passing the ordeal, and is now soon expected home, under the British flag. This is considered the shortest way of avoiding seizure, on account of, irregularities of clearance at our Customhouses. These vessels go to Liverpool or Havre, as trade happens to be best.

abstract: The storeship Supply, which reached this port on Monday last from Pensacola, was immediately placed alongside of the Commissariat Dock in the Navy yard and at once commenced to discharge cargo.
lead_paragraph: The storeship Supply, which reached this port on Monday last from Pensacola, was immediately placed alongside of the Commissariat Dock in the Navy yard, and at once commenced to discharge cargo. The future movements of the vessel are not as yet known. The force at work on the steam-propeller frigate Wabash has recently been greatly increased, so that she can be ready for sea in ten days or two weeks, if necessary. The Roanoke, the same class frigate as the Wabash, is undergoing repairs in the Dry Dock. The force at work upon her is not very large, as a portion of the mechanics were drawn off and set to work upon the Wabash. The Roanoke, however, can be got ready for sea at very short notice. The repairs on the brig Perry have been completed, and she is now being fitted up. The steamers Corwin and Bibb and the frigate Savannah complete the list of vessels now at this Yard ready for service, or which can be got ready for service within a reasonable time. The force of mechanics in the Yard has lately been increased somewhat, much to the gratification of successful applicants, who were before out of employment.

abstract: William Chauncey vs. Lemuel Arnold, and Lemuel Arnold, Executor of Caroline Arnold, deceased. This action was tried in May, 1859, before Judge MONCRIEF, without a jury, and on the evidence the counsel for defendant moved a dismissal of the complaint, which motion was granted, and the cause now comes before the Court on an appeal from the order of dismissal.
lead_paragraph: William Chauncey vs. Lemuel Arnold, and Lemuel Arnold, Executor of Caroline Arnold, deceased. -- This action was tried in May, 1859, before Judge MONCRIEF, without a jury, and on the evidence the counsel for defendant moved a dismissal of the complaint, which motion was granted, and the cause now comes before the Court on an appeal from the order of dismissal. The complaint avers that, in 1846, Lemuel Arnold and Caroline, his wife, filed a bill in the Court of Chancery, against the executors of William W. Gilbert to set aside the will of said Gilbert and to protect certain rights which Caroline Arnold had in his property. That to raise money to prosecute said Lemuel Arnold executed his bond in the sum of $5,000, conditioned to pay to a payee the name of whom was left blank in said instrument, the said sum of money, as soon as the estate should be distributed among the heirs-at-law. Lemuel Arnold and wife then joined in an instrument executed, the same conveying to the blank payee of the said bond, all her right, title and interest in the estate of said Gilbert. The said conveyance was also executed by Jane Gilbert, mother of Caroline, and Charlotte Brayton, trustees of Caroline, under an ante-nuptial agreement between the said Caroline and the said Lemuel, the said ante-nuptial agreement having been made Oct. 3, 1837. This bond and conveyance as aforesaid remained in the hands of the defendants until June, 1847, when, as alleged, Lemuel Arnold obtained the necessary loan from the plaintiff and surrendered to plaintiff the bond and conveyance, with the name of the payee left blank. Arnold carried on his suit against the estate of Gilbert until about May, 1853, when, it is alleged, the difficulty was mutually compromised between the parties, and Caroline Arnold received in her own right a large estate under said compromise. The bond given as aforesaid fell due some time in May, 1853, and not having been paid in accordance with its condition, this suit was brought to recover upon the same.

abstract: On Feb. 2, Fort Palmetto, on Coles' Island, in the harbor of South Carolina, was completed, and the soldiers there celebrated the event by raising the Palmetto flag and giving cheers for all concerned in the construction of the fortifications.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 2, Fort Palmetto, on Coles' Island, in the harbor of South Carolina, was completed, and the soldiers there celebrated the event by raising the Palmetto flag and giving cheers for all concerned in the construction of the fortifications. Some fifty negroes who had assisted in digging ditches, &c., the Mercury says, then assembled on the ramparts around the flagstaff, and gave utterance to the following sentiment: "We are de first dat cum to dis fort -- we work on 'em til'e finish -- tree chairs for Palmetto Fort -- tree chairs for Capen POPE, and tree more for Sous Carolina." The enthusiasm with which these cheers were given would have amazed the old Railsplitter himself. After which they all dispersed to their homes about the several Islands singing "Dixie."

abstract: Conspirators always have the advantage of the public at large. They plot and carry for ward their plans in secret. They can avail ...
lead_paragraph: Conspirators always have the advantage of the public at large. They plot and carry forward their plans in secret. They can avail themselves of circumstances and of temporary currents of opinion and of feeling, to promote their ultimate design, without revealing that design to the world at large. They can command aid and support, under various pretences and from a thousand different motives, for the promotion of their real secret object, -- which they could never secure if that object were proclaimed to the world, or even revealed to their own adherents. Secresy is itself a weapon of prodigious power, especially for the accomplishment of a wicked end.

abstract: It is not more than fifty years since Col. VALLAMEY urged on English officials the expediency of studying the Old Irish language, since there were, as he estimated, above two millions of persons who spoke no other tongue. Since that time it has become well-nigh ...
lead_paragraph: It is not more than fifty years since Col. VALLAMEY urged on English officials the expediency of studying the Old Irish language, since there were, as he estimated, above two millions of persons who spoke no other tongue. Since that time it has become well-nigh dead, while even the "rich brogue" which flavors Hibernian English, is vanishing before the influence of schools and of intercourse with England. The constant stream of emigration to America and Australia, drawn, in a great measure, from the Catholic element, which is synonymous with the more purely Irish portion of the inhabitants of the Emerald Isle, was the first great measure of national diminution and of change. The passing of the Encumbered Estates act, and its important social results also caused a great stirring up of the depths of Irish life. Capital was set free, and brought into active operation; potatoe farms, which barely maintained starving peasants, became grazing farms; schools were established, Anglicizing influences progressed, and, in short, the change was so rapid that within three years Irish Protestant clergymen confidently asserted that in Ireland their party and friends held the balance of power.

abstract: This Board met yesterday, the President in the Chair. The weekly statement showed that 2,765 persons have arrived at this port since the 1st of January 396 emigrants arrived last week. Aggregate ...
lead_paragraph: This Board met yesterday, the President in the Chair. The weekly statement showed that 2,765 persons have arrived at this port since the 1st of January -- 396 emigrants arrived last week. Aggregate receipts, $13,910 60. Disbursements, $14,010 96. Overdraft, $100 36. The Commissioners entered into a contract with Samuel Cooper, an undertaker, for the burial of emigrants on Staten Island, chargeable to the Board for the sum of $6 for each case. They formerly employed a man for the same purpose, paying him $25 per month, but there having occurred no deaths on the Island for years, they found it necessary to economise the matter.

abstract: Official dispatches announce that at 8 o'clock on the morning of the 22d, the batteries of Gaeta unexpectedly opened a heavy fire against the Sardinians.
lead_paragraph: Official dispatches announce that at 8 o'clock on the morning of the 22d, the batteries of Gaeta unexpectedly opened a heavy fire against the Sardinians. The latter promptly replied, and compelled the place to remain silent, and the besiegers continued their fire, Fourteen vessels were stationed before Gaeta, and at noon on the 22d, the fleet was got into line. The Sardinians were actively engaged on new batteries.

abstract: On Tuesday night the police of the Eighteenth Ward were apprised that a prize-fight was in progress at the "dumping ground," foot of Sixteenth-street, East River. Hurrying to the indicated place, the ...
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night the police of the Eighteenth Ward were apprised that a prize-fight was in progress at the "dumping ground," foot of Sixteenth-street, East River. Hurrying to the indicated place, the guardians of the public peace found a ring prepared, and a battle raging fierce and fast between two rising stars in the sporting sky, known as Pat Manning and Jimmy Clark. At the sudden irruption of the officers the spectators -- of whom there were fifty or more -- stood not upon the order of there going, but went without delay, and their disappearance was accomplished so quickly that none of the participants in the affair, save the principals, could be captured. The prisoners, wearing the scant costume of the ring, panting from overexertion, and with faces bruised and bloody, were led away to the cells, whence yesterday morning they were taken before Justice CONNOLLY, at the Jefferson Market Court. Having heard the case, the magistrate fixed the ball of each at $560, to keep the peace; and William Beard, representing himself to be owner of a drinking-saloon at No. 288 First-avenue, offered to go surety for the prisoners. Doubts having been expressed as to the credibility of his story, Beard became angry, and abusive, making it necessary for the very forbearing magistrate to commit him for contempt of Court. A messenger was afterwards sent to inquire if the man really owned the property, and returned with the report that it did not belong to him.

lead_paragraph: Englishmen present the singular paradox of being the greatest travelers and most adventurous people in the world, and at the same time the most ignorant of the geography of other countries. Not long ago the London Economist, the editor of which was one of the most intelligent men in England, made, in a leading article, frequent mention of the "State of Philadelphia." Their best journalists cannot write of this country without making a curious muddle of our localities -- substituting Buffalo for St. Louis, or the State of Ohio for that of Missouri. They are in still greater ignorance of our routes of commerce, and of the effect of our system of public works upon the course of trade. Accordingly, the last number of the London Herald tells us that

abstract: The diplomatic correspondence which we publish this morning clears up something of the fog which has hung over the action of South Carolina concerning Fort Sumter.
lead_paragraph: The diplomatic correspondence which we publish this morning clears up something of the fog which has hung over the action of South Carolina concerning Fort Sumter. As was made known by the second letter of Major ANDERSON to Gov. PICKENS, when the Star of the West visited Charleston, active operations were suspended until further advices could be received from Washington. Col. HAYNE was sent thither with instructions to demand the surrender of Fort Sumter: these instructions will be found among the documents in question.

abstract: The Union General Committee yesterday caused to be fired one hundred guns from the Battery in honor of the noble stand taken by the "Old Dominion" in favor of the Union, as indicated by the recent elections in that State. The firing drew a large crowd who were in great suspense as to the nature and meaning of the demonstration. On being informed, they offered to take up a collection on the spot to defray the expense of firing a hundred more. Great enthusiasm prevailed, and the most hopeful sentiments were at cred.

abstract: For the first time in a dozen years it may be said that all the sea-going vessels at the Brooklyn Navy-yard are almost ready for service. Still the force of workmen employed is far below the average, and the disbursements, which would amount to about $35,000 monthly, if regularly paid, are lower than they have been for a considerable period. We append a list of the vessels now in the bay, with a brief statement of their condition.

abstract: A gentleman who has been traveling in the South furnishes the Chicago Tribune with the particulars of some outrages recently perpetrated in that section, of which he was personally cognizant. Among other places he visited Charleston, ...
lead_paragraph: A gentleman who has been traveling in the South furnishes the Chicago Tribune with the particulars of some outrages recently perpetrated in that section, of which he was personally cognizant. Among other places he visited Charleston, and while there met an old friend who had been arrested only a few days before on account of suspicions aroused against him because he was born in Rhode Island. The expenses of his trial amounted to about $300. He was himself wanted to leave Charleston after he had been there but a few hours, and did so when he got ready. Thence he took a steamer for Florida and entered one of the ports in that State just as a sloop was leaving which had on board a man and his son who had been beaten nearly to death because one of them acknowledged having voted for Mr. LINCOLN. In an extended tour through Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, Texas and Louisiana numberless instances of a similar character came under the notice of the gentleman in question.

abstract: Egbert Deming, Trustee of the New-York Marble Company vs. The New-York Marble Company, Henry Dwight and James R. Bame, severally and joint- ly as Trustees of said Company. The TIMES, of Dec. 28th last, contained a full report of the war among the boom then decided that the appointment of William ...
lead_paragraph: Egbert Deming, Trustee of the New-York Marble Company vs. The New-York Marble Company, Henry Dwight and James R. Bame, severally and jointly as Trustees of said Company. -- The TIMES, of Dec. 28th last, contained a full report of the war among the Receivers in the Company's affairs. Justice Hogeboom then decided that the appointment of William W. Green, as Receiver, was regular, and by relation dated back to the period when the order of reference was made to appoint a Receiver; and that the appointment of Jeremiah F. Jenkins in Bame's proceedings, was improvident and improper. But inasmuch as it was suggested by the defendants' affidavits used before him, that Green was not a suitable person for Receiver, by reason of his having rival interests to the Company, Justice Hogeboom gave the defendants leave to move to set Green aside as Receiver, and for the appointment of some other person in his stead. This motion was accordingly made by defendants Dwight and Bame, and came on to be heard before Justice LEONARD. His Honor denied the motion, with $10 costs, and confirmed Green's appointment.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. FLOTOW'S very agreeable and melodious opera of "Martha" was played here last night to an unusually good attendance. The performance ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- FLOTOW's very agreeable and melodious opera of "Martha" was played here last night to an unusually good attendance. The performance was thoroughly excellent, and so vastly superior to what we have been accustomed to of late, that we are disposed to accept it as a recognition of the kindly counsels which we so lately tendered to the management. A gentle word uttered at the right moment is seldom thrown away on sensible people. The performance was light and vivacious, the vocalism careful and spirited, and even the acting good, especially in all that relates to Miss ADELAIDE PHILLIPS. Mme. COLSON and Signor BRIGNOLT, although not in their usual voice, sang well and Messrs. SUSINI and FERRI were at times excellent. A few entertainments so thoroughly given would, we think, renew the lagging interest in Italian Obert.

abstract: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. An adjourned meeting of the kings County Board of Supervisors was held last evening in the County Jail, President CROWELL in the Chair. Considerable routine business ...
lead_paragraph: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. -- An adjourned meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors was held last evening in the County Jail, President CROWELL in the Chair. Considerable routine business was transacted, when several communications were received, proposing sites for the new Court-House -- one benevolent individual, to settle the difficult question, offering to present the county with a site. The communications were referred to the Committee on Court-House for consideration and report. The Supervisor from the Second Ward, moved that the Superintendents of the Poor be requested to honor the orders of members of the Board for relief, but his associates thought that it was an innovation upon the established custom, and therefore voted the matter down, whereupon the Board adjourned.

abstract: The Peace Convention at Washington was in session four hours yesterday, but no business of special importance was transacted. Some of the Southern ...
lead_paragraph: The Peace Convention at Washington was in session four hours yesterday, but no business of special importance was transacted. Some of the Southern members were anxious to proceed immediately to the consideration of the Crittenden Compromise, but the proposition met with strenuous opposition, and it was finally decided to defer all business until the arrival of the Delegates from all the States in which they have been appointed. With regard to the prospects of harmonious action in the Convention, there appears to be a difference of opinion. It is feared on the one hand that the result of the Virginia election will lead to a show of opposition to conciliation on the part of the Republicans, while, on the other hand, it is alleged that the effect will be entirely the reverse, -- that the Republicans will be much more inclined to listen to what Virginia may propose, now that she has declared her fidelity to the Government. The New-York delegation to the Convention will reach Washington to-day.

abstract: On Tuesday morning, Jan. 22, an important public meeting was convened in the Mayor's parlor, Town Hail, Manchester, with reference to the American crisis and the supply of cotton.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning, Jan. 22, an important public meeting was convened in the Mayor's parlor, Town Hail, Manchester, with reference to the American crisis and the supply of cotton. So large was the attendance, that the meeting was compelled to adjourn to the large room of the Town Hall, which was speedily filled with merchants and manufacturers. The meeting was convened by the Provisional Directors of the Cotton Company, (Limited,) the circular stating that the public had not adequately responded to the invitation to assist in its establishment. The Mayor of Manchester (MATTHEW CURTIS, Esq.,) was called upon to preside. There were present Lord A. Churchill, M.P., Mr. Bazley, M.P., Mr. J.A. Turner, M.P., Capt. Gray, M.P., Mr. J. Cheetham, Mr. E. Ashworth, Mr. H. Ashworth, Mr. E. Potter, Mr. H. Littledale, Mr. T. Mosley, Mr. W. Wanklyn, Mr. J. Pender, Mr. Stolterfoht, Mr. H. Mason, Mr. D. Chadwick, Mr. Bell (of Madrass,) and many other gentlemen of influence.

abstract: Congress ought to take some effectual steps towards placing our Navy on a more effective footing.
lead_paragraph: Congress ought to take some effectual steps towards placing our Navy on a more effective footing. Every day's experience shows its utter inadequacy even for the ordinary emergencies of the service. But when affairs wear so threatening an aspect as they do at present, every consideration of national honor and the public safety demands that prompt measures be taken to remedy its defects and render it available and efficient.

abstract: A DYING MAN FOUND IN A FACTORY MYSTERIOUS CASE. On Wednesday morning, one of the employes in the paper-box manufactory No. 144 Centrostreet, on opening the establishment for the day's...
lead_paragraph: A DYING MAN FOUND IN A FACTORY -- MYSTERIOUS CASE. -- On Wednesday morning, one of the employes in the paper-box manufactory No. 144 Centre-street, on opening the establishment for the day's business, found a German named JOSEPH BROCKMAN in a room on the third floor, lying insensible, and bleeding at his mouth, nose and cars. At the fool of the stairs, on the floor below, there was another pool of blood, and appearances indicated that the injured man had lain down in that place. Assistance having been procured, BROCKMAN was removed to the Sixth Ward Station-house, where he received medical attention; but all efforts to restore his consciousness having failed, he was sent to the Hospital on Blackwell's Island. While at the Station-house, a dark-lantern was found in his pocket, and this fact gave rise to the supposition that, having been engaged in the commission of a burglary, he had fallen down stairs and received his injuries. This theory of the matter is not, however, sustained by the man's antecedents. He was formerly employed in the factory, had always borne the reputation of an honest man, and his friends state that the dark-lantern was placed in his pocket the night previous for the purpose of preventing some children playing with it. The door of the premises was locked, as usual, when the porter arrived on Wednesday morning, and no false keys or burglars' implements of any sort were found in the building. The probability is that BROCKMAN was accidentally locked in the factory and fell down stairs while groping in the dark.

abstract: It is a very serious question how far a Postmaster is to be held responsible, in cases of pecuniary loss resulting from a failure to do his whole duty in respect to the custody of letters passing through his hands.
lead_paragraph: It is a very serious question how far a Postmaster is to be held responsible, in cases of pecuniary loss resulting from a failure to do his whole duty in respect to the custody of letters passing through his hands. When it is clearly shown that such loss has been the result of his own gross carelessness or that of his subordinates, or the general bad management of his office, it would seem no more than just that such liability should follow.

abstract: A violent gale of wind visited the City last evening, and appears to have extended over several hundred miles of territory North and South.
lead_paragraph: A violent gale of wind visited the City last evening, and appears to have extended over several hundred miles of territory North and South. At Albany it was accompanied by a blinding snowstorm. In Philadelphia, there was no snow, but a violent hurricane, which did much damage. In Baltimore, it was still more fierce; the tide fell three feet in the harbor, trees were uprooted, chimneys demolished, and upwards of thirty houses unroofed. Telegraphic communication with this City was much interrupted in consequence of the prostration of the lines.

abstract: About two weeks since, a poor German girl applied to the Commissioners of Emigration for admission to Ward's Island Hospital, in anticipation of her near confinement, representing that she had been seduced by a young man soon after her arrival in the City.
lead_paragraph: About two weeks since, a poor German girl applied to the Commissioners of Emigration for admission to Ward's Island Hospital, in anticipation of her near confinement, representing that she had been seduced by a young man soon after her arrival in the City. As is usual in such cases, the Commissioners compelled her to make a complaint against her betrayer, for whom a warrant of arrest was issued by one of the Police Justices at Jefferson Market Court. While the woman awaited the appearance of the accused she was seen at Court by Officer Fischer, a policeman of the Twentieth Ward, who entered into conversation with her, and having learned the circumstances of her case, advised her to forego the prosecution and leave the matter to him, saying that a settlement might be effected, which would result to her pecuniary advantage. She accordingly quietly left the Court, and when the accused was brought in it became necessary to discharge him on account of the absence of the prosecutrix. A few days later Fischer called upon the seducer and frightened him into the payment of $45, under the representation that for that amount the woman had agreed to relinquish any and all claims upon him -- five dollars of the sum being given to a man in Eighth-avenue, who personated a lawyer and drew up the written release. The policeman afterwards called upon the woman whom he accompanied to the office of the Board of Charities and Correction, and by swearing that she had been six years in the country, under an assumed name procured for her a permit to Bellevue Hospital. Before seeing her safely in the Institution he told her that he had only been able to obtain seventeen dollars from her betrayer, one dollar of which sum he demanded as a recompense for his trouble, and $12 in addition as the entrance fee to the Hospital. The affair having thus been arranged, Fischer was congratulating himself upon the success of his rascality, when he was summoned a few days since before the Board of Police Commissioners, and to his surprise, tried upon a complaint for unofficer-like conduct, growing out of the transaction, which resulted on Wednesday in his dismissal from the force. His roguery was divulged in this way. The Commissioners of Emigration having suddenly last sight of the woman, feared that she had been foully dealt with, and, of course, sent to her seducer for an explanation; he told how he had settled the matter. Next the wards of Bellevue Hospital were searched, and the woman having seen found there, made a statement of Fischer's dealings with her.

abstract: It is quite common to regard the political difficulties of the day as simply a crisis, to be met and its consequences averted as promptly as possible, and then suffered to fall into the same oblivion which overtakes all the events of current political history.
lead_paragraph: It is quite common to regard the political difficulties of the day as simply a crisis, -- to be met and its consequences averted as promptly as possible, and then suffered to fall into the same oblivion which overtakes all the events of current political history. Future students of the annals of this day will view it in a different light. They will see in it one of the most deliberate and gigantic CONSPIRACIES which have ever threatened the subversion of powerful nations, or aimed at the overthrow of great States. And the problem will be to trace it to its origin, and to follow the successive stages of its progress and development.

abstract: The returns of the election in Virginia, as given in the Petersburgh Express, of Feb. 6, present some interesting features.
lead_paragraph: The returns of the election in Virginia, as given in the Petersburgh Express, of Feb. 6, present some interesting features. Out of 44 Counties then reported 32 had elected conservative candidates, -- some of them for the Union in any event. Among those best known to the country at large who have been returned, are Hon. Timothy Rives, who defeated Edward Ruffin, Jr., by an overwhelming majority; Messrs. Baldwin, Baylor, and A.H. Stuart, elected from Augusta County; Hon. Wm. Ballard Preston, from Montgomery County; Hon. W.L. Goggin, from Bedford County, and Hon. Sherrard Clemens, from Ohio County. Then it is settled that Ex-Secretary Floyd has been defeated in Washington County, and that Campbell and Grant, conservatives, have been returned. Ex-Governor Wise had a Methodist clergyman to contend with in Princess Ann County, and it is by no means certain that he has defeated him. In commenting on the result the Richmond Dispatch insists on people at the North making a distinction between Unionists and Submissionists, and expresses a belief that Virginia will be content with no settlement that does not restore the whole Union. If that cannot be accomplished, she will, of choice, as well as from the necessity of her position, go with a Southern Confederacy.

abstract: We trust that Congress will not fail to take some effective action to prevent the premature renewal of the patent for McCORMICK'S reaper.
lead_paragraph: We trust that Congress will not fail to take some effective action to prevent the premature renewal of the patent for MCCORMICK's reaper. We have already stated the facts which render such action simply a matter of justice to the farmers of the whole country. There is not the slightest necessity for a hasty decision of the point by the Patent Office, for the present patent does not expire until October next, and every consideration of justice and fair dealing requires that so important a step should not be taken without a much more full investigation than this application has yet received. The effect of renewing the patent will be to compel every farmer to pay something over fifty dollars for every reaping machine he may use, -- not for the cost of its construction, but simply as tribute to Mr. MCCORMICK for the privilege of having one made. The only possible justification for such an act in any case, lies in the fact that the inventor has not been sufficiently rewarded for the time, labor and ingenuity bestowed upon his invention. This reason cannot be urged in the present case, for Mr. MCCORMICK has already received more than a million dollars for his invention.

abstract: THE ABSON WIFE POISONING CASE -- VERDICT OF GUILTY. -- In the Hudson County Court of Oyer and Terminer, Attorney-General DAYTON occupied the entire day in summing up on the part of the State, in the case of WM. ABSON, charged with the murder of his wife by poison. The learned counsel alluded to the feeling existing between ABSON and his wife, and compared it with the other circumstances attending the case; of his friendship for the girl JULIA KENNEDAY, her effrontery when upon the stand, and other matters which the counsel contended was a cause for wishing to be rid of his wife. The evidence was reviewed at length, and the argument closed with a most able and eloquent appeal to the jury to vindicate the law of the land. His Honor Judge OGDEN then delivered his charge to the jury. It was impartial and just, and seemed to meet the approval of both sides. The evidence was graphically reviewed and the law explained on all doubtful points. In the charge the Judge took occasion to allude to the reporters who have attended the trial, expressing his satisfaction at the correctness of their reports, and also for their refraining from expressing any opinion as to the guilt or innocence of the accused. At 20 minutes to 5 o'clock the jury retired to deliberate; and after being out four hours, came into court with a verdict of "Guilty of murder in the first degree." When the verdict was pronounced, the prisoner exhibited the first sign of trepidation that he has manifested during the trial. His face flushed, and his restless demeanor gave evident symptoms of anxiety. Sentence will be pronounced on Tuesday morning at 10 o'clock. None of the family or relations of the prisoner were present when the fatal verdict was pronounced.

abstract: A WARNING. A large number of housekeepers were brought before Justice CONNOLLY, yesterday, on complaint of the Corporation Attorney, for violating a...
lead_paragraph: A WARNING. -- A large number of housekeepers were brought before Justice CONNOLLY, yesterday, on complaint of the Corporation Attorney, for violating a City ordinance by the non-removal of ice and snow from the sidewalk in front of their premises. The delinquents were fined $2 50 each, when by paying 25c. each in the first instance, to have the snow removed, they would have saved both time and money. A large number of persons have received injuries, recently, by the violation of this ordinance, and the prosecuting officer has resolved to bring all the delinquents to justice.

abstract: This Bureau is, just now, one of the busiest in the City, the Commissioners being engaged during office hours in hearing the statements of the property owners and non-owners who crowd there to correct their taxes. In every case an affidavit must be drawn up and sworn to in person. No complaint has yet been made by the Commissioners of any delay in asking a diminution of taxes, though in most cases the payment is postponed until the latest day possible, and there has never been but one case of a party seeking an increase of his taxes, and that, which occurred last year, was duly noted in the TIMES. Corrections may be made until June, when the books will be amended.

abstract: MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE OF A SUPPOSED SLAVER. -- About a week ago, a fine clipper bark of 800 tons, called the Griffin, Capt. DAVIS, quietly left her moorings in New-York, and slipped over to Elizabethport. She was in full ballast, and was ready for sea, but had no cargo of any sort on board. It happened, however, that she left six thousand dollars worth of shipping liens in New-York. She had been recently coppered, refitted throughout, and provisioned for a long voyage, and had left the jurisdiction of the Sheriff and Marshal of New-York without discharging her liabilities. As she had no ostensible honest reason for going to Elizabethport, the creditors concluded that they were to be "done" in some manner out of the amount of their claims, and accordingly libeled the Griffin. She was seized on Monday by Mr. WM. H. JELLIFFE, an attorney for the New-York claimants, and put into the custody of the United States Marshal and the Sheriff. On Tuesday night, however, Capt. DAVIS gave the Sheriff's officers and Marshal's tip-slaves the slip, and went to sea without his papers. Where he has gone to is only a matter of conjecture, but the presumption of parties interested is that the destination of the Griffin, is not far from the Congo River. The libelants at first thought of chartering a clipper to go in pursuit of her; but as she is an exceedingly fleet vessel, and her route is somewhat uncertain, the experiment will hardly be tried. -- Newark Mercury, Feb. 7.

abstract: HOW THE PRINCE WENT TO COLLEGE. The English Press found cause for merriment, in the fact that our people manifested great curiosity concerning the Prince of Wales, during his recent visit to this country, and they lost no opportunity which could be used as a text for good-natured raillery and innocent sarcasm.
lead_paragraph: HOW THE PRINCE WENT TO COLLEGE. -- The English Press found cause for merriment, in the fact that our people manifested great curiosity concerning the Prince of Wales, during his recent visit to this country, and they lost no opportunity which could be used as a text for good-natured raillery and innocent sarcasm. By the papers recently received, we find that an equal amount of curious interest, of anxious impertinence, and pertinacious pushing was discoverable on the occasion of the matriculation of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, at Cambridge. The Prince, accompanied by Major-General BRUCE and Capt. GREY, entered the city at twelve o'clock, and immediately the "joy-bells" were rung, a vast procession of spectators gathered, and everything and body was in a topsy-turvy state. The Chancellor of the University was honored with a presentation to the Prince, as was all the professors, doctors and bigwigs. After this, the Corporation were presented, and then the Chief Magistrate read the following civic address:

abstract: The completion of the Bergen tunnel, one of the most important public works of New-Jersey, and a triumph of engineering skill of which any State might be proud, was duly celebrated Wednesday, when the...
lead_paragraph: The completion of the Bergen tunnel, one of the most important public works of New-Jersey, and a triumph of engineering skill of which any State might be proud, was duly celebrated Wednesday, when the tunnel was formally opened and the first train of cars passed through it. This work was built by a corporation known as the Long Dock Company, mainly for the benefit of the Erie Railroad Company, who are understood to have advanced a large share of the money for its construction, and who hold a lease of the improvement. By means of it, the business of the Erie Railroad is brought to tide-water mark, and to immediate contact with this City, thus saving the great expense and delay of shipping their freight to Piermont. The tunnel is 4,000 feet, or upwards of three-quarters of a mile in length, running the whole distance through a solid rock of the most adamantine species, and from fifty to two hundred feet beneath the surface of the earth. It has been five years in process of construction, and its cost has been a fraction less than two millions of dollars. From the commencement of the work there have been from 1,000 to 1,400 men employed on it, and the loss of life by accident has been about two dozen persons.

abstract: Yesterday morning a writ of replevin was served upon Police-Superintendent KENNEDY for the thirty-eight cases of muskets seized three weeks since on board the steamer Monticello, as contraband of war. On the 30th ultimo, Mr. G.B. LAMAR, President of the Bank of the Republic, had an interview with Mr. KENNEDY, to whom he represented that he had been authorized by the Adjutant-General of the State of Georgia, who had purchased the arms from the Directors of a Bank at Hartford, Conn., to receive them and forward them to Georgia. Mr. KENNEDY replied that no claimant had appeared, and he did not intend to surrender the muskets until one presented himself. With this answer the conversation ended, but last Friday Mr. KENNEDY received a note from MANN & PARSONS, attorneys at-law, on behalf of Mr. WM. H. CALLENDER, making a formal demand for the arms. Mr. KENNEDY at once placed the matter in the hands of his counsel, who entered into negotiations with the claimant's representatives, and the result was the delivery of the muskets.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning a writ of replevin was served upon Police-Superintendent KENNEDY for the thirty-eight cases of muskets seized three weeks since on board the steamer Monticello, as contraband of war. Mr. KENNEDY replied that no claimant had appeared, and he did not intend to surrender the muskets until one presented himself. With this answer the conversation ended, but last Friday Mr. KENNEDY received a note from MANN & PARSONS, attorneys at-law, on behalf of Mr. WM. H. CALLENDER, making a formal demand for the arms. Mr. KENNEDY at once placed the matter in the hands of his counsel, who entered into negotiations with the claimant's representatives, and the result was the delivery of the muskets.

abstract: When the new King of Prussia told his assembled Generals a few days ago of a probable demand for their active services during the coming Spring, Something more than curiosity prompted an inquiry as to which way the eagles of Brandenburg as to take their fight.
lead_paragraph: When the new King of Prussia told his assembled Generals a few days ago of a probable demand for their active services during the coming Spring, Something more than curiosity prompted an inquiry as to which way the eagles of Brandenburg as to take their fight. It might be toward the Rhine, for France is supposed to nurse just now with unusual ardor all the predilections for a Rhenish frontier which were handed down from Louis XIV. It might be toward the Po; for there were confident assertions in a half-dozen usually well-informed quarters that a treaty has been arranged between Russia, Prussia and Austria, for the preservation to the latter of Venice. Or lastly, and more probably, it might be toward the Eider, the stream dividing the Danish Province of Schleswig from Holstein; for the difficulties between the last-named Duchy and the Danish Crown have again assumed dangerous proportions, inviting the pacificatory intervention of a German army. The latter contingency, we say, is more likely, for the simple reason that the Ministry which, twelve years ago, led Prussia to the adoption of a warlike policy on this very question, is once more in power in the person of Baron SCHLEINITZ, who is known to have a more than German pertinacity in his ideas.

abstract: Late, and it is believed reliable, intelligence from Charleston states that the four or five old hulks which were sunk in the main ship channel of Charleston harbor have been broken up by the action of easterly storms, and wholly swept away, leaving, of course, the stones used to sink them upon the bottom. The brig Emily St. Pierre is reported to have passed in without obstruction. It is said she drew 16 feet of water but this can hardly be correct, as she discharged a part of her cargo at Savannah. Capt. ADKINS, of the Marion, and BERRY, of the Columbia, insist that the channel obstructions still remain, and that it is not possible to pass in or out that way.

abstract: Rev. NICHOLAS MURRAY, D.D., died, at Elizabeth, New-Jersey, on Monday evening last. He was born in Ireland, in December, 1802, and, as his parents were Roman Catholics, he was brought up in that religion. When but sixteen years of age he came to this country, and became connected with the establishment of HARPER & BROTHERS, in this City. His active mind did not find itself satisfied with the doctrines of the Church in which he was educated, and soon after his arrival here, he abjured Roman Catholicism, and embraced the Protestant faith. At once he determined to devote himself to the Ministry, and, having completed his preparatory studies, he entered Williams College, where he graduated, in 1826. After having finished his theological course at the Princeton Seminary, he was settled over the Presbyterian Church, in Wilkesbarre, Pa., where he remained until July, 1834, when he was called to the Church in Elizabeth, N.J., of which he was Pastor at the time of his death. The title of Doctor of Divinity was conferred upon him by the College of which he was an alumnus, in 1842. Prominent as Dr. MURRAY has been in the denomination to which he was attached, he has gained a still wider celebrity through the medium of his controversial writings. The letters which he wrote some years since to Archbishop HUGHES under the signature "Kirwan" were very extensively circulated in this country and did not serve to increase the reputation of the distinguished prelate to whom they were addressed, inasmuch as he found himself decidedly overmatched. So popular were those letters on account of the ability which marked them, and the genial and genuine Irish humor by which they were pervaded, that they were translated into several foreign languages and scattered through Europe. Another volume on a kindred subject, entitled Romanism at Home, was the result of a visit made to Europe in 1851. Last summer Dr. MURRAY again crossed the Atlantic, partly professionally, but chiefly for his health, and during his absence, contributed a series of interesting letters to the New-York Observer, -- the same paper which first published the Kirwan letters. So much did he seem benefited by this trip that long years of usefulness were anticipated for him. The announcement of his death will fall with startling suddenness upon his wide circle of friends and upon the still larger number of those to whom he was so well known by reputation.

abstract: Collector COLCOCK, of Charleston, applied, on the 21st of January, to Ex-Judge MAGRATH, now Gov. PICKENS' Secretary of State, asking him for advice as to the course to be pursued in the event of interference by the Government at Washington with the clearance of vessels and the payment of duties.
lead_paragraph: Collector COLCOCK, of Charleston, applied, on the 21st of January, to Ex-Judge MAGRATH, now Gov. PICKENS' Secretary of State, asking him for advice as to the course to be pursued in the event of interference by the Government at Washington with the clearance of vessels and the payment of duties. Under date of January 29, Judge MAGRATH replies in a long and rather obscure communication, stating that the difficulties anticipated must occur, if they occur at all, with vessels of three classes -- those owned by foreign powers, or those owned by States in the Union, and by the States out of the Union. With regard to the first class no difficulty can be foreseen, as the principles of public law, as recognized at Washington on this point, are plain. All treaties with the United States recognize the law under those treaties as binding upon all the States, and such treaties continue binding on the States which still maintain the Confederation known as the United States. Judge MAGRATH then proceeds to discuss the status of South Carolina. She has resumed her independence, he says, and only those States which maintain the existence of the United States as a despotism deny this fact. If a State, he says, has not a right to secede from the United States, then would the consequences have followed, that being free before the adoption of the Constitution, it lost its freedom by becoming a party to a compact to secure, among other things, a more perfect freedom.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFF MAN, the first case called was that of Michael McBride, indicted for an attempt at rape upon young woman by the name of Mary Hosey, the first witness, who testified...
lead_paragraph: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, the first case called was that of Michael McBride, indicted for an attempt at rape upon young woman by the name of Mary Hosey, the first witness, who testified that she was servant in the family of Mr. Underwood; she was 20 years of age; on the 2d of December last she was returning from Manhattanville, starting from that place at about 8 1/2 o'clock in the evening; she walked the entire distance; when she had reached the vicinity of One Hundredth-street, the prisoner, whom she had never seen before, met and accosted her, offering to accompany her home; she attempted to escape from him; but only succeeded after he had made several assaults upon her, attempting the offence of which he was charged; the screams of the witness attracted some policemen, who rescued her and took her home.

abstract: One of the most furious gales that have visited this region for many months past commenced in this City last evening. Beginning with a slight snow-squall about 5 o'clock P.M., which soon blew over and left a cloudless sky, the wind continued to increase in violence until late in the night, and even at the time of going to press (2 1/2 A.M.) it has scarcely abated any of its fury. Simultaneously with the commencement of the gale, the mercury suddenly fell several degrees, and the weather continued to grow colder as the gale increased. We have heard of no serious damage being done in the City, but it is scarcely possible that the shipping in the harbor and on the coast should have escaped uninjured.

abstract: The United States store-ship Supply, which brought home from Pensacola the wives of Lieuts. SLEMMER and GILMAN, of Fort Pickens, had also on board a number of ordinaries who have been attached to the Warrenton Navy-yard, and who were present when it was ingloriously surrendered by Commodore ARMSTRONG. Among them was an old Quartermaster named WM. CONWAY, who has been a great many years in the service, being last with Capt. TURNER, in the United States ship Saratoga. When the fillibusters from Alabama and Florida marched through the gate and took formal possession of the Yard, without opposition from the Commandant, old CONWAY was a witness of the proceedings, and manifested in every possible way his deep mortification and disgust. On being ordered to haul down the flag, he slowly and sullenly obeyed. The crowd gathered around the flag-staff, to witness and jeer at this act of humiliation of the Government. As the starry folds in their descent touched the head of the old sailor, he could no longer restrain his feelings, tears gushed from his eyes, and, in an agony of grief and mortification, he clasped the old flag in his arms, buried his face in its folds, and kissed it repeatedly. Derisive shouts only greeted this act, and nothing but the venerable years and hearty sincerity of the old sailor, saved him from summary acts of violence by the mob. CONWAY is still on board of the Supply, at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, and frequently expresses his sorrow that he should have lived to see his country's flag dishonored by her own citizens.

abstract: We have attempted, in preceding articles, to analyze Southern society, and to show what elements, in the nature of things, are most active in the present revolutionary commotion.
lead_paragraph: We have attempted, in preceding articles, to analyze Southern society, and to show what elements, in the nature of things, are most active in the present revolutionary commotion. We have shown how inconsiderable in number is the class of large slaveholders, and pointed out the considerations which must impose upon it, by a law of self-preservation, the necessity of a conservative reaction. This reaction, we learn from various sources, is actually taking place. We have also pointed out where the real strength of the South and of the Pro-Slavery cause lies, viz.: in the middle and smaller classes of slaveholders, and in the great body of intelligent non-slaveholders.

abstract: The question of revenue is beginning to enlist considerable discussion in South Carolina. One of the most prominent of the grievances of that State against the Federal Government has hitherto been the tariff on imports, and it has been taken for granted by the great majority of people, within the State and beyond its borders, that the new Republic would certainly adopt Free Trade and direct taxation as the basis of its revenue system.

abstract: Col. HAYNE, the Special Envoy of South Caro lina, and Lieut. HALL, the messenger of Major ANDERSON, left Washington yesterday, bearing dispatches upon which depend possibly the question of peace or war the former with the refusal of the Government to surrender Fort Sumter, in...
lead_paragraph: Col. HAYNE, the Special Envoy of South Carolina, and Lieut. HALL, the messenger of Major ANDERSON, left Washington yesterday, bearing dispatches upon which depend possibly the question of peace or war -- the former with the refusal of the Government to surrender Fort Sumter, in accordance with the desire of South Carolina, and the latter with the final instructions of the Government to the faithful officer to whom has been intrusted the command and defence of that fort. The impression seems to prevail in Washington, however, that an attack upon it will not take place immediately, notwithstanding the bravado of the South Carolinians, and their professed anxiety to pull down that "hated flag."

abstract: THE KING OF THE SKATERS. LOUIS NAPO LEON seems to be as much at home upon skates as he is on horseback. He, with the Empress and prominent members of their suites, is in the habit of indulging frequently in that amusement, and on a...
lead_paragraph: THE KING OF THE SKATERS. -- LOUIS NAPOLEON seems to be as much at home upon skates as he is on horseback. He, with the Empress and prominent members of their suites, is in the habit of indulging frequently in that amusement, and on a recent occasion went to a large pond opposite Suresnes for that purpose. As soon as the Emperor and the Court arrived, the sport commenced in very business-like style. The Empress got into a sledge, and M. HARTOGS, a German gentleman, whose proficiency as a skater attracted the Imperial notice two years ago, and who is now called at Court the Emperor's Aid-de-Camp de glace, had the honor of pushing Her Majesty on the ice. He look her along at railroad speed, and was out of sight of shore in less than a minute. The Emperor then put on his skates, and conducted the sledge of a lady whose name I could not learn. Afterwards Her Majesty ventured to skate, but only with the assistance of two gentlemen. She is not at her ease upon the ice, and, considering that she comes from sunny Spain, this is not to be wondered at. The Emperor is a very good skater. He does not attempt any tours de force, but he is perfectly master of his movements. His wont is to go along rather slowly, and he stops frequently to contemplate the animated scene around him. Not the least etiquette is observed on the ice. No clear space is kept about the Emperor or Empress. They go about just like anybody else, and to-day, unlike last evening, everybody, without exception, was allowed to skate at the same time with them. The Emperor had nothing whatever but his own adroitness to prevent him from being knocked over by the first tyro in the sport whose skates might run away with him. It was an interesting sight to see the master of so many legions, the mighty potentate upon whose mysterious breath the fate of so many nations hangs, slipping about unpretentiously on the ice, no squire or even servant following him, and apparently as much on an equality with the people about him as a carter is with a plowman on an English farm-yard pond. Once a young man, who saw the Emperor skating slowly along the middle of the lake, steered almost indiscreetly close to him and gave him the go by, with the evident intention of getting credit with the spectators for being the best skater. The Emperor then, without any apparent effort, increased his speed, gracefully distanced his opponent by a few yards, and, contented with his victory, resumed the steady pace which he seems to affect.

abstract: The most important literary announcement of the present year is undoubtedly the fact that the fifth volume of Lord MACAULAY'S History of England is preparing for publication, under the editorship of his sister, Lady TREVELYAN.
lead_paragraph: -- The most important literary announcement of the present year is undoubtedly the fact that the fifth volume of Lord MACAULAY's History of England is preparing for publication, under the editorship of his sister, Lady TREVELYAN. It will contain the continuation of that work as far us the manuscript was left revised by him. The narrative is in immediate connection with the fourth volume, and, with two exceptions, is complete and consecutive, ending with the death of WILLIAM III. A full index to the entire work will be given in this volume. In confining the publication to the portion which received the author's last revision his literary executors practice a wise and considerate reticence -- too often entirely lost sight of. MACAULAY'S finished works are enough to secure his place in literature, and no good purpose is served by exposing the fragmentery rough drafts and sketches of the consummate artist. His treasures now, in the English Library Edition, will fill twelve volumes, octavo, ("History," 5 vols.; "Critical Essays," 3 vols.; "Miscellanies," 2 vols.; "Parliamentary Speeches," 1 vol.; "Poems and Ballads," 1 vol.,) a bulk not inconsiderable for one who was not a professed writer, and more certain to be kept in reremembrance than if their voluminousness was doubled.

abstract: On Thursday afternoon a person called at the bookstore of Mr. James Miller, No 554 Broadway, and represented himself as a bibliopole from Albany, named Henry King, who desired to make some additions to his library. Mr. Thomas R. Knox, one of the clerks in the establishment, obligingly displayed the treasures of the store, and King made a selection of valuable works. Mr. Knox, however, had occasion to suspect the honesty of his customer, who placed a handsome volume of Byron and an elegant edition of Homer beneath his cloak, and prepared to go away without paying for them. His exit was prevented, and a policeman sent for, who recovered the stolen volumes, and arrested the well-dressed thief. Waxing exceedingly wroth at the exposure, the prisoner sought revence by firing at the keen-eyed salesman with a revolver. The aim, however, was not well taken, and the ball entered the floor some distance in the rear of the intended victim. King was taken before Justice CONNOLLY, who imprisoned him for trial in default of $1,000 bail, on the charge of felonious assault.

abstract: We published, a day or two since, with brief remarks, elaborate articles from the London Times and Economist, upon the great theme, just now, in England, cotton. As 4,000,000...
lead_paragraph: We published, a day or two since, with brief remarks, elaborate articles from the London Times and Economist, upon the great theme, just now, in England, cotton. As 4,000,000 people in that country derive their support from the manufacture of this article, the question of supply, by which they are to be employed, is an all-absorbing one. England has long been impatient of the thraldom in which it has been held by its dependence upon the United States for a regular supply, and is now subjecting the whole world to a careful examination and analysis for the purpose of finding other fields for its production. That success is speedily to follow her efforts there is no doubt. Cotton is a plant that can be grown almost universally in the tropics, and to suppose that it cannot be raised in other countries as well as in the United States, would be as absurd as to affirm that we have the only soils well adapted to wheat and corn.

abstract: Comparatively few visited Central Park yesterday it was so cold. Comparatively few, therefore, enjoyed some of the best skating that has been afforded there this season. The many made a monstrous...
lead_paragraph: Comparatively few visited Central Park yesterday -- it was so cold. Comparatively few, therefore, enjoyed some of the best skating that has been afforded there this season. The many made a monstrous mistake. You might as well object that a fire is too hot for burning, or that snow is too slippery for sleighing, or that bells are too merry for jingling, or a State too seditious for seceding, as to urge that weather like that of yesterday is too frigid for a frolic on the ice. A nipping and an eager air gives zest to exercise on runners, as spices give snap to vapid viands; and skating, like beef, is made much more a la mode when some pungent relish is added. Who would prefer a sweltering August day, if nature permitted the anomaly, for a ride over the whitened, frozen, cracklink ground, to a season in which buffaloes and boon companions huddled around you are a comfort, and the body is braced and full of electricity, and the lungs are clear, and laughter and the bells bells ring out cheerily on the rushing wintry blast? And why should one rather skate when the weather is Spring-like and when one is not so buoyantly inclined to the exertion, and when but little effort warms one too completely, than when the gale is biting and savage, and tries to tie up your veins and curdle your blood, and throws down his icy gauntlet, and dares you to the combat -- you and all your caloric -- and shouts in your ear, and breathes defiance in your face, rouses all your spirit for the conflict, and only yields after you've overtaken him with earnest strides, and, panting, trample him beneath your sandal of steel? To follow, in such an atmosphere, fleet as "an arrow of light" in the wake of the howling wind -- it is a joy akin to that "____which warriors feel In foemen worthy of their steel."

abstract: Yesterday morning, between 2 and 3 o'clock, the alarm bells, which had called the firemen out already three times for the Third and Fourth Districts, sounded for the Eighth District, and the weary, half frozen firemen hastened to the spot with their accustomed alacrity. The night reminded old firemen of the great fires of 1835 and 1836, when the water froze in the hose, and when every fireman not near enough to the flames to be thawed out, presented the appearance of a warrior encased in armor of ice. Last night the wind blew a perfect hurricane, and, as in 1835, the cold was so intense as to freeze every drop of water as it fell.

abstract: We publish this morning the demand of Col. HAYNE for the surrender of Fort Sumter, and the President's peremptory refusal, through the Secretary of War. The correspondence is as interesting as it is important. Col. HAYNE'S letter is long, and by no means lacking in ability. He assumes throughout the absolute independence of South Carolina, and thus escapes the most difficult part of the argument which the emergency would seem to require. He aims merely to convince the President that it will be much better for him and the country to surrender the fort than to attempt to hold it.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning the demand of Col. HAYNE for the surrender of Fort Sumter, and the President's peremptory refusal, through the Secretary of War. The correspondence is as interesting as it is important. Col. HAYNE'S letter is long, and by no means lacking in ability. He assumes throughout the absolute independence of South Carolina, and thus escapes the most difficult part of the argument which the emergency would seem to require. He aims merely to convince the President that it will be much better for him and the country to surrender the fort than to attempt to hold it.

abstract: MILITARY BALL.-Company B, (National Greys,) Capt. SPRAGUE, of the Thirteenth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., gave their annual ball in the Academy of Music, Thursday night. The ball was one of the most suc-
lead_paragraph: MILITARY BALL. -- Company B, (National Greys,) Capt. SPRAGUE, of the Thirteenth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., gave their annual ball in the Academy of Music, Thursday night. The ball was one of the most successful affairs of the kind ever given in this city. Among the military gentlemen present were Major-Gen. DURYEA and Staff, Brigadier-Gen. CROOKE and Staff, Col. DURYEA, formerly of the Seventh Regiment, and officers representing the Seventh, Eighth, Ninth, Fifty-fifth and Seventy-first Regiments of New-York, and also the different Regiments in Kings County. The band of the Seventh Regiment, containing seventy piece, furnished music for the occasion. The great feature was a drill by Capt. SPRAGUE'S command. This commenced at about 11 1/2 o'clock, when the floor was cleared and thirty members of the corps were marched in by Capt SPRAGUE. The Company was formed in two ranks and exercised in the manual of arms, according to SCOTT'S heavy Infantry tactic -- first by the word of command, next by tap of the drum, and finally the "silent drill." The Company was then formed in three ranks and went through with the same manoeuvers, adding thereto the stacking and unstacking of muskets. The company retired, and dancing was resumed. Subsequently the floor was again cleared and the Company returned, dressed in the Zouave uniform, and went through with a part of HARDEE'S Light Infantry tactics. The drill in SCOTT'S tactics was unexceptionable. In the Zouave drill, the Company manifested a surprising proficiency, considering the very short time they have been practicing, and their efforts were frequently applauded. At the conclusion of the drill, dancing was again resumed and kept up until a late hour.

abstract: A very good story is told concerning the doings at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The Directors have, doubtless which the best and most moral intentions, been so very scrupulous as to what should be allowed therein and what should not, as to rather throw ridicule on the whole affair. A time-honored custom at Mr. BEECHER'S, Dr. STORRS', and other popular churches, is for the Deacons and Trustees to officiate as Ushers, seating strangers and looking out for the general good behavior of the boys. Several of these gentlemen are Directors of the Academy, and the story runs that a couple, who had not secured seats in advance approached one of them on Tuesday night, when the following conversation ensued:

abstract: Family quarrels have an irresistible attraction, as well for dwellers in Vanity Fair, as for the innumerable many who live in the suburbs of that giddy metropolis. And it maybe a safe proposition, perhaps, to lay down that the interest increases with the magnitude of the parties implicated, insomuch that they, who turn in scorn from the story of hostilities between Pat and Bridget, are ravished with a scene between Augustus Fitz-Green and Mary, his wife, of Thirteenth-avenue; and simply go wild over a difficulty between King Cole and Queen Cunigonde, or a divorce case in which King GEORGE and Queen CAROLINE are to figure. Now in Paris a quarrel of even more than royal dimensions is engaging the thoughts of all men, women and girls. The Emperor, who so wisely rules France, and so adroitly manages Europe, has confessed himself unable to govern his own family; and the aid of the Courts having been invoked, the whole matter is to be pleaded in public on and after the 24th of this current month of February. The parties to this interesting bit of litigation are Mr. JEROME BONAPARTE, of Baltimore, the son of the late King JEROME, of Westphalia, by his first wife, and Prince NAPOLEON and the Princess MATHILDE, the fruit of a second marriage of the same potentate. What the law has to determine is to which of his wives was the Ex-King legally married; for one or the other union was clearly illegal, and the posterity which sprang from it illegitimate.
lead_paragraph: Family quarrels have an irresistible attraction, as well for dwellers in Vanity Fair, as for the innumerable many who live in the suburbs of that giddy metropolis. The Emperor, who so wisely rules France, and so adroitly manages Europe, has confessed himself unable to govern his own family; and the aid of the Courts having been invoked, the whole matter is to be pleaded in public on and after the 24th of this current month of February. The parties to this interesting bit of litigation are Mr. JEROME BONAPARTE, of Baltimore, the son of the late King JEROME, of Westphalia, by his first wife, and Prince NAPOLEON and the Princess MATHILDE, the fruit of a second marriage of the same potentate. What the law has to determine is to which of his wives was the Ex-King legally married; for one or the other union was clearly illegal, and the posterity which sprang from it illegitimate.

abstract: A very successful performance of "Ernani," and of one act from "Lucia," at the Brooklyn Academy, on Saturday night, brought the operatic week to an end. The house was one of the best of the season, and was of course highly remunerative. Here in New-York we have done little towards supporting the opera, and it is conceded that without Brooklyn the season of the Associate Artists would have been of remarkable brevity. Fortunately the two cities make the enterprise a good one, and there seems to be a prospect that we shall have an energetic Spring campaign. Especially will this be so if VERDI's new opera, "Un ballo in Maschera," which is to be brought out at the Academy (New-York) to-night, achieves the success which is expected of it. The rehearsals have been conducted with much industry, and the artists are unanimous in their praise of the work. The caste includes the names of Mesdames COLSON, HINKLEY and PHILLIPS; Messrs. BRIGNOLI, FERRI, SUSINI, &c. The first performance of an opera is always a fashionable event, and the attendance tonight will certainly be brilliant.

abstract: The interests of publishers and of engravers, generally, go hand in hand. Literature and art are twin sisters, and so strong is the sympathetic bond between them that whatever touches the one affects the other in like degree. Publishers complain of poverty this Winter and engravers are also deploring a lack of employment.
lead_paragraph: The interests of publishers and of engravers, generally, go hand in hand. Literature and art are twin sisters, and so strong is the sympathetic bond between them that whatever touches the one affects the other in like degree. Publishers complain of poverty this Winter and engravers are also deploring a lack of employment. Beyond multiplying the features of Presidential candidates and furnishing the country with an idea of how seceding Senators and Secretaries -- a collection by the way that would make a very valuable addition to the "Rogues Gallery" -- look, the latter gentlemen have done little during the present season. This stagnation is more severely felt since Winter is the harvest-time of engravers and artists generally. It is in anticipation of the long evenings that people seek those surroundings which shall make home pleasant; they look around for something to break the pale monotony of the walls and relieve the polished baldness of the centre-table. Notwithstanding the general dulness, however, the enterprising house of ROE LOCKWOOD & SON have got a work under way which bids fair to rival anything of the kind ever before undertaken in this country. We allude to their series of Audulon's Birds of America, the initial plates of which are before us. The feathered Americans are drawn with a fidelity only equaled by the faithfulness of color with which their plumage is rendered. The work is expensive, and must necessarily have a somewhat contracted circulation, but it is very certain to attract the attention of ornithologists, and if its merit does not reach the heart and pockets of many of our merchant [???], it will be simply because they are rocked into an apathy to Art in the cradle of the Crisis.

abstract: The circumstances attending the death of Mrs. FANNY WHITE BLANKMAN, and the production of a will, said to have been made by her, leaving the bulk of her property to her husband, to whom she had not very long been married, created some sensation at the time of their occurrence; and the interest of the case has been steadily increasing since the evidence in regard to the Will has been in course of development before the Surrogate -- Mrs. BLANKMAN's blood relatives denouncing it as a forgery, and contesting it upon that ground.
lead_paragraph: The circumstances attending the death of Mrs. FANNY WHITE BLANKMAN, and the production of a will, said to have been made by her, leaving the bulk of her property to her husband, to whom she had not very long been married, created some sensation at the time of their occurrence; and the interest of the case has been steadily increasing since the evidence in regard to the Will has been in course of development before the Surrogate -- Mrs. BLANKMAN's blood relatives denouncing it as a forgery, and contesting it upon that ground.
