abstract: At a few minutes before 3 o'clock on Friday morning, Feb. 8, Dr. JOHN W. FRANCIS expired. For nine weeks he had been stretched on a bed of suffering. This unprecedented lapse of his usual professional activity and social enjoyment had in no small degree weaned him from that strong interest in life which was a peculiar trait of his character; and great physical pain had subdued the vivacity, while it failed to impair the clearness of his mind. Accordingly, there were times when he contemplated death with calmness as a desirable release; and on more than one occasion, he expressed his entire resignation to the will of God; at other times he rallied and indulged hopes of recovery -- hopes which his physicians, family and friends earnestly shared. The case was a peculiar one -- a prolonged nervous disturbance that interfered with sleep, and seriously lessened the assimilative process of the constitution, and a crisis resulted from poverty of blood. An ominous carbuncle on the back, gradually impaired the vital force; the process of healing commenced and progressed favorably -- but too late. The original trouble was complicated with another serious drain upon the patient's strength, and frequent attacks of exhaustion and collapse at length ended fatally. Dr. FRANCIS died in the full possession of his faculties, and without pain. He spoke words of affection and of faith, and expired surrounded by those most dear to him; and so perfectly conscious that his last hour had arrived, that he announced it distinctly and emphatically but a few moments before his departure. He has never been the same man since the loss of his eldest son, an event which occurred six years ago, and deprived him of the seasonable respite he proposed to himself, in resigning some of his professional cares to the inheritor of his talents and his tastes. Eminently blessed, however, in his remaining children, he lived to see them fulfill the best promise of their youth, and to experience their filial devotion in his lingering illness. To them and their widowed mother words of human consolation are unavailing.

abstract: MORTALITY. -- One hundred and thirty-eight deaths were reported to the Health Department during the week ending Saturday last, classified by the Health Officer, Dr. JONES, as follows: Men, 21; boys, 45; women, 25; girls, 47. Adults, 46; children, 92; males, 66; females, 72; colored persons, 5. There were 29 deaths by fevers, 26 of which were scarlet, 19 by consumption, 8 by inflammation of the lungs, 6 each by diptheria and dropsy in the head, 7 by convulsions, 5 by bronchitis, 4 each by congestion of the brain and croup, 3 each by dysentery, inflammation of the brain, marasmus (infantile) and small-pox; 2 each by apoplexy, compression of the brain, congestion of the lungs, debility (adult), inflammation of the bowels and palsy, and one each by abscess, disease of kidneys, asthma, bleeding from navel, bleeding from stomach, brain, convulsion (infantile), cyanosis, delirium tremens, enlargement of heart, congestive fever, typhoid fever, typhus fever, whooping cough, inflammation of stomach, inflammation, of womb, disease of lungs, old age, premature birth, scrofula, spirue, suffocation, teething, varioloid. Seventy-eight of those who died were children under 5 years of age; 107 were natives of the United States. The deaths occurred in the several wards as follows: First, 2; Second, 6; Third, 2; Fourth, 6; Fifth, 10; Sixth, 22; Seventh, 5; Eighth, 4; Ninth, 3; Tenth, 20; Eleventh, 16; Twelfth, 5; Thirteenth, 9; Fourteenth, 9; Fifteenth, 1; Sixteenth, 11; Seventeenth, 2; Eighteenth 2; Nineteenth, 3.

abstract: The new Empire is at last fairly launched, with Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, a name not unknown to fame, at its head. He has figured before the country as an officer in the Mexican War, as a member of both Houses of Congress, and also as a member of the Cabinet of the United States.
lead_paragraph: The new Empire is at last fairly launched, with Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, a name not unknown to fame, at its head. He has figured before the country as an officer in the Mexican War, as a member of both Houses of Congress, and also as a member of the Cabinet of the United States. The most marked events of his career were his earnest advocacy of the repudiation of the debts of his State, declared by its highest tribunals to be valid and binding; his strenuous opposition, as a Disunionist, to the compromise measures of 1850, when he was defeated in the contest for the Gubernatorial honors of his State, by Mr. H.S. FOOTE, the Union candidate; and by his real premiership of Mr. PIERCE's Administration, which soon followed. Upon the termination of this, he was again returned to the Senate of the United States, which he has just left to take the helm of the new Slaveholding Confederacy.

abstract: The State of Georgia has taken the bold step of seizing vessels in Savannah, the private property of citizens of New-York. This is in reprisal for the seizure in New-York by our Police, of arms belonging to the State of Georgia, -- and avowedly to be used by her in resisting the authority of the Federal Government. This step on the part of Georgia is calculated greatly to exasperate public sentiment here, and is utterly unwarranted and unjustifiable.
lead_paragraph: The State of Georgia has taken the bold step of seizing vessels in Savannah, the private property of citizens of New-York. abstract: -- No collection of paintings in this City has attracted so much attention or given such general satisfaction, as that of the French and Flemish pictures which were sold at public auction on the nights of Wednesday and Thursday last. The announcement that the gallery would be open free of charge, to those who wished to examine before purchasing, drew a room full of those who probably changed their minds after looking al the pictures, for when the auction opened, they were among the missing. The bidding was very spirited, and prices most extravagant, considering the state of finances generally, were obtained. But few pictures were withdrawn, and the vast majority sold at rates most satisfactory to the original proprietors, and doubtless gratifying to the bumps of approbativeness located on the craniums of the artists. SNUYDER's "Tour of Distia" brought the minimum rate $18; and MULLER's "Letter-writer of Venice" drew the moderate sum of $575. Other pictures had been disposed of at fancy prices at private sale, which were of greater value than these. One landscape, a small work of ROUSSEAU's, sold for $700, and others by eminent artists, brought from $500 to $800. On the whole, we think GOUPIL & Co. ought be satisfied with the result of their Third Annual Exhibition and Sale -- and we resume they are.

abstract: A VERY DANGEROUS BUILDING. -- The attention of the police has recently been called to a building in process of erection at Nos. 25 and 27 Washington-street, to be occupied as a tenement house, and owned by a man named BURKE. From the following description of the premises, any person having a tyro's knowledge of architecture can understand that the structure is in a dangerous condition and liable to fall at any moment: The building is sixty feet front and rear, with walls twelve inches thick. The sides are party walls into which the beams project three to four inches. There are two brick partitions running through the structure, which is six stories high. The walls are already cracked, and sag down in consequence of the piers on which they stand having given way. The ground on which the building stands is made, and spiles should have been driven in before the foundation was laid. There are no anchors or stirrup irons in the whole building, either in headers or trimmers, as the law requires. The whole structure is of old bricks and bats, and the timbers, including beams, are old and rotten. Considerable fear is expressed by persons having to pass the premises, but as yet no action has been taken in the case by the authorities.

abstract: The issuing of licenses for the City cars was completed on Saturday, by the payment, on the part of the Sixth-avenue Railroad Company, of the fees for forty cars, drawn by two horses, at $50 each, and twenty one-horse cars, at $20 -- making a total of $2,500 for this line alone, and, with the amount received on Thursday from the Eighth and Ninth avenue lines, make up the amount of $6,170 received in two days for this purpose alone.

abstract: The Richmond papers publish the correspondence between Judge ROBERTSON of Virginia, who went as Commissioner to South Carolina when Ex-President TYLER started for Washington, and Judge MAGRATH, Secretary of State to Gov. PICKENS. Judge ROBERTSON, writing under date of Jan. 29, explains the object of his mission, -- to secure guaranties from the seceded States that they would not commence hostilities against the General Government while negotiations for an adjustment were pending, and says that it is useless to make any proposition of the kind since he has learned from Mr. TYLER that President BUCHANAN refuses to give any parallel assurance. Judge MAGRATH responds, and manages to convey the idea in a great many words, that Gov. PICKENS also thinks it useless to say anything about the matter, and that the best thing Judge ROBERTSON could do under the circumstances, will be for him to return home, carrying with him from the General Assembly of the State "the assurances of their cordial respect and esteem."

abstract: The President elect starts to-day for the National Capital. He enters upon one of the most momentous and difficult duties ever devolved upon any man, in this country or any other. No one of his predecessors was ever called upon to confront dangers half as great, or to render a public service half as difficult, as those which will challenge his attention at the very outset of his Administration.
lead_paragraph: The President elect starts to-day for the National Capital. He enters upon one of the most momentous and difficult duties ever devolved upon any man, in this country or any other. No one of his predecessors was ever called upon to confront dangers half as great, or to render a public service half as difficult, as those which will challenge his attention at the very outset of his Administration. Six States have already repudiated the authority of the Federal Government, -- have organized a separate Confederacy, and stand prepared to resist by force any attempt to maintain the supremacy of the Constitution of the United States. The other Slaveholding States hold a position of quasi neutrality, -- declaring that their adhesion to the Union can be secured only by affording them guarantees against wrongs of which they complain, and dangers which they apprehend. The events of the present month will do much towards deciding the action which these States will finally decide to take: -- but more will depend on the policy which Mr. LINCOLN's Administration may proclaim at the very outset of its career. We cannot believe that Virginia, or any of the other Border States, will permit herself to be dragged into a position of irrevocable hostility to the Union, in advance of the Inaugural Address, in which the new President will declare the basis on which he will discharge the high duties which his office devolves upon him.

abstract: The British brig Elliott, of Arbroath, Capt. FARHAR, hence for Bristol on the 7th inst., returned on Saturday, in consequence of having lost three men by cold and exposure. Capt. FARHAR makes the following report: "Sailed from Quarantine on the 7th, at 10 A.M. At 3 P.M. we hove to on the bar, for the station-boat. It was blowing a hurricane at the time, and intensely cold.
lead_paragraph: The British brig Elliott, of Arbroath, Capt. FARHAR, hence for Bristol on the 7th inst., returned on Saturday, in consequence of having lost three men by cold and exposure. Capt. FARHAR makes the following report: "Sailed from Quarantine on the 7th, at 10 A.M. At 3 P.M. we hove to on the bar, for the station-boat. It was blowing a hurricane at the time, and intensely cold. We have to under double-reefed fore and maintopsails. At 7 P.M., A. MADZEGH, seaman, of Holland, while reefing the foretopsail, fell overboard and was drowned. At 9 P.M., ROBERT ELLIOTT, seaman, of Newburyport, died from cold and exposure. His body was thrown overboard. On the 8th inst., at 10 A.M., JAMES REED, seaman, of England, aged 40 years, died from cold and exposure, and his body was thrown overboard. The Captain and the remainder of the crew are slightly frostbitten. The Highlands were in sight during the whole time. We had Mr. A. PHILLIPS, pilot of boat James Avery, No. 9, on board from the time of leaving the port. The only damage the vessel has received is the loss of jib and foretopsail." He returned for a new crew, and is now anchored at Quarantine.

abstract: -- The New-York correspondent of the Philadelphia Press denies the stories that Ex-Postmaster Fowler is in destitute circumstances. Friends of Mr. Fowler, who are in constant communication with him, state that he is in receipt of a handsome salary as agent of a large company near Mexico, and that independently of that he has a respectable sum on hand in cash -- sufficient, at all events, to maintain himself in entire comfort for a twelvemonth, at least, and that in case he should need more, it would be promptly and cheerfully sent to him. The parties by whom he is employed are greatly pleased with his management thus far, and he has their entire confidence. He writes home in good spirits, and is far from abandoning the hope of returning to New-York, and discharging every obligation against him.

abstract: Recruiting for the army, not withstanding the large number out of employment, has almost come to a stand-still in this City. The weekly report of all the rendezvous, handed in yesterday, records a very marked falling off in the number of accepted recruits. The proportion of physically disqualified applicants seems to be on the increase, as one rendezvous has been obliged to reject over fifty, while retaining only eleven.

abstract: Mr. BOYCE, his wife and two children, whose case was referred to on Friday last, still remain at No. 29 Greenwich-street, both the parents being too ill to be moved, and the wife probably past recovery from inflammation of the lungs. They were ruthlessly driven from a comfortable home on the Santee River, S.C., without any opportunity to arrange their business, or to provide the smallest comforts for their sudden journey. Though a native of New-York State, Mr. BOYCE has been over twenty years a resident of Georgia and South Carolina, but because he would not agree to "secede with them," he was ordered away without mercy. The family has been called upon by a fewhumane persons, who have afforded them some temporary relief, but their condition is still very pitiable indeed. A temporary home for the little children, until the health of the parents would allow of their resuming the care of them, would be a great relief.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BOYCE, his wife and two children, whose case was referred to on Friday last, still remain at No. 29 Greenwich-street, both the parents being too ill to be moved, and the wife probably past recovery from inflammation of the lungs. abstract: The writ of replevin issued by the Superior Court, on application of W.H.D. CALLENDER, Cashier of the State Bank of Commerce, of Hartford, Conn., and directed to J.D. KENNEDY, Superintendent of Metropolitan Police, for the recovery of the muskets seized by the latter, sets forth that there were twenty-eight cases, marked diamond, L., to be shipped by the steamer Monticello, for Montgomery, Ala., care of he Central Railroad, Augusta, Ga.; that they contained 560 Minie rifles, for which, on the 22d of January, bills of lading were duly signed by the agents of the above-named steamers; that they were wrongfully detained from the plaintiff, &c., having been seized by defendant, while in possession of the parties with whom plaintiff had placed them, on the ground that they were contraband of war. The value of the arms is stated to be $8,500.

lead_paragraph: Louise Zimmer vs. William Parker. -- This action was brought to recover $10,000 damages, for an alleged seduction and breach of promise to marry. The action was tried in December, 1860, before Mr. Justice WOODRUFF and a jury, and the plaintiff was awarded damages to the amount of $1,101 94. An appeal is now taken to this term of the Court, and a new trial asked, on the ground that the verdict was rendered against the weight of evidence. The following are a few of the facts of the case, as they were elicited upon the trial. The plaintiff being placed upon the stand as a witness in her own behalf, testified that she went into the house of defendant as a hired help, for general housework; that the defendant lived in Greenwich-avenue, between Twelfth- and Thirteenth streets, in this City; that when the plaintiff first came to the house of the defendant, defendant told her he would like her, and that he would like to marry a German woman, and asked the plaintiff if she would marry him; plaintiff testifies that at first she told him nothing, believing him to be only in fun; plaintiff then told him after his constant importunities that he ought not to fool her, that she was a poor woman and he a wealthy man; to which he answered that was no matter, that he did not go in for richness and poorness, and then told her that he would rather have a poor woman who could work than a rich woman who had a great deal of property, telling her that he did not wish to be bossed by any woman. She further testified that she thought a great deal of the man and saw that he liked her. It appears that they mutually promised to marry each other. Sometime after this the defendant was taken sick. Plaintiff then testifies that shortly after this she felt that she was in a delicate condition, and told him about it, to which he replied that he did not believe it. Upon assuring him that such was the case, he told her that if such was the case he would give her his nephew for a husband, and set him up in business. This offer she refused.

abstract: In navigation of all kinds, marine and political, beacons are quite as important as guides. It is quite as necessary to be warned against concealed perils as to be guided into safe channels.
lead_paragraph: In navigation of all kinds, -- marine and political, -- beacons are quite as important as guides. It is quite as necessary to be warned against concealed perils as to be guided into safe channels. In the present disturbed and menacing condition of public affairs, it is well for all who are loyal to the Constitution and who desire to preserve the Union, to take note of every incident and every indication which may throw light upon the real character of the events of the day, and the real motives of the actors in them. It will not do to act upon impulse, or to regard the most noisy and clamorous demonstrations as the most reliable evidences of genuine public sentiment.

abstract: The circumstances attending the suicide of Mr. Otis T. Peters, a native of Connecticut, 52 years of age, at Mrs. Schoonmaker's boarding-house, No. 26 Fourth-avenue, on Sunday morning last, were made the subject of inquiry, yesterday, by Coroner JACKMAN. It appeared from the testimony of Officer Little, of the Fifteenth Ward, who resides in the house where the occurrence happened, that on Sunday morning, when he went home to breakfast, about 6 1/2 o'clock, Mrs. Schoonmaker called him to the bedroom of the deceased, whom he found with a razor in his hand. Witness called for assistance, and two of the gentlemen boarding in the house came up. After much trouble, they succeeded in taking the razor from deceased, but in a short time he procured another razor, and the fact having come to Mrs. Schoonmaker's knowledge, she again called upon witness to go to him. Witness and some of the other boarders watched deceased for over an hour, and told him if he attempted to cut his throat they would knock him down. Regardless of the threat, however, he raised his right arm to draw the razor across his throat, but was prevented by witness, who struck him with a club, disabling his right arm. In an instant he changed the instrument to his left hand, and drew it across his throat, inflicting a wound from which he did not survive more than a couple of minutes. This testimony was corroborated by other witnesses, and the case having been submitted to the jury, a verdict of suicide while temporarily deranged was rendered. It is said that reverses in business prompted the deceased to take his life.

abstract: Not the least among the many woes which at present invest our common country, we may rank the remarkable and lamentable increase of execrable verse.
lead_paragraph: Not the least among the many woes which at present invest our common country, we may rank the remarkable and lamentable increase of execrable verse. The welling of the waters of disunion seems to have had with us an effect somewhat similar to that produced in Egypt by an overflow of the Nile. Poets have sprung up here in quite as marvelous a manner as frogs do there, and croaking is heard from a multitude' of throats before silent. Any attempt to count the crop would necessarily prove eminently futile. If any mathematician wishes to approximate to a correct census, let him multiply the number of poets before in existence by the square of secession, -- unless we are greatly mistaken the result will be infinity.

abstract: COTTON NOT KING, EVEN IN MANCHESTER. -- From the London Economist, which, more directly than any other journal, represents the views and opinions of the manufacturers, merchants and men of capital in Great Britain, we copy, in another column, an article in reference to the "infatuated folly" of the views entertained by the Southern fire-eaters of the policy and wishes of the British Government and people. It is a strong, calm and dignified assertion of English convictions as opposed to Southern hopes; a straightforward and powerful warning to those gentlemen of the Cotton States who believe in the universal sway of their special commodity, as to the delusion under which they are laboring. We recommend the attentive perusal of this article to the members of the Montgomery Convention before they decide on going to the useless expense of accrediting an Embassador to the Court of St. James! Let them be careful how they expose their diplomatic representative to the "scorn and indignation" which would await him, even in the mills of Manchester and the streets of those villages and towns where spinning-jennies are most in use.

abstract: The whaling bark -Massachusetts arrived at Rio Janeiro Dec. 14, in charge of the First Mate, who stated that the Captain left the bark with three boats and their crews (18 persons) on the 6th Dec., in chase of large sperm whale. Night coming on and a heavy gale at the time, lost sight of the boats, and lay the bark to daring the night, put the boats did not return to the vessel; then cruised several days in search of them and not falling in with them concluded they wee all lost. We then put into Rio Janeiro, but upon the same evening of the day the M arrived, news arrived from Santo that the Captain, with his boats and crews all arrived safe at that port on the 10th inst. after being five days in the boats, without any provisions.

abstract: Julius Carmoza, an Italian peddler, residing at No. 85 Suffolk-street, ventured yesterday in search of customers among the people of the Five Points. While coming out of the hallway of a house at Cow Bay he was met by Theresa Townsend, a notoriously bad character, who threw a sack over his head and shoulders, and held him fast until two male confederates rifled his pockets and despoiled his pack, taking away about $160 worth of property. In his efforts to free himself from the robbers Carmoza was severely cut in the hand. As quickly as he was released he made his loss known to Officer Gilmartin, of the Sixth Ward, who arrested the woman, and a man named Michael Cronin, both of whom were identified by the peddler, who charged the latter with having used the knife upon him. The prisoners were held for trial by Justice KELLY, each in default of $2,000 bail. None of the property was recovered. It is believed that the other highwayman will be arrested to day.

abstract: Mr. LINCOLN, the President elect, left Springfield, en route for Washington, yesterday morning. He was accompanied to the depot by a large concourse of his fellow-townsmen, to whom he made a brief parting address, expressing his regrets at leaving them, alluding to the difficult and responsible duties upon which he was about to enter, and declaring his reliance upon Divine Providence for aid and assistance.
lead_paragraph: Mr. LINCOLN, the President elect, left Springfield, en route for Washington, yesterday morning. He was accompanied to the depot by a large concourse of his fellow-townsmen, to whom he made a brief parting address, expressing his regrets at leaving them, alluding to the difficult and responsible duties upon which he was about to enter, and declaring his reliance upon Divine Providence for aid and assistance. Mr. LINCOLN reached Indianapolis last evening, where he was received by an immense crowd of citizens, and made a few remarks in response to repeated calls, in which he for the first time since his election adverted to the troubles now agitating the country.

abstract: TENNESSEE has just proclaimed her loyalty to the Union and the Constitution. She adds her voice to that of Virginia, in declaring her desire to preserve in all its vigor the form of government which our fathers created, and to have no part in the plots and revolutions by which selfish and unprincipled conspirators are seeking its destruction.
lead_paragraph: TENNESSEE has just proclaimed her loyalty to the Union and the Constitution. She adds her voice to that of Virginia, in declaring her desire to preserve in all its vigor the form of government which our fathers created, and to have no part in the plots and revolutions by which selfish and unprincipled conspirators are seeking its destruction. The elections which have just taken place in these States arc among the most important which have ever occurred in this country, -- and the results are such as must carry the most profound satisfaction to the heart of every American patriot. It may serve the purpose of extremists to misrepresent their character and underrate their significance; and it is doubtless true that both these States have voted for the Union with the expectation of additional guarantees for their institutions and their rights.

abstract: PRODUCTION OF VERDI'S NEW OPERA Whether the "Masked Ball," produced at our Academy, last evening, be the last, as it is the latest, work of VEEDI'S genius, there can hardly be a doubt that the composer's reputation, which already overshadows that...
lead_paragraph: PRODUCTION OF VERDI's NEW OPERA. -- Whether the "Masked Ball," produced at our Academy, last evening, be the last, as it is the latest, work of VEEDI'S genius, there can hardly be a doubt that the composer's reputation, which already overshadows that of every other contemporary, will be permanently benefited by its production. We state this at the outset, because for the last twenty years, during which period VERDI has written twenty-one important works, and supplied the Italian stage of two worlds with almost all its new music, it has been customary to say after the production of a novelty, that Signor VERDI has not added to his reputation by the same, and because moreover it is stated that that truly illustrious and remarkable composer has expressed an intention of not resuming the pen. He has abandoned the lyre for the sabre, and at this moment is probably in the ranks of GARIBALDI. The last works of great composers are usually their best, and although exception may be taken to certain numbers in the "Masquerade Ball," we are disposed to regard it as a success, even if it should -- as we trust may not be the case -- close the career of one of the most remarkable musical geniuses the world has ever seen.

abstract: -- A cattle drover, while passing through Buffalo a few days since, dropped a pocket-book, containing nearly $2,000, in the refreshment saloon of the Lake Shore Railroad depot. An honest man, by the name of Joseph True, picked it up, inferred that its owner must have left the city by the Lake Shore Railroad, telegraphed to the conductor of the train, and in a couple of hours afterwards was overwhelmed with the thanks of the happy drover, who returned by the first train to claim his property.
lead_paragraph: -- A cattle drover, while passing through Buffalo a few days since, dropped a pocket-book, containing nearly $2,000, in the refreshment saloon of the Lake Shore Railroad depot. abstract: We lay before our readers this morning an interesting and instructive budget of news from Japan. Our special correspondents in that quarter of the world have given us, not only very picturesque and striking descriptions of the natural scenery, style of living and general appearance of things in that remote region of the earth, but some very pertinent items of information as to the effect produced upon the Government and people of the Japanese Empire, by that extraordinary Embassy which has just returned from our shores. We have full details of the reception of the Japanese Ambassadors on their arrival, -- the disposition made of the tons of valuable presents which they bore away from our shores, -- and the use which they are likely to make of our gifts and our civility.
lead_paragraph: We lay before our readers this morning an interesting and instructive budget of news from Japan. abstract: Messrs. Heule Brothers, jewelers, having an office at No. 26 Maiden lane, corner of Nassau-street, on the third story of the premises, very nearly lost about $40,000 worth of property on Monday night through the operations of a couple of adroit burglars, whose arrest was effected just at the point when their plans for possessing the plunder approached fruition. The circumstances of the case are as follows: Shortly before 11 o'clock on Monday night a private watchman named Cavannah noticed that the window shades in Messrs. Heule Brothers' office were not lowered as usual, and deeming the fact strange, he called Officers Troy and McDonough, of the Second Precinct, and told them of it. A key to the outer door of the building was procured, and on going up stairs the door of the jewelers' office was found to be firmly barred on the inside. This fact confirmed the officers suspicions that burglars were within, and Cavannah went to inform the proprietor of the place, leaving Troy to guard the office door, and McDonough to act as sentinel at the street door. The Policemen had scarcely taken their stations when the burglars, becoming alarmed, and having no other means of exit, removed the barricades, and made a rush for the street. Troy managed to secure one of them, who gave the name of Charles Crooks; and Officer McDonough having heard the scuffle up stairs, at first held the street door firmly closed, but presently he opened it and arrested the other burglar named George Turner, who was making a desperate effort to get out. The prisoners, both of whom are respectable in appearance and unknown to the Police, were conducted to the Station house and searched. On Crooks were found a gold watch and chain, over a hundred dollars in gold coin, and a loaded Colt's revolver. His companion carried various skeleton keys, one of which unscrewed at the top, thus admitting the attachment of any kind of ward, a key fitting the street door, and two of Adams' five-barrel revolvers. On the floor of Messrs. Henle Brothers' office the policemen found an assortment of burglars' tools, consisting of an iron drill with two bits, one for iron and the other for wood; a double master-key, a bit-handle shaped like an auger-handle, a screwdriver and nippe to extract screws, a jimmy and two packages of powder, a coil of fuse, a blow-pipe to blow the powder into the safe, a file, and a "jimmy," which was bent. The prisoners were yesterday taken before Justice KELLY, at the Tombs, and examined upon the charge. They are both Englishmen, unmarried, and each is about 23 years of age. They stated that they had entered the office about 6 o'clock in the evening, by the aid of a skeleton key, and commenced operations upon the safe containing the diamonds, which is of Herring's make, about 4 feet square. The safe stood in a closet, upon a platform, a foot and a halt in height, and to work at it conveniently it was necessary to remove it away from the wall. This awkward job was accomplished by the burglars, who made an inclined plane of some pasteboards which they found in the room above the office, and when interrupted they were engaged in removing the screws from the back part of the safe. There is no doubt that the prisoners, from their perfect equipment in burglars' tools, and their ingenious manner of working, are experienced rogues, probably recently arrived from England. Justice KELLY committed each of them for trial, in default of $2,000 each.

abstract: At the regular meeting of the Board of Supervisors, yesterday, the weekly report of the Comptroller--showing a balance of County funds on hand amounting to $855,378--was ordered on file. The Comptroller also sent in a communication in response to a resolution of the Board, giving a list of employes in the office of Commissioners of Taxes, numbering thirty-two persons, who receive salaries amounting in all to $47,278.

abstract: The report of the Special Committee appointed by the House of Representatives to investigate the fraudulent abstraction of Bonds belonging to the Indian Trust Fund from the Department of the Interior, is a document to which, more perhaps than to any other, the future philosophical historian will refer when seeking to explain the hidden origin of our existing national difficulties.
lead_paragraph: The report of the Special Committee appointed by the House of Representatives to investigate the fraudulent abstraction of Bonds belonging to the Indian Trust Fund from the Department of the Interior, is a document to which, more perhaps than to any other, the future philosophical historian will refer when seeking to explain the hidden origin of our existing national difficulties. With an Administration so imbecile and blindly confident in its Chief Magistrate, so utterly corrupt and reckless in one of its most important subordinates, -- there can be but little wonder that all public virtue fell to the point of paralysis in the National Government, and that schemes of treason throve and flourished to a luxuriant but premature blossom, on the rank soil and beneath the torrid atmosphere of organized official delinquency.

abstract: The Select Committee appointed on the 24th of December, to investigate the fraudulent abstraction of Indian Bonds in the Department of the Interior, have submitted their report. They state that it became apparent, very soon after the commencement of the inquiry, that the abstraction of the bonds was only an incident in a series of transactions of much greater importance, and they have accordingly pushed the investigation to the furthest limit of the authority vested in them. The Government still holds State Bonds and United States Stocks for certain Indian tribes, to the amount of $2,525,241. These bonds, as well as the 870 abstracted, were purchased from time to time, by authority of law, with the money of the Indians, arising from treaty stipulations. Originally they were in charge of the Indian Bureau, while that Bureau was connected with the Department of War, and remained in its custody after it became one of the Bureaus of the Interior Department in 1849, and from that time up to 1857. In that year the custody of the securities was transferred to the Secretary of the Interior. The Government having the Bonds in its possession, was the trustee for the Indians, who were the actual owners of them.
lead_paragraph: The Select Committee appointed on the 24th of December, to investigate the fraudulent abstraction of Indian Bonds in the Department of the Interior, have submitted their report. abstract: The President elect left Indianapolis, yesterday forenoon, at the appointed time, and arrived at Cincinnati last evening. At every station along the route immense throngs of people were collected, who welcomed him in the most enthusiastic manner.
lead_paragraph: The President elect left Indianapolis, yesterday forenoon, at the appointed time, and arrived at Cincinnati last evening. At every station along the route immense throngs of people were collected, who welcomed him in the most enthusiastic manner. At Cincinnati, where the reception was almost unparalleled in enthusiasm, Mr. LINCOLN made another important speech, which was partly aimed at the Kentuckians. It will be found in full in our telegraphic report.

abstract: LEONARD, J. Waring vs. Ayres The appellant must comply with the terms required on an appeal to the Court of Appeals, in order to stay proceeding.
lead_paragraph: LEONARD, J. -- Waring vs. Ayres -- The appellant must comply with the terms required on an appeal to the Court of Appeals, in order to stay proceeding. An appeal is therefore not effectual, unless an undertaking be filed under section 344. He may have an order staying proceedings on the execution when he executes and files an approved undertaking in conformity with sections 334 and 335.

abstract: To-day the electoral votes for President of the United States are to be counted in Congress, and Vice-President BRECKINRIDGE, as the presiding Officer of the two Houses in joint session, is to declare who is to fill that high office for the next four years.
lead_paragraph: To-day the electoral votes for President of the United States are to be counted in Congress, and Vice-President BRECKINRIDGE, as the presiding Officer of the two Houses in joint session, is to declare who is to fill that high office for the next four years. At the outset of the secession movement it was confidently predicted on the one hand, and widely feared on the other, that a revolutionary attempt would be made to prevent the performance of this duty, and thus to keep the Executive department of the Government from falling into the hands of the Republican Party. All these apprehensions have disappeared. No one now doubts that this duty will be performed, -- that Mr. LINCOLN will be duly proclaimed the President elect, -- that he will be inaugurated on the 4th of March, and will enter forthwith upon the discharge of the functions of his office. The clouds that lowered so heavily upon our political horizon have, to this extent, been dispersed, -- partly without doubt by the preparations made under the direction of Gen. SCOTT to meet any such attempted violence, and partly by the salutary change which has come over the public mind in the Southern States.

abstract: Emil Heineman vs. Benjamin Waterbury. This is an appeal taken from a judgment rendered at a Special Term of this Court entered upon the report of a referee.
lead_paragraph: Emil Heineman vs. Benjamin Waterbury. -- This is an appeal taken from a judgment rendered at a Special Term of this Court entered upon the report of a referee. The action was brought by the plaintiff as indorsee against the defendant as maker of a promissory note for $1,864 19, dated March 20, 1857, to the order of and indorsed by Acker & Harris. The defendant by his answer sets up that, the note was given to Acker & Harris as an accommodation note, and that no consideration was received by them for it. Same time after the making of the note, the firm of Acker & Harris failed, making a general assignment for the benefit or creditors. In the meantime Acker & Harris, it appears, had indorsed and transferred the note in question to the plaintiff. The defence, therefore, in substance, is that the plaintiff, in common with other preferred creditors of Acker & Harris, nothing claims against them for a large amount, had made such an agreement with their voluntary assignee, under the said assignment, as discharged the defendant from the payment of the note, he claiming that although he was the maker and prima facie the party primarily liable for its payment, it was in fact an accommodation note lent by him to Acker & Harris, and he therefore stood in the relative position of a surety for them, and that the plaintiff knew this when he received the note.

abstract: FAILED TO UNITE. For several weeks past negotiations have been pending between the Douglas, Breckinridge and Union organizations with a view to form a united front to resist the rising tide of Republicanism in Kings County.
lead_paragraph: FAILED TO UNITE. -- For several weeks past negotiations have been pending between the Douglas, Breckinridge and Union organizations with a view to form a united front to resist the rising tide of Republicanism in Kings County. Committees of Conference were appointed by each organization, and they finally arrived at the conclusion that combination was impossible, and the Committees have so reported to their respective organizations. It is not probable that another attempt will be made until after the Spring Charter election.

abstract: Mr. LINCOLN evidently regards his departure for Washington as a fit occasion for breaking the silence he has hitherto so resolutely maintained on the state of public affairs.
lead_paragraph: Mr. LINCOLN evidently regards his departure for Washington as a fit occasion for breaking the silence he has hitherto so resolutely maintained on the state of public affairs. He is no longer simply a private citizen, but is on his way to the assumption of duties and responsibilities more grave and momentous than have ever before been devolved upon any of his predecessors. In acknowledging the greetings which he receives from his fellow-citizens at the various points of his journey, he accordingly refers to those duties, and to the important questions of practical policy which will engage his earliest official attention. While it would be evidently unfair to regard such casual remarks as indicating, with any great precision, the line of conduct which he will pursue as President, they may very justly be studied as indicating the general spirit and temper with which he will enter upon his official duties.

abstract: We find that we have been doing injustice to Messrs. McSPEDON BAKER, and hasten to make all the amends in our power to those injured innocents.
lead_paragraph: We find that we have been doing injustice to Messrs. MCSPEDON & BAKER, and hasten to make all the amends in our power to those injured innocents. Our reporter wrongfully attributed the amount of $76,000 for "printing and stationery furnished to the Courts and Heads of Departments during the year 1859" as an item in favor of Messrs. MCSPEDON & BAKER; whereas the fact is, that the sum in question is designed to be given to the already somewhat famous firm of E. JONES & COMPANY. Why the Comptroller should have refused to insert this amount in the Tax Levy of the present or past year, we have no means of ascertaining; but, happily for Messrs. JONES & Co., the item has been at last inserted in the Tax Levy, and now only awaits the action of the State Legislature to make it a valid claim.

Officers ARMSTRONG and LINDSEY, who were stationed at Pier No. 12, North River, occupied by H.B. CROMWELL & Co.'s line of steamers, observed cart No. 1,664 drive upon the Pier at 8 o'clock A.M., with a small box marked J.E. ADGER & Co., Charleston, S.C. Believing that the box contained something "contraband," the officers took temporary charge of it, and notified Sergeant GERST of the circumstance.

abstract: The second performance of VERDI'S new opera of "Un Ballo in Maschera" attracted a magnificent house last evening, and gave such abundant satisfaction that there can hardly be a doubt about the future of the work. The melodies throughout are cast in so curiously an original mold that some little familiarity with them is necessary to their full enjoyment. But a first hearing leaves a "kink" in the memory, and excites the desire for more -- a desire which is sure to give success to the opera that creates it.

abstract: An attempt was made last evening to flood the City with a bogus sheet called the Extra Press, announcing an attack upon Fort Sumter, the bombardment of Charleston, and other equally startling intelligence.
lead_paragraph: An attempt was made last evening to flood the City with a bogus sheet called the Extra Press, announcing an attack upon Fort Sumter, the bombardment of Charleston, and other equally startling intelligence. This was a futile effort to repeat the clumsy imposture practised some four weeks ago, but the Police nipped it in the bud by arresting one of the newsboys with an armful of the papers as he was running through the Park. The officers went to No. 23 Ann street, where the sheets were sold, and found about one hundred boys, large and small, ready to buy them. As the policemen entered the place the lights were extinguished, and the enterprising publisher, whose name is known, made good his escape. Word was telegraphed from the Second Ward Station to Headquarters to arrest any boys offering the bogus sheets for sale. Later in the evening, Officer WATERS found about 600 copies of the paper, which he took possession of, and removed to the Station-house.

abstract: George Law et al. vs. The United States.? Mr. O'Conor having occupied the whole of Tuesday with his summing up for the complainants, at the opening of Court yesterday morning requests to charge were handed up to the Judge by the parties.
lead_paragraph: George Law et al. vs. The United States. -- Mr. O'Conor having occupied the whole of Tuesday with his summing up for the complainants, at the opening of Court yesterday morning requests to charge were handed up to the Judge by the parties. The Judge proceeded to charge the jury at some length. After detailing the proceedings of the Government to enforce the collection of the bond, and the staying of those proceedings by order of the Court, which also required the present complainants to give security in the sum of $200,000 to pay any sum which they might finally be called upon for, he said: It was necessary, in order to bring the legal questions before the Court, that these parties, who, in the ordinary course of an action upon the bond, would have been defendants, should be converted into complainants, and bring an action against the United States to restrain them from using this high prerogative power of collecting the bond by warrant. That was done by one in the form of a bill in Chancery, and in the bill the parties set forth that this bond, which was signed by them, was not executed as a completed instrument, but that they had made an agreement with Fowler to become his sureties together with Mr. Charlick, and had never agreed to become such alone, but only on the condition that the other party should execute it with them, and that they never knew or had any reason to suppose that the bond taken by the Government had not been executed according to the condition of that agreement. They also alleged that Fowler had previously been in the receipt of large moneys as Postmaster by the appointment of the President, and that this bond was really a continuation of the preceding bond; that Fowler had failed before the giving of this new bond to account for the moneys received by him, and had become a defaulter to the knowledge of the Post-office Department, while they themselves never knew but that he had performed his duties strictly. They therefore alleged first, that they were not bound in the bond, and would not have been in an action at law upon it; and second, that the Government and its officers had been themselves delinquent in allowing Fowler to become a defaulter, and that they had had no notice of that fact so that they could have indemnified themselves for the liability which they assumed.

abstract: The second anniversary of the Fourth Ward Mission School last evening was the occasion of one of the most interesting exhibitions ever witnessed within the walls of the Cooper Institue.
lead_paragraph: The second anniversary of the Fourth Ward Mission School last evening was the occasion of one of the most interesting exhibitions ever witnessed within the walls of the Cooper Institue. Never before were there so many of the gentler, sex convened in the large hall, and never was the edifice so completely crammel with spectators. The three hundred children belonging to the Mission were seated on the platform, and with their bright faces, clean aprons and bustling activity, contributed to beautify the coup d'ail. So great was the crowd, however, that not even the excellent ventilating apparatus and the diligent attention of the ever-faithful engineer could render the atmosphere tolerable. The audience seemed to swelter throughout the evening.

abstract: The Mohawk river broke up on Tuesday. Early in the day the Schoharie Creek was opened by the warm weather, and the water, laden with immense masses of ice, rushed into the Mohawk, breaking up the ice in that river, and carrying everything before it.
lead_paragraph: The Mohawk river broke up on Tuesday. Early in the day the Schoharie Creek was opened by the warm weather, and the water, laden with immense masses of ice, rushed into the Mohawk, breaking up the ice in that river, and carrying everything before it. Trees, buildings and fences were leveled with the earth and carried down the river. Our reporter learns from passengers just arrived on the Central Railroad, that the ice in many places has piled up on the track, delaying the trains. Some of the cakes are over two feet thick, and weigh several tons. In the river huge fields are being carried down with the stream at the rate of ten miles an hour. At Fonda, the water is within eight feet of the bridge. At ordinary times it is not nearer than twenty feet. At Amsterdam the people are moving out of their houses as rapidly as possible. Such an early breaking up of the river was never known before.

abstract: It is very evident that the tone of the public mind in all sections of the country, and among men of all parties, has greatly changed for the better during the past few weeks.
lead_paragraph: It is very evident that the tone of the public mind in all sections of the country, and among men of all parties, has greatly changed for the better during the past few weeks. The first heat of Secession has passed away, -- and thousands of men in the Southern States, who at the outset were infected with the contagious fever of revolution, are now canvassing the subject in the light of common sense, and with a practical view to their permanent interests. So on the other hand, even the most resolute and decided Republicans at the North, finding that loyalty to the Constitution "still lives" in the Southern States, and that there is a strong, vigorous and resolute Union Party there, have laid aside something of their suspicious jealousy of everything looking like conciliation, and are disposed to meet the Union men of the Border States on any fair and honorable basis of adjustment.

abstract: When the startling tidings came, some three months back, that the Cabinet of Vienna had consented to replace Hungary in the state to which its Revolution of '48 had brought it, there was probably but one feeling among those who knew the real nature of Austrian policy that the metamorphosis of a despot into a constitutional monarch was too unnatural to be either lasting or sincere.
lead_paragraph: When the startling tidings came, some three months back, that the Cabinet of Vienna had consented to replace Hungary in the state to which its Revolution of '48 had brought it, there was probably but one feeling among those who knew the real nature of Austrian policy -- that the metamorphosis of a despot into a constitutional monarch was too unnatural to be either lasting or sincere. But if any illusions were entertained on the score of the conversion of a Hapsburg to liberalism, they are now very rudely dispelled by an Imperial Ordinance recently dispatched to the Hungarian Government at Pesth, in which all the concessions made in October last are annulled, if, indeed, it is admissible to speak of annulling in the case of decrees which the Government had not even begun to carry out. The Hapsburg thus thoroughly justifies the antecedents of his line. In the midst of the most just and salutary reforms ever undertaken by an Austrian Sovereign, the Emperor suddenly stays his hand, goes back on all his promises, and adds insult to the injury he has already heaped on the most loyal, patient and patriotic of peoples.
headline: {'main': 'Hungary.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Hungary.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: Congress, at the very instant the country is threatened with dismemberment, which may involve a recasting of all our foreign and domestic relations, and the adoption of an entirely new chart for the future, presents the singular spectacle of seeking to inaugurate a line of policy which cannot be changed or modified in any of its important features for many years, without most disastrous consequences. It is now proposed to reenact a highly protective tariff, both for revenue and protection. To the adoption at this crisis of such a measure, there are certainly very grave objections.

abstract: Judge McALLISTER had prepared a very lengthy opinion in the case. He read his opinion first. He began with the jurisdiction of the Court in the case.
lead_paragraph: Judge McALLISTER had prepared a very lengthy opinion in the case. He read his opinion first. He began with the jurisdiction of the Court in the case. The attorney for the United States had argued that the Court had no jurisdiction, because the claim was made to a mine, which does not come under the head of real estate; whereas, the act of 1851, providing for the settlement of private lands in California, gave authority to the Courts to confirm only fee-simple titles, Judge MCALLISTER held these doctrines to be unsound. Mines are real estate by the Mexican, English and American law; and the act of 1851 does not refer to fee simple titles alone, but to all land titles. There were few fee-simple titles in California, most of the grants being accompanied by conditions and limitations, (the Fremont grant, for instance, being limited by a prohibition of alienation.) The Court, therefore, has jurisdiction over mining titles, under the act of 1851.

abstract: HON. JOHN ROBERTSON, of Virginia, has made a partial report to Gov. LETCHER of the results of his mission to the Gulf States.
lead_paragraph: HON. JOHN ROBERTSON, of Virginia, has made a partial report to Gov. LETCHER of the results of his mission to the Gulf States. Gov. BROWN, of Georgia, received him cordially, and gave his word that the State would abstain, during the period contemplated, from all acts calculated to produce a collision of aims between Georgia and the Government of the United States. Probably the New-York vessels at Savannah were seized in accordance with this understanding. Gov. MOORE gave Judge ROBERTSON every assurance that Alabama, in her act of secession, and in occupying the forts and arsenals within her limits, intended no hostility to the Federal Government. Her sole object has been to protect her rights, interests and honor, without disturbing (if possible) her peaceful relations with the Federal Government. This, he felt assured, would continue to be the policy of the State, unless the Federal authorities should, by some hostile act or demonstration, make it necessary to adopt a different course for her protection, and the protection of the other States that have seceded, or may secede. Judge ROBERTSON was invited by the Legislature of Alabama to address that body, but declined to do so, assigning as a reason that his official position might give undue importance to his opinions.

abstract: The President elect yesterday left Cincinnati at 9 o'clock, A.M., and arrived at Columbus, the Capital of Ohio, at 2 o'clock, P.M.
lead_paragraph: The President elect yesterday left Cincinnati at 9 o'clock, A.M., and arrived at Columbus, the Capital of Ohio, at 2 o'clock, P.M. As on the previous day, he was met at every station by enthusiastic crowds, who, when the time would permit, insisted upon a sight of him, and a shake of his hand. At Columbus, soon after his arrival, he was escorted to the Capitol building, where the Legislature was in session, and he was welcomed in the Executive room by Gov. DENNISON, and before the Legislature by Lieutenant-Governor KIRK. Mr. LINCOLN made a short address, in which he alluded to the silence which he had maintained up to the present time, and justified himself in the course he had pursued. Mr. LINCOLN subsequently held a levee at the residence of Gov. DENNISON, which was very fully attended.

abstract: This Committee met at No. 615 Broadway last Monday evening, S.B. DUTCHER presiding. The Committee resolved to meet the President elect at the Hudson River Railroad Depot, on Tuesday next, in citizens' dress, wearing appropriate badges, and to accompany him to his hotel. The following gentlemen were selected to proceed to Albany to represent the Wide-Awakes of New-York, and to escort President LINCOLN to the Metropolis: Hon. SILAS B. DUTCHER, Frank W. Shepherd, Secretary; Gen. J.H. Hobart Ward, Grand Marshal; Maj. Robert Irwin, Alex, McLeod, Assistant-Marshal Daniel E. Gavit, Adjutant Wm. M. Gillespie, Capt. C.G. La Fata, of the Italian Wide-Awakes; Capt. Allen Rutherford, and Hon. Lewis Hoops. This special Committee have received an invitation to accompany the Presidential party in the special train, and will leave for Albany on Monday morning.

abstract: MURDEROUS ASSAULT. Last Sunday night, as a man named HENRY GRAY was passing through Bond-street, a gang of rowdies made an unprovoked attack upon him, and, while attempting to defend himself, one of the party stabbed him severely with a knife...
lead_paragraph: MURDEROUS ASSAULT. -- Last Sunday night, as a man named HENRY GRAY was passing through Bond-street, a gang of rowdies made an unprovoked attack upon him, and, while attempting to defend himself, one of the party stabbed him severely with a knife. GRAY's call for assistance attracted the attention of some persons, when the ruffians retreated. Yesterday WILLIAM KELLY was arrested on suspicion of being one of the parties engaged in the assault, and was fully identified by GRAY. KELLY was committed to answer.

abstract: Maria E. Waring vs. Rose M. Lincoln and Carolyn Lincoln. This action was brought against Rose M.Lincoln and her only child, Carolyn, to remove a cloud from the title which the plaintiff claims...
lead_paragraph: Maria E. Waring vs. Rose M. Lincoln and Carolyn Lincoln. -- This action was brought against Rose M.Lincoln and her only child, Carolyn, to remove a cloud from the title which the plaintiff claims to have to several lots of land near the Croton Aqueduct. It seems that the property was conveyed by Wm. Leggett to P.S. Waring, a brother of plaintiff's husband. The plaintiff, her husband, and P.S. Waring lived together, and after purchasing the premises in question, occupied them for two or three years. The plaintiff claims that the premises were conveyed to her, but that the deed was unrecorded at the time of a sale of the property by the Sheriff, under an execution against T.S. Waring, who made the conveyance to her. Lincoln purchased the property and took the Sheriff's deed.

abstract: The Lockport Advertiser says that on Feb. 7, when the mercury was ten degrees below zero, a lady and gentleman came some nine miles to Lockport, in a cutter, for the purpose of being married.
lead_paragraph: -- The Lockport Advertiser says that on Feb. 7, when the mercury was ten degrees below zero, a lady and gentleman came some nine miles to Lockport, in a cutter, for the purpose of being married. When they arrived at the American Hotel, the gentleman's face and ears were frozen, and also the lady's nose. As soon as the marriage ceremony was performed they prepared to leave, and were soon on their way rejoicing.

abstract: The United States revenue cutter Harriet Lane is to be temporarily converted into a man-of war. She went over, yesterday, to the Brooklyn Navy-yard to receive a new and formidable armament.
lead_paragraph: The United States revenue cutter Harriet Lane is to be temporarily converted into a man-of war. She went over, yesterday, to the Brooklyn Navy-yard to receive a new and formidable armament. Four thirty-three hundred weight guns, one 12-pound howitzer, and a quantity of shot and shell will be put on board. It is said that a marine guard is to be detailed for her immediately.

abstract: A FIRST-RATE SUICIDE. A Tours journal states that during the celebration of mass at the Cathedral of this city, on Sunday morning, a welldressed man apparently about 45 years of age, and wearing the decoration of the Legion of Honor, requested of the bell-ringer's wife to be allowed to ascend one of the towers to make some sketches.
lead_paragraph: A FIRST-RATE SUICIDE. -- A Tours journal states that during the celebration of mass at the Cathedral of this city, on Sunday morning, a welldressed man apparently about 45 years of age, and wearing the decoration of the Legion of Honor, requested of the bell-ringer's wife to be allowed to ascend one of the towers to make some sketches. She told him that he could not go up until the service was over. He appeared annoyed, but went out and walked about in front of the Cathedral until mass was concluded. The bell-ringer having then presented himself, the stranger proceeded to ascend with great rapidity the staircase leading to the lower, the bell-ringer accompanying him. On the way he stopped at more than one opening, and appeared to measure with his eye the distance to the ground. On reaching the top, a height of nearly 200 feet, he requested the bell-ringer to leave him alone, saying that he was an artist, and wanted to sketch the views, but the other answered that he had positive orders not to let persons remain by themselves in the tower. The ringer then began describing to him the principal buildings in the city, the summits of which were seen; but the visitor impatiently silenced him, and throwing off his hat and coat took a spring to throw himself over the parapet. The latter however, being of considerable height, he only got astride it. 'Good heavens!' cried the bell-ringer, 'What are you doing!' and catching hold of his arm and leg, tried to pull him down: but the man exclaimed, 'Let me alone?' and by a violent effort freed himself from the ringer's grasp, and threw himself forward, striking as he descended against two or three projections of the building. He was of course killed on the spot, his legs and arms being broken in several places, his breast being smashed in, and his jaw being also broken with such force that some of the teeth were cast out. On the deceased was found a passport in the name Wertheim, native of Austria, but naturalized as a Frenchman, and describing him as examiner of candidates for admission to the Polytechnic School: the passport was vised for Spain, Switzerland, Hamburg, and the Sardinian States. In his pockets besides were 1,300 francs in notes, and some visiting cards bearing the same name, with the address 25, rue Monsieur le Prince, at Paris. There is no doubt that the man was insane."

abstract: John Holliwell, a jolly son of Neptune, who first saw the light in North Carolina, forty years ago, was brought before Justice STEERS, charged with bigamy.
lead_paragraph: John Holliwell, a jolly son of Neptune, who first saw the light in North Carolina, forty years ago, was brought before Justice STEERS, charged with bigamy. From the evidence it appeared that the accused, although compelled to rove in pursuit of a livlihood, is of a domestic turn, and provided himself with a rib and a home in every port at which he tarried. In November last he was married to a fair Irish damsel, named Eliza White, and went to housekeeping with her in this City. Recently she ascertained that there was still living a prior claimant to his name and love, to whom he was united in Bernstaple County, Mass., as long ago as 1840. She, there ore, made a complaint for bigamy against the uxorious seaman, who was arrested by Officer Van Arsdale, of the Third District Police Court. At the time of his apprehension, the accused, who has been mate of a vessel, was conducting a correspondence with another confiding maid, who expected soon to marry him. The prisoner acknowledged his villainy, but excused himself on the ground that he was in his cups when his last matrimonial "splice" was made -- in fact, that he had been "roped" into it. The magistrate said the offence could not be explained away, but the case must go to the Grand Jury. A bondsman in the sum of $1,000 could not be found, and the sorrowing tar was locked up.

abstract: The apparent well-grounded apprehension of the passage of this proposed measure, creates excessive alarm among merchants, and no small regret to the friends of a well-devised and stable policy.
lead_paragraph: The apparent well-grounded apprehension of the passage of this proposed measure, creates excessive alarm among merchants, and no small regret to the friends of a well-devised and stable policy. Its passage would well illustratethe heedless and reckless character of our legislation. Not the least provision is made to meliorate, or prepare the people for its effects. A radical change is instantly to take place in a law, to conform to which years are required to escape excessive loss and sacrifice. Instead of the deliberate action which should characterize a judicial or legislative body, the proposed measure acts with the precipitancy and recklessness of a mob. Such a bill should not take effect for at least two years after its passage, for the reason that the arrangements of merchants and manufacturers extend through periods often of greater length. If a new tariff, as is the present, in many cases, be prohibitory upon articles which have been largely imported and are in common use, nothing can exceed the injustice and hardship of such a measure. Stocks of goods on hand will be advanced to an amount equal the duty, while the Government will not be benefited a penny. Two or three years will in many cases be required before domestic establishments can be in position to supply the market. In the meantime, none will be benefited but the speculators and lucky holders under recent importations.

abstract: The Census Reports furnish the true history of the "irrepressible conflict" between Freedom and Slavery; and the result of the last year's enumeration indicates unmistakably what the issue of the struggle will be.
lead_paragraph: The Census Reports furnish the true history of the "irrepressible conflict" between Freedom and Slavery; and the result of the last year's enumeration indicates unmistakably what the issue of the struggle will be. The friends of Freedom have every reason to rejoice at the evidence it will give of the growing preponderance of Free-labor and Free-State power in the Union, and grounds for as sured confidence, that ten years more of the conflict between the social and industrial forces of the two systems, will reduce the population of the Slave States to little more than one-third of the whole, even supposing them to maintain their present foothold; and if some two or three of the Border States should in the meantime be transferred from the weaker to the stronger side, by emancipation, the result will be that "the South" will be dwarfed, numerically, to proportions utterly inconsistent with the high pretensions she has heretofore set up.

abstract: A new piece, in five acts, called "Central Park, or the House with two Doors," was produced here last evening, with very marked success.
lead_paragraph: A new piece, in five acts, called "Central Park, or the House with two Doors," was produced here last evening, with very marked success. It is, as its name implies, of purely local origin, and one of those pleasant embroideries which Paris supplies to ad its town topics, but which, here, are almost unknown. Our authors are too apt to "make an effort," and in doing so, frequently overlook the interests -- often dramatic -- which lay absolutely before them. Mr. LESTER WALLACK, who is, we understand, the author of the present work, has seized on the one topic which for the last two months has more than any other occupied the attention of the amusement-going public. The Central Park, we have heard it asserted, injures the theatres, because people go there in the evening, when the moon shines, and the keen air invites to open-air recreation. There is unquestionably some truth in this assertion. People do go to Central Park, and for this very reason the discreet dramatist finds the occasion to utter his say on the subject. Thus Mr. L.WALLACK, who, on ordinary occasions. Is an eclectician, culling from the French and the English stage a sprig of the laurels which he so worthily wears, becomes for the moment a contemporanian, and discourses of the things of newspaper freshness. And in doing this successfully he has adopted a purely domestic vein, and gives us for his plot a matrimonial complication about a portrait, which falls accidentally into the hands of a jealous hero, and, exciting that individual's suspicious, leads to a series of blunders, having no harm in them, and possessing the merit of being perfectly understood by the audience from beginning to end, -- leading gradually to a series of extremely ingenious situations, and terminating, as all domestic quarrels should terminate, with reconciliation. We shall not attempt to follow more closely the plot of the piece. It does not indeed admit of analysis, being, as the French would say, the suggestion of circumstances, and therefore superior to the rules of ordinary criticism. As such we regard it, simply adding that the construction, although occasionally more obscure than is necessary, is frequently admirable. The little intrigues for "finding out something," with which the piece abounds, are excellently conducted, and without anticipating the last act, lead to it pleasantly, and make one glad when the marital cloud has disappeared. The dialogue possesses the great merits of being both unconventional and unlabored; the responses are quick and natural, without being blurred by vain yearnings after brilliancy and wit. Jealousy, in its trivial form, is all that the author has tried to portray, and he has done it with situations rather than talk. Herein consists the merit of the piece, which is neither wordy nor long, but contains many aspects of life, as we have it here presented, in an agreeable and thoroughly amusing shape. The last scene on the "Big Pond," in Central Park, is very ingeniously contrived, not only as a pictorial representation, but as a denouement.

abstract: The Richmond Whig claims that in the election for delegates to the State Convention an issue was joined between the Legislature and the Senators and Congressmen. The Congressional manifesto could be regarded in no other light, than as an appeal from the Legislature to the people themselves. That appeal was fairly tried on the 4th inst., at the polls, and the Legislature has the satisfaction to know that its judgment has been affirmed, with costs and damages, against the appellants! Execution on this judgment, says the Whig, may be delayed for a time, but it is inevitable. At as early a day as the Constitution and laws will allow, retribution, swift and sure, will overtake the faithless dynasty which now abuses the confidence of Virginia. All existing organizations, it says, have been demolished by the new issue which has been raised, and hereafter the division line will be between Unionists and Disunionists. This distinction it intimates, must be recognized by Republicans throughout the North also. Messrs. LINCOLN and SEWARD will see the necessity of this, and giving the cold shoulder to the extreme men of their party, will cut loose from the absurdities of the Abolition school and establish a new organization which must be called the Union Party. The Whig urges that the Convention should adopt as its motto, "To ask for nothing but what is right, and to submit to nothing that is wrong."

abstract: Information reaches us from Washington daily that the Bankers of this City have absolutely declined...
lead_paragraph: Information reaches us from Washington daily that the Bankers of this City have absolutely declined to accommodate Government with a loan, without some governmental pledges that the outstanding difficulty between the Northern and Southern States shall also be accommodated. This resolution, we are assured, is not to be shaken. The vaults of these obdurate gentlemen shall shed not a single coin until Government, in the plenitude of its penitence, shall hold out the olive branch to its rebellious subjects, and give peace to the people.

abstract: The task of precipitating the Border States into revolution has been intrusted to less crafty plotters...
lead_paragraph: -- The task of precipitating the Border States into revolution has been intrusted to less crafty plotters than those who have done that service for the Cotton Confederacy. For several weeks past, ever since, indeed, the era of disunion, which currently dates with the November election, the majority of the Virginia delegation at Washington have been pledging their State to follow the lead of South Carolina. For Virginia, these imperative gentlemen have urged the same excessive claims as had previously and vainly been put forth by the Gulf States, and have alarmed the country with assertions that the Old Dominion was sure to prefer an alliance with a new to one with the old Republic. To these menaces was added a declared preparation for the seizure of the National Capital, -- so open, in fact, as to challenge the attention of the Administration in time to prompt those defensive measures, without which there is reason to believe the scenes of Wednesday in the Capitol would not have been acted in peace. In debate and conversation have these persons used none but the most ultra language upon the pending issue; language borrowed from the vocabulary of RHETT, YANCEY and SLIDELL; and had the views of their constituents answered to their own, there is every ground to believe that Virginia, in her recent election would have voted herself out of the Union.

abstract: Mr. LINCOLN left Columbus, yesterday, at the appointed time, and after considerable detention at one part of the road by some obstruction, arrived at Pittsburgh last night in a pelting rain.
lead_paragraph: Mr. LINCOLN left Columbus, yesterday, at the appointed time, and after considerable detention at one part of the road by some obstruction, arrived at Pittsburgh last night in a pelting rain. He stopped for a short time at Steubenville, Ohio, and made a short address to the assembled thousands, and also made a short speech on his arrival at Pittsburgh, in which he promised to make a longer one this morning. His reception there was very enthusiastic, notwithstanding the storm.

abstract: THE SEVENTH REGIMENT GYMNASIUM Corporal ABNER S. BRADY'S Zouave Manufactory, No. 20 St. Mark's-place, (Eighth-street,) where the soldiers of the...
lead_paragraph: THE SEVENTH REGIMENT GYMNASIUM Corporal ABNER S. BRADY'S Zouave Manufactory, No. 20 St. Mark's-place, (Eighth-street,) where the soldiers of the Seventh Regiment are exercised far beyond drilling, and where all civilians who see fit to join are greatly strengthened for the battle of life, was melodious with music last evening, resonant with plaudits, and thronged to overflowing with ladies and gentlemen, who assembled there to listen to a concert by GRAFULLA's Seventh Regiment Band, to witness the gyrations of the gymnasts, and to inspect the expensive appointments of the institution. The labial performances with the wind-instruments were exceedingly well executed, and when they were over the manual exercises of the suing band commenced, with human cords and muscles stretched on parallel bars and spring boards, with dumb-bell accompaniments, and with aerial flights, and rising and falling on ladders, and in ground and lofty tumbling. Most notable among those who took part in them, were Mr. BRADY himself, WHO, among other wonders, grasping a ring suspended from the ceiling, with his left hand only, six times lifted himself till his shoulder was parallel with it; and Messrs. W.T.C. GROWER, the instructor of the Gymnasium, Van Vleck, O'Neill, Smith, Burnham, Weed, Conner, Jennings, Poore, Lawrence, King, Bird, Corey, Doughty, Quinn and many others. During the evening S. WALLACE CONE, Esq., delivered an address. The [???] and concert will be repeated, with a new programme to-morrow evening.

abstract: A British ship which, two months ago, was chartered in London to come to New-York, discharge here, and then proceed to Charleston to load with cotton for Liverpool, has had her destination changed; the Captain, on account of the obstruction of that harbor, the removal of buoys and coast lights, together with the unsettled state of the country, having determined to abandon the voyage, enter a protest, and recharter his ship to load grain for London.

abstract: Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest on Thursday afternoon, at the house Mr. D.W. BURNEIT, in One Hundred and Twenty-seventh street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues, Harlem, upon the body of HENRY M. TONER, a boy 13 years of age, whose death resulted from intermittent fever, consequent upon an accidental in jury to his eyelid received on the 22d of last December. On the day in question the deceased was playing with his companions around the barn. In running round the corner of the building he came in contact with a pitchfork which a man was using to load a cart with manure. The only apparent injury was a scratch upon the eyelid, but the lad at discovering the blood became very nervous, and having been taken home, sank into issensibility. He continued unconscious about a week, only speaking when aroused. Afterwards he recovered sufficiently to go about the house, but remained feeble, and intermittent fever setting in, he died. Deceased was of a very nervous organization, and had fainted at the sight of blood, when his cousin accidentally cut his finger. There is no doubt that his fatal illness resulted from fright at the slight injury he suffered.
