abstract: The Joint Committee of the Common Council on the reception of the President elect held another meeting yesterday, and adopted the following as the programme of the reception on the arrival of Mr. LINCOLN in this City. The President elect is to be received at the new depot of the Hudson River Railroad in Thirtieth street, whence he is to be escorted up Thirtieth street to Ninth-avenue, down Ninth-avenue to Twenty-third-street, up Twenty-third-street to Broadway, and down Broadway to his quarters, which are not yet decided upon, but will be either at the St. Nicholas Hotel or at the Astor House.
lead_paragraph: The Joint Committee of the Common Council on the reception of the President elect held another meeting yesterday, and adopted the following as the programme of the reception on the arrival of Mr. LINCOLN in this City. abstract: The Light Guard Ball long ago became one of the institutions of the City. Its title to be so regarded was fully vindicated at the Academy of Music, last evening.
lead_paragraph: The Light Guard Ball long ago became one of the institutions of the City. Its title to be so regarded was fully vindicated at the Academy of Music, last evening. It was the sixth reunion of "the elite corps," and its numberless friends, that has taken place there. The decorations were magnificent. Behind the dancing floor, constructed over the backs of the parquette seats, on an elevated plat form, was a statue of the Goddess of Liberty, with armorial surroundings, pyramids of cannon shot, howitzers of small calibre, muskets, the bearskin caps and knapsacks of the Guard, and the symbolical Tiger, and over all, in a blaze of gas jets, shone forth the words, "The Light Guard -- 1827." The house was [???] but tastefully decorated with flags, of all nations, and uncounted Canary-bird cages were hung around the huge apartment, and their many occupants responder cheerily to the music of DODWORTH's two monster bands. At 9 1/8 o'clock the dancing began; but when it ended, we are unable to say. When we went to press, the revelry was at its height. The throne was, in popular phraseology, immense. Those who honor no other public ball with their presence, make it a point to go to that of this favorite command. Most of the officers and a great many of the men of the First Division, were there in full uniform, and their brilliant costumes and the floating wonders of the ladies' toilettes were notably noteworthy. And so till dusky night was enlightened by the missionary morn, the ball for the ball was up. It was a very delightful occasion, and, so far as we learned, nothing occurred to mar it.

abstract: The New-York Belting and Packing Company vs. The Metropolitan Insurance Company. -- This case, which has been on trial for the last three days, and was reported in the TIMES of Feb. 13, resulted yesterday morning in a verdict for the plaintiff for the full amount claimed-- $4,209 61. The policy was one of twenty-two others, taken out in most of the Insurance Companies in this City and out of town. The whole amount of the insurance was $65,000; the whole loss was about $100,000. Most of the Companies settled the losses promptly. The Metropolitan Company,however, resisted, and setup as a defence that the risk had been increased since the policy was taken out, and that they had been prevented from can celing their policy by false representations.

abstract: Soon after 1 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the spice mill of SAMUEL WILDE & SON, corner of Ninth and Ainslie-street, and before the fire could be extinguished nearly all of the stock, valued at $3,000, was destroyed. The building was nearly fire-proof, and, excepting the floors and beams, sustained no material damage. The loss is covered by insurance. THIBBETTS, No. 102 South First-street, destroying property valued at $500 before the fire could be extinguished. There was no insurance.

abstract: Dennis McMahon, Jr., Assignee of Charles T. Harrison vs. Thomas E. Allen. This was an appeal from a judgment entered on report of late Hon. Wm. Kent, Sole Referee.
lead_paragraph: Dennis McMahon, Jr., Assignee of Charles T. Harrison vs. Thomas E. Allen. -- This was an appeal from a judgment entered on report of late Hon. Wm. Kent, Sole Referee. In the year 1848, Ruth S. Harrison died in this City, possessed of certain real and personal property, which she devised to her children and appointed her husband, John Harrison, sole executor. She left, among other things, her personal property, beyond what was sufficient to pay her debts, to her daughter Lucy Ann, wife of the plaintiff. She devised her house, No. 694 Houston-street, to her two sons for life. She died intestate as to her house No. 14 Charles-street, which was subsequently sold under foreclosure, leaving a surplus of about $900, the third of which belonged to Charles T. Harrison. The house in Houston-street was worth from $8,000 to $10,000, and was subject to a mortgage of $5,000. The defendant collected the rents and paid interest and made repairs, &c., from the death of Mrs. Harrison until March, 1852 upon authority derived from the executor and the brother of Charles T. Harrison, who was in Europe. At that time Charles returned and sold his interest in the estate to defendant for upwards of $1,000. A few months thereafter he executed a paper purporting to be a general assignment of all property to the plaintiff, and a few weeks afterwards executed another paper purporting to revoke the assignment to the plaintiff.

abstract: RICHARD H. WINSLOW, Esq., late of the firm of WINSLOW, LANIER & Co., Bankers of this City, died at his residence in Westport, Conn., early yesterday morning. Mr. WINSLOW was a native of Hartford, Conn., whence he came to this City more than thirty years ago, and has since been engaged in active business here until his retirement from the firm of which he was senior partner, about eighteen months ago. Since his retirement he has taken an active interest in political affairs, and last year was elected to the Senate of his native State. He was also a candidate for Lieutenant-Governor of Connecticut in 1859. He was a lineal descendant, from Gov. WINSLOW, of Plymouth Colony. His age at the time of his death was about 55.

abstract: A fort night has elapsed since Capt. VAUGHAN, of the British ship Kalos, was lynched at Savannah,...
lead_paragraph: -- A fortnight has elapsed since Capt. VAUGHAN, of the British ship Kalos, was lynched at Savannah, because he chose to eat dinner with a colored stevedore, and yet we do not hear by mail or telegraph that any one of the perpetrators of the outrage has been arrested. It was hardly to be supposed that the mercenary motives offered for the detection of those concerned in the affair could have any influence upon the high-minded members of the Rattlesnake Club, the organization saddled with the responsibility of having applied the tar and feathers to the unfortunate son of Neptune, but the fact that a Grand Jury deemed the matter of sufficient moment to make it the subject of a presentment, and the vigorous denunciations by the local Press of the "outrage," -- that is what lynching is called when tried on an Englishman, -- really induced the hope that we might have a Georgia Court deciding whether rough treatment of individuals suspected of Abolition proclivities were a crime, and if so, what penalty it deserved.

abstract: Margaret G. Baker vs. W.H.B. Totten. -- In this case the defendant procured an attachment against the husband of the plaintiff. The officer to whom the attachment was issued levied upon certain property which the plaintiff claimed as her separate property. It seems, however, that she joined prior to this levv, with her husband in the execution of a mortgage upon this identical property. The Judge dismissed the complaint on the ground that the plaintiff did not connect the defendant with the levy, the Court holding that the remedy if any, should have been against the officer making the levy.

abstract: The comparative indifference with which our public now regards the actual condition and the imminent eventualities of the body politic in Europe, affords a very striking commentary upon the gravity and the growth of our own national troubles.
lead_paragraph: The comparative indifference with which our public now regards the actual condition and the imminent eventualities of the body politic in Europe, affords a very striking commentary upon the gravity and the growth of our own national troubles. If it is always instructive to see ourselves as others see us, there is, also, a serious lesson to be sometimes drawn from our own anxiety or unconcern in regard to the affairs of our neighbors. Twelve months ago the American Press would have bestowed upon the overthrow of the Miramon Government, and the reestablishment of constitutional principles in Mexico, an attention which it now hardly vouchsafes to the commercial agitation of England, threatened in the very vitality of her most-important industrial interest, and to the political perturbations of the whole continental system, perplexed from St. Petersburgh to Palermo with "fear of change." It is well, certainly, that Americans should give their hearts and brains to the national crisis of America; and yet it is far, very far from well that we should so absorb ourselves in the immediate future of our own history as altogether to overlook the possibilities lowering over Europe with the now opening Spring; possibilities of good or of ill, which cannot fail to exert a direct and most important influence upon the course of events upon our own side of the Atlantic.
headline: {'main': 'Europe in 1861.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Europe in 1861.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: GENEOLOGICAL TREE OF THE LUTHER FAMILY. Mr. CHARLES LUTHER, a lineal descendant of the great Reformer, has published a lithograph of the genelogical tree of the Luther family, a copy of which is before us.
lead_paragraph: GENEOLOGICAL TREE OF THE LUTHER FAMILY. -- Mr. CHARLES LUTHER, a lineal descendant of the great Reformer, has published a lithograph of the genelogical tree of the Luther family, a copy of which is before us. The name of LUTHER is a claim upon the sympathies of Christians of all denominations. Mr. LUTHER, with a family dependent on him for support, is incapacitated by serious bodily injuries from manual labor, and has taken this course to obtain a sufficient sum to start him in some business, which will give him a livelihood. The cost of the lithograph is a trifle. It is a valuable memento of a man whose name is linked by a thousand bonds to the cause of Christianity, and its purchase commends itself to those who would do that name honor by a kindness to the survivor bearing it.

abstract: The crowd which assembled in Pittsburgh yesterday morning to see the President elect, and hear the address which he had promised on Thursday evening to deliver, was the most numerous and the most enthusiastic that ever collected in that city.
lead_paragraph: The crowd which assembled in Pittsburgh yesterday morning to see the President elect, and hear the address which he had promised on Thursday evening to deliver, was the most numerous and the most enthusiastic that ever collected in that city. Rain fell in the morning, but the weather became more propitious about eight o'clock, when Mr. LINCOLN was waited upon by the Mayor and Councils, and introduced to the people in a brief address by the former. Mr. LINCOLN, in his speech, alluded to the National crisis as a factitious one -- such a one as could be gotten up at any time by turbulent men, aided by designing politicians -- and advised everybody to keep cool, and everything would be settled satisfactorily. The most important part of the speech, however, was relative to the Tariff question, which more immediately interests the people of Pennsylvania than almost any other. He reiterated the declarations of the Chicago Platform upon the subject, and declared that the policy of his Administration would be in accordance with those declarations. The speech was received by the Pittsburghers with the liveliest demonstrations of satisfaction. At the conclusion of his speech, Mr. LINCOLN proceeded to the special train and started for Cleveland, which place he reached at 4 o'clock P.M.

abstract: The Independance Delge professes to have received confirmation of its statement that a verbal communication had been made by Prince METTERNICH to M. THOUVENEL, in which Austria declared that she should consider as a casus belli with Piedmont an attack by GARIBELDI on any point whatever of the Austrian territory.
lead_paragraph: The Independance Delge professes to have received confirmation of its statement that a verbal communication had been made by Prince METTERNICH to M. THOUVENEL, in which Austria declared that she should consider as a casus belli with Piedmont an attack by GARIBELDI on any point whatever of the Austrian territory. It is added that Austria expressed the wish to respect Lombardy, and that M. THOUVENEL observed that if, in an eventuality such as that which Prince METTERNICH referred to, the Austrian Government employed German federal contingents, France would consider that fact a violation of the principle of non-intervention.

abstract: The present is not a favorable time for collecting debts in Kansas; but it is to be hoped that famine and the evils which attend upon it will not afflict them long. To those who have outstanding claims in that State, the following decision of their Supreme Court, communicated through MCKILLOP & Co., maybe important. That Court have decided, "that all causes of action upon a specialty or any agreement, contract or promise in writing, or upon contract not in writing, express or implied, or action upon a liability created by statute other than a forfeiture or penalty," which accrued prior to the passage of the "code of civil procedure" of the Territory of Kansas, approved Feb. 12, 1858, must be commenced prior to Aug. 1, 1861, otherwise the right of action becomes debarred by statute of limitation.

abstract: The United States vs. Edmund A. Lane. -- The trial in this case, which was for the alleged murder of a seaman on board the bark Anna, terminated yesterday morning in a disagreement of the jury. The case was given to them yesterday afternoon, and after being out over fifteen hours, they came into Court this morning, and stated that there was no prospects of an agreement, and they were accordingly discharged. They stood, as we understand, seven for acquittal and five for a verdict of guilty.

abstract: ARREST OF PASSERS OF COUNTERFEIT MONEY. An attempt was made on Thursday evening, to flood the City with counterfeit $5 bills on the munson Bank, of Munson, Mass.
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF PASSERS OF COUNTERFEIT MONEY. -- An attempt was made on Thursday evening, to flood the City with counterfeit $5 bills on the munson Bank, of Munson, Mass. By a concerted movement of the counterfeiters, these bills were put out in different parts of the City at the same time, but the Police had early notice of what was going on, and succeeded in arresting six of the gang. Sergeant SMITH and Officer WALDRON, of the Fourth Precinct, arrested GEORGE SMITH, CHARLES WARD, and WILLIAM ALLEN; Sergeant MORTON, of the Fifth Precinct, arrested GEORGE H. LOSSES; Sergeant FERRY, of the Third Precinct, arrested WILLIAM SIMMONS; and a man named HENRY FRANCES was arrested in the Sixth Precinct. Yesterday the accused were committed for examination.

abstract: -Treason in South Carolina seems to have reached a tapering point. If the report of Capt. DOUBLEDAY be worthy of credit, certain ladies of Charleston have broken faith with the new Republic by having eminently underhanded dealings with the soldiers of Sumter. That officer states that a bevy of these fair traitors, having relatives in the Fort and learning that the garrison was destitute of candles, made their crinolines serve as Christmas-trees for the nonce, swung each branching hoop with a wealth of candles, and in this wise smuggled boxes of the desired luminaries into the Fort. Now this statement may be true, but we "mainly doubt." We are loth to believe that ladies born under the Palmetto would thus carry aid and comfort "under the rose" to even relative enemies. The act referred to would be "hiding candles under a bushel" with a vengeance. Nor is it easy to admit the implied reflection upon the vigilance of South Carolinian officials. After heading off succor so successfully in other cases, it does not seem likely that they would permit these light supplies to slip past the muzzles of their guns. But if the fact of this reinforcement be true, Capt. DOUBLEDAY has been guilty of an indiscretion, if not a serious crime. He should have kept the secret better. The story of the surreptitious supply should have been told only to the moon; it should not have been unveiled to the light of day, -- much less exposed by DOUBLEDAY.

abstract: Under date of Barclay's Fort, New-Mexico, Jan. 11, S.D. WATROUS writes to the St. Louis Republican a full account of ice recent fight between Col. CRITTENDEN'S Command and a number of Comanches. The former numbering 100 mounted Riflemen, left Fort Union on Dec. 26, and on Jan. 2 came upon a camp of 175 lodges. The women and children at once took refuge in the mountains, while the warriors came forward boldly to meet their assailants. One gallant fellow, supposed to be a chief, rushed madly up nearly to the muzzles of the rifles, waving his shield and encouraging his followers to the charge, while his arrows were sent thick and fast into the ranks of his enemies. He seemed to court death -- and he found it. The rifles of Lieut. JACKSON and two others were leveled, and he fell, pierced by three balls at the same moment Col. CRITTENDEN'S orders were to take deliberate aim and make every shot tell, and so well were they carried out that the Indians were obliged to take refuge in a ridge of rocks near at hand, whence, under shelter, they annoyed the soldiers exceedingly. By deploying the troops as skirmishers, the savages were eventually driven from their hiding places, leaving ten warriors dead on the field, while not a single man of Col. CRITTENDEN'S force lost his life, and but three were wounded. The troops entered the valley at 8 in the morning and left it at 4 in the evening. The number of man engaged in the action was fifty-five, the rest were guarding the horses and packs.

abstract: Mr. JOHN COCHRANE, of New-York, (Dem.,) presented a memorial from the New-York Chamber of Commerce, protesting against the passage of the Morrell tariff bill, and specifying its objectionable features to be the repeal of the Warehousing system, the specific and double or compound duties, and the effect it would have to lessen the revenue by diminishing the exports. Referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.

abstract: A meeting of citizens of Jersey City was held last evening at the room of the Fire Commissioners, for the purpose of appointing a Committee to cooperate with the Common Council Committee for the purpose of making arrangements for the reception of the President elect. His Honor Mayor VAN VORST occupied, the Chair, and H.A. GREENE acted as Secretary. The following named gentlemen were appointed the Committee; Mayor Van Vorst, S.M. Hopkins, A.O. Zabriskie, Ephraim Marsh, Hon. D.S. Gregory, and M. Traphagen.

abstract: Amid the direful prognostics which are everywhere being drawn from the present schism of the States, France sends over, from two of her greatest orators, a loud paean to Democracy.
lead_paragraph: -- Amid the direful prognostics which are everywhere being drawn from the present schism of the States, France sends over, from two of her greatest orators, a loud paean to Democracy. On the occasion of the recent reception of Father LACORDAIRE into the Academie -- a "solemnity" which the Parisian journals describe as brilliant beyond all precedent, graced as it was by the Imperial presence and by all the notabilities in politics, science, literature and the arts -- the eloquent Dominican poured himself forth in the warmest eulogiums on the Republic, which were seconded and intensified by similar laudations from M. GUIZOT, to whose lot it fell to reply to the new member. Called to fill the fauteuil left vacant by the death of M. DE TOCQUEVILLE, it was natural that Father LACORDAIRE should expatiate on a theme so congenial to the memory of the great author of Democracy in America. But it seems there is no end to the virtues, civil and social, to the pieties and the patriotisms of which our too modest people are the unconscious illustrators and embodiments.

abstract: The river is gradually falling, and the probability is that no further damage will be done. There is yet no crossing from Greenbush to Albany, as the ice is a stationary mass. The passengers by the Hudson River Railroad proceed to Troy without changing cars, and the Albany passengers then take stages for that city. The Stockport Bridge is rebuilt, and yesterday the trains arrived at their respective destinations on time. The break was a very serious one, the piles of the bridge being carried bodily away by the force of the current and the immense masses of ice. The river was broken up for nearly a mile and a half each side of the bridge, and the country flooded for a considerable distance around. The officers of the Company have been on the spot superintending the work day and night. By Monday the bridge will be stronger than ever.

abstract: The report that France had demanded explanations on account of the speeches delivered by the King, was denied in Ministerial and Diplomatic quarters at Berlin.
lead_paragraph: The report that France had demanded explanations on account of the speeches delivered by the King, was denied in Ministerial and Diplomatic quarters at Berlin. In the commission appointed by the Prussian Chambers of Representatives, to indite the address in reply to the Royal speech, a proposition to insert a paragraph declaring that the consolidation of Italy was in the interest of Europe, was lost by a majority of one only, ten against and nine for.

abstract: We have very few arrivals to report to-day. The wind has been N.E., with rain. At 4 P.M., the wind suddenly shifted around by the southward to N.W., and from thence back to N.E. The ship War Hawk, for Liverpool, another ship, one bark and three brigs, are at anchor at the S.W. Spit, outward bound. The steamship Daniel Webster, Miner for Brazos, with U.S. troops, has anchored at Quarantine. The telegraph at Sandy Hook, at sunset, reports no inward-bound vessels in sight.

abstract: The organization of the Southern Confederacy meets with very much less than an enthusiastic reception at the hands of radical Secessionists.
lead_paragraph: The organization of the Southern Confederacy meets with very much less than an enthusiastic reception at the hands of radical Secessionists. The Charleston Mercury, the prescriptive mouth-piece of that faction, speaks with unqualified disgust of its leading characteristics; denounces especially the retention of the Tariff and Anti-Slave-trade policy of the former Union, and proposes a sullen submission only because the adjustment is provisional, and in another year will give way to ideas of that advanced order, for which YANCEY and RHETT precipitated the South into revolution. Nothing but this hope reconciles these implacable men to a programme so much less expanded than that for which they have labored through the last hall dozen years.

abstract: As the President elect approaches Washington, the revelation of his political views becomes more explicit.
lead_paragraph: As the President elect approaches Washington, the revelation of his political views becomes more explicit. Of the firm and dignified temper which he brings to the adjustment of our great national issue he gave satisfactory indications in Indiana. In Ohio he added the evidence that the same discretion should not be wanting in considerate forbearance and conciliation. And when he reaches Pennsylvania, and finds himself among the thriving workshops and mines of the Monongahela and Alleghany Valleys, he at once addresses himself to a topic at the same time of the highest local and of the highest national importance, and tells us what views he at present entertains of the questions of tariff, protection and revenue, and with what earnest purpose he proposes to apply himself to the mastery of these difficult subjects.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Charles Wentworth and James Robinson, indicted for burglary, pleaded guilty in the third degree.
lead_paragraph: In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Charles Wentworth and James Robinson, indicted for burglary, pleaded guilty in the third degree. Another similar indictment was pending against the prisoners, and as Wentworth was an old offender he was sent to Sing Sing for four years and two months. Robinson was sent to the same retreat for three years and two months.

abstract: Mr. JOHN B. GOUGH, the eminent temperance advocate, last evening electrified another audience so large that the capacious apartment in Cooper Institute, which has seen so many throngs, could hardly recall the night on which it had been much better filled; it was certainly never filled to better advantage. He laid an Atlantic cable from "the streets of London" -- that was the title of his lecture -- to New-York, and established a telegraph office in the heart of every listener. Over the wires, which were human nerves, he swept a fund of anecdote and information with regard to our cousins across the water, and especially their "Province covered with houses," as the British metropolis has been called.
lead_paragraph: Mr. JOHN B. abstract: There is always a certain comfort in being able to fall back on History or Philosophy for the support of a position about which one has misgivings. War for an "idea" is quite a diferent affair from your vulgar aggression. It is...
lead_paragraph: There is always a certain comfort in being able to fall back on History or Philosophy for the support of a position about which one has misgivings. War for an "idea" is quite a diferent affair from your vulgar aggression. It is so comfortable to be sustained by the conviction that one is, in his humble way, the agent of a Law of Nature -- a little minister of Fate, as it were! Thus the present French Emperor seems to be preparing this Spring to carry out his long meditated design of pushing his Eastern frontier to the Rhine -- not, understand you, actuated by any motions of that "spirit of conquest and usurpation," so severely reprehended by M. GUIZOT in his late Academic discourse, but purely to satisfy the conditions of Physical Geography. In like manner the loveliness of Negro Slavery, which is well known to be entirely justified by the sciences of Theology, Physiology and Ethnology, has received additional illustration from the erudite, not to say grammatical Dr. VAN EVRIE, who proves from anatomy that as Sambo, from the structure of the os calcis, cannot stand up straight, the eternal fitness of things will be best consulted by flattening him out as effectually as possible.

abstract: The fact must have struck the public mind as singular, that FLOYD and his agents confined their larceny of the Indian Trust funds to the bonds of Southern States. A large majority of the Trust Fund consists of the bonds of the Northern States, yet the thieves strictly confined their depredations to the stocks of Missouri, Virginia, Tennessee and North Carolina.

abstract: Mr. LINCOLN left Cleveland on Saturday morning, and reached Buffalo at 4 o'clock in the afternoon. A tremendous crowd was in waiting at the depot to receive him, through which he and his party with difficulty made their way to the carriages. So great was the pressure, which the Police force seems to have been totally inadequate to prevent, that one of Mr. LINCOLN's suite, Major HUNTER, of the Army, had his shoulder dislocated. The Mayor, on the arrival of the party at the American Hotel, introduced the President elect to the citizens of Buffalo, and he made a few remarks, which were received with the greatest favor. They were similar in tenor to those made at Pittsburgh, so far as relates to the present -- or rather, as expressed by Mr. LINCOLN -- the threatened difficulties. Yesterday he attended the Unitarian Church in Buffalo, in company with Ex-President FILLMORE. To-day he starts for Albany, where he will arrive at 3 o'clock P.M. He will leave Albany for this City to-morrow at 10 o'clock, and arrive here at 3. What will be done when he reaches here may be gathered from the reports, published in another column.

abstract: FREE ACADEMY JUNIOR EXHIBITION. The Junior Class of the Free Academy gave their annual exhibition on Saturday evening at Irving Hall, corner of Fifteenth-street and Irving-place. Dr. WEBSTER, the venerable President of the Institution, occupied the chair; the platform was filled with members of the Faculty an prominent citizens connected with educational movements, while the audience, as usual, comprised a goodly representation of the talent, wealth, solidity and female beauty of the Metropolis.
lead_paragraph: FREE ACADEMY -- JUNIOR EXHIBITION. -- The Junior Class of the Free Academy gave their annual exhibition on Saturday evening at Irving Hall, corner of Fifteenth-street and Irving-place. Dr. WEBSTER, the venerable President of the Institution, occupied the chair; the platform was filled with members of the Faculty an prominent citizens connected with educational movements, while the audience, as usual, comprised a goodly representation of the talent, wealth, solidity and female beauty of the Metropolis. The exercises consisted of orations by Messrs. Charles Roberts, Jr., Galen C. Spencer, Augustus D. Fitch, Otho E. Michaelis, James S. Page, Joseph Koch, Sidney H. Stuart, James M. Trippe and Adolph L. Sanger, and poems by George W. Snow, Jr. and Nathan B. Roberts. Dodworth's Band beguiled the hows with favorite operatic selections. The performances of the young orators and composers received from their respective friends their due meed of applause and floral tributes ad libitum. The great topic of the day -- recession -- came in for casual notices from several of the speakers, producing the expression of diverse sentiments among the audience. In Mr. PAGE's oration an allusion to "mob law at the South" created considerable excitement, hisses and applause. In the oration on "Ram and Sunshine," an allusion to GARIBALDI, Italy and Italian independence, provoked an outburst of enthusiatic approbation, and the gifted declaimer was showered with bouquets.

abstract: A SUCCESSFUL LITERARY ENTERPRISE. -- The prizes offered for 11-60 by the University Quarterly (the new College magazine published at New-Haven,) have been awarded as follows: The prize of $30 for the best article from a professional student, to EDWARD A. WALKEE, for his article written from Heidelberg University, Germany, on "German Student Life and Travel," and the prize of $20 for the best article from a colegiate student, to OLIVER WENDELL HOLMES, Jr., for his article from Harvard University, in the October number, on "Plato" The Committee of Award were Hon. GEORGE S. HILLARD, Ex-President HITCHOOCK, and Prof. GEORGE TICKNOP. The Quarterly has cleared its first year out of debt; its expenses having been about $1,900, and its receipts a little over $2,000. Nearly thirty colleges and professional schools are now engaged in its support.

abstract: MORTALITY. -- There were only 90 deaths in this city last week, classified by the Health Officer as follows: Men, 23; boys, 19; women, 17; girls, 37; Adults, 40; children, 56; Males, 42; female, 54; Colored persons, 1. Diseases -- Consumption, 21; scarlet fever, 8; infantile convulsions and inflammation of the lungs, 6 each; inflammation of the brain, 5; apoplexy, congestion of the brain and congestion of the lungs, 4 each; infantile debility and small-pox, 3 each; bronchitis, croup, diphtheria, disease of heart, inflammation of bowels, infantile marasmus, rheumatism and scrofula 2 each; and one each of abscess, disease of kidneys, asthma, cancer, casualties, compression of the brain, adult convulsions, adult debility, dropsy, dropsy in the head, erysipelas, bilious fever, typhoid fever, hooping-cough, premature birth, sprue. Forty-four of the 96 who died were under 5 years of age, and 69 were natives of the United States. The deaths occurred in the several Wards as follows: First, 3; Second, 3; Third, 4; Fourth, 3; Fifth, 7; Sixth, 14; Seventh, 7; Eighth, 4; Ninth, 3; Tenth, 8; Eleventh, 11; Twelfth, 3; Thirteenth, 3; Fourteenth, 5; Fifteenth, 1; Sixteenth, 7; Seventeenth, 1; Eighteenth, 1; Nineteenth, 3.

lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, the Special Committee of Aldermen and Councilmen deputed to wait upon the President elect and tender him the hospitalities of the City, started on their mission, intending to meet Mr. LINCOLN at Albany. After the official tender of the City's hospitalities, arrangements will be perfected for his reception and entertainment during his brief stay here. It is understood that apartments for Mr. LINCOLN have been secured at the Astor House by the Committee. He will be received on his arrival to-morrow afternoon, in the new depot of the Hudson River Railroad, foot of Thirty first-street, and escorted to his quarters, passing through Ninth-avenue. Twenty-third street and Broadway. Mr. VAN RANST, of Canal-street, who has charge of the vehicular portion of the proceedings, has assigned for the use of the President elect the carriage purchased for and used by the Prince of Wales, which has never been used since he role in it. On Wednesday, Mr. LINCOLN will receive the people in the Governor's Room. The [???] reception will he officially announced by the Committee.

abstract: A PRAYER FOR PURIFICATION. -- The question of street-cleaning having, under the contract system, been hung up for an indefinite term in the courts, an inquiry what shall be done for the streets and the public health, is not unreasonable. Months have passed since broom or shovel has been plied in warfare upon the accumulating filth. Other months, as matters now promise, must pass before any attempt can be made at cleanliness. Is there no divinity, akin to Cloarina, who shall save the community from the deluge of nastiness which seems inevitable without the intervention of some power superior to Common Councils and City Inspectors?

abstract: A terrible tragedy occurred in this city last night. A party of five Overland Mail and Little Rock coach-drivers entered the grocery of a German named HAGGE, and commenced quarreling. Pistols were drawn on both sides. The bar-keeper, named BUTCHER, was shot through the heart, and died instantly; HAGGE received a shot in the forehead, and died at 8 o'clock this morning.

abstract: The matinee given on Saturday, at the Academy of Music, was a pleasant and profitable return to a species of entertainment which had well-nigh been killed by the bad management of Mr. ULLMAN. The house was crowded to its greatest capacity, and by as fair a throng as ever was assembled within its walls.
lead_paragraph: The matinee given on Saturday, at the Academy of Music, was a pleasant and profitable return to a species of entertainment which had well-nigh been killed by the bad management of Mr. ULLMAN. The house was crowded to its greatest capacity, and by as fair a throng as ever was assembled within its walls. At this season, when there is a sort of fashionable objection to evening performances, it would, we think, be good policy to provide at least one matinee a week. Conducted properly, and with a decent determination to carry out the programme, and not merely to seize the dollar, as was the defunct manager's plan, there can hardly be a doubt about the success. On Saturday the performance was excellent, and gave complete satisfaction. The whole of VERDI's new opera, "Un Ballo en Maschera," was rendered, and the same work will be repea ed to-night, for the fourth time in America.

abstract: THE NEW TARIFF -- THE WAREHOUSE SYSTEM. -- In the Senate on Saturday, at the instance of Mr. SEWARD, the warehouse clause was stricken out of the Morrill bill, leaving the present system untouched. So far a great point has been gained. Now that the keystone of the bill has been swept away, why not postpone the whole measure to the next Congress, which is the only one that can be in a position to act in view of the emergencies that are hereafter to arise? Can there be any doubt of the policy of such a course, even on the part of the friends of the bill? Such is clearly Mr. LINCOLN's view of the case. Is it wise for the present Congress to define the policy of the incoming Administration? What this policy is to be is not yet disclosed. The first step it may be necessary for Mr. LINCOLN to take may be in direct conflict with the measures now sought to be enacted. Its passage, it strikes us. would be a great impediment to the pacification of our political differences. Let us see if these can be settled, and then let us have a tariff to which all are parties. As we must raise, if we can, the enormously increased expenses of Government by impost, there is no doubt that any tariff that would produce revenue enough, would be sufficiently protective. The present question is not one of low or high tariff, but whether any important change should be made, till we have more clearly before us the considerations by which we must in a great measure be controlled.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW TARIFF -- THE WAREHOUSE SYSTEM. -- In the Senate on Saturday, at the instance of Mr. SEWARD, the warehouse clause was stricken out of the Morrill bill, leaving the present system untouched. Is it wise for the present Congress to define the policy of the incoming Administration? What this policy is to be is not yet disclosed. The first step it may be necessary for Mr. LINCOLN to take may be in direct conflict with the measures now sought to be enacted. Its passage, it strikes us. would be a great impediment to the pacification of our political differences. Let us see if these can be settled, and then let us have a tariff to which all are parties. As we must raise, if we can, the enormously increased expenses of Government by impost, there is no doubt that any tariff that would produce revenue enough, would be sufficiently protective. The present question is not one of low or high tariff, but whether any important change should be made, till we have more clearly before us the considerations by which we must in a great measure be controlled.

lead_paragraph: On Saturday morning the United States steamer Crusader, Lieutenani-Commanding JOHN N. MAFFIT, connected with the Coast of Cuba fleet, arrived at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, where she was received with the customary salute. This vessel has been signally successful in capturing slavers, having made three prizes during her cruise. The Wyandotte and Mohawk are also stationed on the Cuban coast to intercept slavers. Commander MAFFIT, some time since received orders to report with his ship to Commodore BLEESE, at Brooklyn, but there being a demand for some important service at Key West, she was temporality delayed.

abstract: MOTLEY, in his History of the Dutch Republic, tells us that PHILIP II. of Spain was wont to say, "Time and I make two." In our political troubles, Time, in combination with our own action, has already given us a product of no small value. At the North we have emerged, seemingly, from a state of chaos to firm ground. We have over us the same Gov-...
lead_paragraph: MOTLEY, in his History of the Dutch Republic, tells us that PHILIP II. of Spain was wont to say, "Time and I make two." In our political troubles, Time, in combination with our own action, has already given us a product of no small value. At the North we have emerged, seemingly, from a state of chaos to firm ground. We have over us the same Government that has, since its formation, been the theme of panegyric both North and South, and under the fostering care of which we have made a progress in population and wealth that is the wonder of the world. This Government is as strong as ever it was in the affection of all the Northern States, and as efficient in every way for good. Social order is preserved, and with it all the industry upon which our wealth is based. Confidence is gradually returning. Whatever may have been individual losses -- and we admit they have been great -- our means for future acquisition are unimpaired, so that, in the worst event, we can adjust ourselves to our new circumstances, and again commence a new career of prosperity.

abstract: THE JAPANIC. -- Language has always a plus ultra. Boston was the first to discover that to be Aboriginal was something more than Original, and New-York has found that though being taken in is not badly expressed by the word Trepanned, that, in turn, is cast very far in the shade by hinting that a dupe has been Japanned. For -- varnish and lacquer it over as we will -- it cannot be denied that "the heathen have prevailed" on a most extensive scale, and that Brother Jonathan has discovered that his late Oriental guests have shown him that there are some folks who come from further down East than he himself -- and truly in more senses than one! Woeful, indeed, has been the effect of the explose that every traveling Kami was nothing but a commis voyageur -- a mere agent with never a title by birth -- while TOMMY was the gayest and grandest humbug of all! Last Summer our city asked for nothing but Japanem et circenses -- "the Japanese and balls to show them in" -- and now more than one of their old friends would only be too malignantly happy could he revolve a few balls into the Japanese. There is, however, this consolation at least for the afflicted givers of feasts and matinees -- if they were taken in it certainly was not by putting their trust in Princes!
lead_paragraph: THE JAPANIC. -- Language has always a plus ultra. Boston was the first to discover that to be Aboriginal was something more than Original, and New-York has found that though being taken in is not badly expressed by the word Trepanned, that, in turn, is cast very far in the shade by hinting that a dupe has been Japanned. Woeful, indeed, has been the effect of the explose that every traveling Kami was nothing but a commis voyageur -- a mere agent with never a title by birth -- while TOMMY was the gayest and grandest humbug of all! Last Summer our city asked for nothing but Japanem et circenses -- "the Japanese and balls to show them in" -- and now more than one of their old friends would only be too malignantly happy could he revolve a few balls into the Japanese. abstract: There is no more preposterous fallacy than that which is just now urged with such pertinacity by the adherents of two opposing political factions, that the fortunes of the whole of the Southern States are irrevocably linked together for the support and propagation of negro Slavery; or, that, because that institution is recognized in them all, therefore their aims, interests and destiny are identical.
lead_paragraph: There is no more preposterous fallacy than that which is just now urged with such pertinacity by the adherents of two opposing political factions, that the fortunes of the whole of the Southern States are irrevocably linked together for the support and propagation of negro Slavery; or, that, because that institution is recognized in them all, therefore their aims, interests and destiny are identical. For the fact is, that the mere incident of negro Slavery, so diverse in the different States in its extent, its scope, its history and its power, can furnish no such omnipotent bond of union to the exclusion of other interests, greater, more vital and universal. There is far more real antagonism to-day, both of interest and principle, between Missouri and South Carolina than there is between Massachusetts and North Carolina. Nay, so radically diverse are the purposes of the Disunion Cotton States from those of the nominally Slave States of the Great West, that the latter could not exist a year in a Confederacy in which South Carolina had a controlling voice. The conspirators of the Gulf, in their dreams of a Slave Empire of which they shall be the lords, would trample down every interest but their own; while in the States of the West and of the center, social and economical forces are working irresistibly to expel that black element which can never be other than perturbating and hostile. With the one, the negro interest is omnipotent, while in the other it is continually dwindling in power, and the broader interests of humanity are firmly asserting their supremacy, and jealously maintaining it.

abstract: There was a disappointed man in Rome on the morning of Feb. 8. Dr. Pope was out visiting his patients the evening previous, and got caught in the terrific snow storm which swept over Western New York on that day.
lead_paragraph: -- There was a disappointed man in Rome on the morning of Feb. 8. Dr. Pope was out visiting his patients the evening previous, and got caught in the terrific snow storm which swept over Western New York on that day. While endeavoring to reach the house of a Mr. Ford, near Verona Springs, he became bewildered, lost his way, and finally concluded to seek shelter under a clamp of bees, so he made his horse as comfortable as possible, turned over the cutter, and crept underneath it. On emerging from his hiding-place in the morning, he found that the trees which he had mistaken for a grove were the shade trees around the very house which he had made an effort to reach, and where he would have been made very welcome had he only gone a dozen steps further and knocked at the door.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. VARDI'S new opera was played last night for the fourth time, and attracted a very briliant and satisfactory audience. Now that the singers are thoroughly at ease in their parts, and ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- VARDI's new opera was played last night for the fourth time, and attracted a very briliant and satisfactory audience. Now that the singers are thoroughly at ease in their parts, and the orchestral and choral forces perfectly up to their work, the opera goes off with much more spirit, being, of course, relatively more complete. It is impossible to hear it to greater advantage than at present, for all the performers take an interest in what they are doing. Every piece was capitally rendered last night, except occasionally, when Mme. COLSON'S hoarseness became apparent. The audience applauded rapturously and redemanded several of the principal morceaux. There cannot be a doubt about the prosperous run of this very charming opera.

abstract: The arrangements for the reception of the President elect in this City to-day, were fully completed as far as the Committee of the Common Council is concerned, before the latter left the City to meet Mr. LINCOLN at Albany.
lead_paragraph: The arrangements for the reception of the President elect in this City to-day, were fully completed as far as the Committee of the Common Council is concerned, before the latter left the City to meet Mr. LINCOLN at Albany. The Republican Central Club and various Ward Associations met last evening and made their preparations for joining in escorting him to his hotel on his arrival here. The occasion will undoubtedly call forth immense throngs of people, and special police arrangements have been made for preserving order. If the Prince of Wales and his suite, who commended so highly the quiet bearing of our masses, were not mistaken in their notions, the guardians of the peace will have very little to do.

abstract: WORK ON THE NEW RESERVOIR AND FOURTHAVENCE. Notwithstanding the unfavorable state of the weather since December, the work on the New Reservoir in the Central Park, and in laying the new fourfeet mains in the Fourth-avenue, has been unremittingly prosecuted. On the reservoir, over seven hundred ...
lead_paragraph: WORK ON THE NEW RESERVOIR AND FOURTH-AVENCE. -- Notwithstanding the unfavorable state of the weather since December, the work on the New Reservoir in the Central Park, and in laying the new fourfeet mains in the Fourth-avenue, has been unremittingly prosecuted. On the reservoir, over seven hundred men have been employed throughout the season, mostly engaged in blasting and working the road which is to form a drive around this immense artificial lake. On the Fourth-avenue, the contractors, Messrs. HARKLEY, knowing the importance of the work, and warned by the bursting, a few weeks since, of the large pipes in the Fifth-avenue, have kept gangs of men steadily at work through the entire Winter and will undoubtedly complete the laying of the pipes within the period specified in their contract. The trenches in the Park which are to form the resting-place of the new mains are nearly completed. At the Central Park a double line of these huge pipes, four feet in diameter, is on the ground, reaching from the present receiving reservoir to the Fourth-avenue, while on the avenue the ditching, blasting and laying of pipes has been prosecuted without delay, except such as has arisen from the state of the weather. With these two important connections completed, and the seven feet pipes laid across the High Bridge, the citizens of New-York need be under nor apprehensions as to a lack in the supply of the indispensable Croton. At the High Bridge, the work of laying the seven-foot pipes have progressed silently but rapidly, the whole distance from either gaze-house being already down with the exception of about one hundred feet. This work has been under the special direction and supervision of J.S. GREEN, Esq., the engineer in change, which is a sufficient guarantee that everything is faith-fully and thoroughly done.

abstract: The magnitude and importance of the trade of New-York, have always been a source of envy to some of our Boston friends who cannot see why the "hub of the Universe" should not advance as fast in commercial importance as this metropolis.
lead_paragraph: The magnitude and importance of the trade of New-York, have always been a source of envy to some of our Boston friends who cannot see why the "hub of the Universe" should not advance as fast in commercial importance as this metropolis. There are certain causes which are so patent to all thinking business men as to render it unnecessary to enumerate them, that have rendered New-York the great commercial centre of this country -- a position which each succeeding year will only serve to strengthen. The Boston Commercial Bulletin does not let its notion that the axle of the earth runs through State-street prevent it from speaking pretty independently, and telling the merchants of the "city of notions" some plain truths. We copy the following from a recent article in that paper:

abstract: The Court-room of the Hudson County CourtHouse was again filled this (Monday) morning by persons anxious to hear sentence pronounced upon ABSON, the wife poisoner, and about 2,000 persons were congregated outside, unable to gain an entrance.
lead_paragraph: The Court-room of the Hudson County CourtHouse was again filled this (Monday) morning by persons anxious to hear sentence pronounced upon ABSON, the wife poisoner, and about 2,000 persons were congregated outside, unable to gain an entrance. The gallery was entirely filled with women. Sheriff FRANCIS had made arrangements to prevent a repetition of the disgraceful proceedings of Monday last. The culprit was conducted to the jury-room about 8 A.M., and there remained until the opening of the Court at 11 A.M., at which hour he was brought before Judge OGDEN and Associate Judges FINK and POPE.

abstract: George Martin, Appellant, vs. The Mayor, , of New-York, and Oliver H. Valentine, et al. vs. The Same Respondents. These two cases, involving substantially the same points of law, came on this morning to be heard at this Court.
lead_paragraph: George Martin, Appellant, vs. The Mayor, &c., of New-York, and Oliver H. Valentine, et al. vs. The Same Respondents. -- These two cases, involving substantially the same points of law, came on this morning to be heard at this Court. Under the act of 1859, the Comptroller of this City applied to the Special Term of this Court to open four several judgments recovered against the City. The application was denied, on the ground that the judgment having been originally obtained in the Marine Court, and transcripts filed in the County Clerk's office, this court had no power on motion to open or reverse them. A similar application was then made in the Marine Court, but denied on the ground that that court can only open its own judgments when they have been obtained by default. The Comptroller then applied to the Special Term of this Court for a perpetual injunction to restrain the several plaintiffs from enforcing their judgments by execution. Such an injunction was granted by the Special Term, from which the plaintiffs now appeal.

abstract: The Gulf States, by the inauguration of Gen. DAVIS as Provisional President, have perfected the outline of their Government. The most striking trait of these arrangements is the frigid disregard with which the more northern tier of Slave States have been treated.
lead_paragraph: The Gulf States, by the inauguration of Gen. DAVIS as Provisional President, have perfected the outline of their Government. The most striking trait of these arrangements is the frigid disregard with which the more northern tier of Slave States have been treated. Their action has not been waited for; their opinions have not been consulted; a form of government has been adopted without reference to them; the offices under it have been filled exclusively from the Cotton States. The President and Vice-President have been taken from Mississippi and Georgia; none of the gentlemen said to be selected for seats in the Cabinet are from beyond the limits of the actual Confederacy; the foreign Envoys are chosen by the same rule; and what legislation has been adopted has not been of a character to conciliate the good will of the doubtful sovereignties. It is obvious, therefore, that if the latter secede at once from their Northern associations, they can only assume towards the Southern Government an attitude of dependence; presenting to the world the spectacle of eight powerful States submitting to the rule of seven others, weaker in resources and population, and addicted to schemes of external aggrandizement and internal economy, fatal to the interests of the Confederation, and yet beyond the control of a conservative counterpoise. Evidently, none but absolutely desperate conditions can impel Virginia, Kentucky or Tennessee into a relation such as this.

abstract: If the New World, by an extraordinary coincidence, is at present like the Old, approaching a tremendous political crisis, it has at least the advantage of the mother hemisphere in perfectly understanding the conditions of the difficulty in which it is involved.
lead_paragraph: If the New World, by an extraordinary coincidence, is at present like the Old, approaching a tremendous political crisis, it has at least the advantage of the mother hemisphere in perfectly understanding the conditions of the difficulty in which it is involved. It is certainly no exaggeration to say that while all Europe sees before it possible war and revolution in the most stupendous scale -- it may be, such a breaking up of great depths and overwhelming of nationalities as has not been witnessed since the transition of the Middle Ages, -- it does not possess a journalist who sees in the whole anything more than a muddle. A muddle, to be sure, of enormous extent -- a chaos of a muddle -- and yet a muddle after all. Antiquity rejoiced in Cretan and Egyptian labyrinths, sphynxes and Gordian knots. The Modern Age surpasses them all with a political "situation."
headline: {'main': 'The European Muddle.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The European Muddle.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The last act in the constitution of the Southern American Confederacy was achieved yesterday, by the inauguration of Gen. DAVIS in the Presidential office. The address of the new Chief Magistrate will be found at length elsewhere in this paper. It will be read with profound attention.
lead_paragraph: The last act in the constitution of the Southern American Confederacy was achieved yesterday, by the inauguration of Gen. DAVIS in the Presidential office. The address of the new Chief Magistrate will be found at length elsewhere in this paper. It will be read with profound attention. It is natural, indeed, that the public should hang with intense interest on the utterances of those who are to wield the power and represent the dignities and honors of the State. This interest is heightened, if possible, when the occasion is an era -- the severance of old relations or the commencement of a new career. Declarations, at such a time, are taken as the enunciation of the policy, or life, of the new order of things. That of the new Republic, its President tells us, is to be peace in its internal organization, from the homogeneity of its industries and interests. Nothing is to be feared from abroad; because, if war should come, the Southern people must again assert the principles for which their fathers bled in the Revolution. He tells us that the Southern Confederacy will have no complications. Its separation from the old Union is complete. No compromise, no reconstruction can now be entertained.

abstract: Erastus Genin vs. George W. Chadsey and Myron H. Decker. This action was commenced by an application for an injunction to restrain the defendants from using as a sign the words upon the plaintiff's sign "Live and Let Live."
lead_paragraph: Erastus Genin vs. George W. Chadsey and Myron H. Decker. -- This action was commenced by an application for an injunction to restrain the defendants from using as a sign the words upon the plaintiff's sign -- "Live and Let Live." The plaintiff showed, by the affidavits of his brother, John N. Genin, the hatter, P.T. Barnum, and others, whose places of business have been long adjacent to his, that he had used the sign for about eighteen years, over the doors of his saloon, at No. 214 Broadway, under the Museum.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, the first case called was that of James Shepherd, already twice tried, and once sentenced to be executed, for the crime of arson. The case now came up for a new trial, on the reversal of judgment in the Court of Appeals, where the Judge, in delivering the opinion of the Court, remarked that the evidence in the case was not sufficient to base even a probability of the prisoner's guilt upon. Owing to the general notoriety of the circumstances of the care, it was supposed that difficulty would arise in obtaining a jury from the list already drawn, who had not heard something about the case, and formed an opinion concerning it, and a new panel of 150 was, therefore, drawn, of whom about 50 appeared, and were sworn.

abstract: We know not how to record the monstrous fact, that a suspicion of corruption has been breathed against one of our State legislators; know not in what terms to break to the people of our City and State the sad tidings, that ...
lead_paragraph: We know not how to record the monstrous fact, that a suspicion of corruption has been breathed against one of our State legislators; know not in what terms to break to the people of our City and State the sad tidings, that a member of Assembly has been not only suspected, but publicly accused and arrested for having demanded a miserable bribe of $100 to east his vote in favor of a particular measure! "The evidence of his crime," says the telegraphic report, "is indisputable;" but little did the telegrapher know of the ingenious -- not to say insurmountable, barriers against conviction, devised by the admirable foresight of former Legislatures, anxious to protect members of their own body from any such thing as substantial punishment.

abstract: Mr. L.W. SPRATT addresses a four-column letter, through the Charleston Mercury, to Hoa. JOHN PERKINS, Delegate to the Montgomery Convention from Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: Mr. L.W. SPRATT addresses a four-column letter, through the Charleston Mercury, to Hon. JOHN PERKINS, Delegate to the Montgomery Convention from Louisiana. His subject is, of course, the action of the (Southern Congress, in inserting a clause in the Constitution of the C.S.A., prohibiting the Slave-trade. He boldly asserts that "the South is now in the formation of a Slave Republic." Many may not be willing to admit this, but it is a fact, nevertheless, for the contest which has led to the secession of the Gulf States was between the Free and Slave systems of labor. For the result Mr. SPRATT returns his heartiest thanks to the Radical Republicans and Abolitionists who have labored so zealously to alienate the sections, and declares that if he had possessed the power he would not have changed their feelings or their opinions. Even now, Mr. SPRATT acknowledges that the contest is not definitively ended. It must go on in the more northern of the States now Slave, and may end in concentrating this class of labor in the States on the Gulf. The new Confederacy, he argues, should recognize this fact; it should declare itself distinctively a Slave Republic; then the States which intended to remain Slave States would seek for admission into it, and none other would come. Thus would the Government inaugurate a career which would be more brilliant than that of any organization which has preceded it. Otherwise the irrepressible conflict will be inaugurated in the new Republic itself. As for the moral sentiment of the world, Mr. SPRATT boldly takes the ground that if deference to it is going to cause the prohibition of the Slave-trade, Slavery itself should be at once abolished, for the condemnation of the one is as strong as that of the other. In conclusion, Mr. SPRATT declares that "if the clause, in question be carried into the Permanent Government, the whole movement is defeated. It will abolitionize the Border Slave States -- it will brand our institutions. Slavery cannot share a Government with Democracy -- it cannot hear a brand upon it; thence another revolution. It may be painful, but we must make it."

abstract: Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday held an inquest upon the body of a male infant, born on Sunday morning at No. 149 Leonard-street, whose death is alleged to have been caused by the neglect of its mother, a German woman, named WILHELMINA ERNST, employed as a domestic by Mr. ADAM DIPPLE. From the testimony it appeared that the accused, who is unmarried, after her confinement sent for a physician, but the child was quite dead when he came. She declared that it had been still-born, but a post-mortem examination, made by Dr. G.W. BOUTON, fully satisfied the Jury that such was not the fact, and they returned a verdict of death from suffocation. The accused, who is nineteen years of age, and a native of Germany, was fully committed to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: The Cooper Union Music Class will give a testimonial concert to Dr. CHARLES A. GUILMETTS, in Cooper Institute, this evening. abstract: The Police arrargements were admirably planned and commendably executed. With the order for parade a hint was incorporated to the effect that it would be well for the men all to wear their best clothes, and furnish themselves with new belts and yellow kids.
lead_paragraph: The Police arrargements were admirably planned and commendably executed. With the order for parade a hint was incorporated to the effect that it would be well for the men all to wear their best clothes, and furnish themselves with new belts and yellow kids. The hint was very generally acted upon, and each of the thirteen hundred men, composing the force detailed to preserve order at the depot and along the route of the procession, looked spruce enough and conducted himself in a manner worthy of an individual compliment from the distinguished visitor. The force was disposed into two divisions, under the command of Inspectors DILKS and LEONARD. These divisions were subdivided into eight detachments of 150 men each, and a corps d'occasion, comprising the Broadway squad and others, to the number of one hundred more. A captain was selected and placed in command of each detachment, and to each was assigned a given space along the route over which to hold despotic sway. The citizens of New-York, however, on this occasion did not lose their reputation for order, as no attempt was made by the throng which fringed the sidewalks to break the police lines. As soon as the last carriage in the cortege passed by a line of officers formed in its rear, allowed the crowd to follow and surrendering the street again to its ordinary uses.

abstract: Punctually at 3 P.M., yesterday, the special train Which conveyed the President elect and suite arrived at the new depot of the Hudson River Railroad, on Thirtieth-street, between Ninth and Tenth avenues.
lead_paragraph: Punctually at 3 P.M., yesterday, the special train Which conveyed the President elect and suite arrived at the new depot of the Hudson River Railroad, on Thirtieth-street, between Ninth and Tenth avenues. The building, which was thrown open for the first time on this occasion, was gaily decorated with flags. None were admitted there but those who had tickets. The Police were stationed in force within, and without, and in Thirtieth-street confined a swaying, compact crowd of men, women and children within the limits of the sidewalks. The carriage-way was kept clear, and there, drawn up near the depot, were thirty-five carriages, provided by Mr. EDWARD VAN RANST, for the accommodation of Mr. LINCOLN and those who were to escort him to his hotel.

abstract: In discussing a royal speech or imperial address, it is well to bear in mind the fact that what we would like to exact from the speaker is not invariably what we may reasonably expect to get.
lead_paragraph: In discussing a royal speech or imperial address, it is well to bear in mind the fact that what we would like to exact from the speaker is not invariably what we may reasonably expect to get. Nothing in the world is easier than to assume a virtuous, a liberal, a humane stand-point, and prove from it the utter vileness of almost any human effort; and when national prejudice or personal interest aid in the coloring, it is not unusual for the "weak-minded and virtuous" to believe that it is a sin not to think the worst of it. And we are powerfully reminded of this wide possibility of difference, in examining the late speech of the Emperor of France, before the Chambers, and the very natural comments upon it by the London Times. Perhaps there are few instances on record in which political truth lay more exactly in medio, between the original and the comment, than in this.
headline: {'main': 'The Imperial Speech.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Imperial Speech.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: THACKERAY has somewhere informed us that what with mesalliances and dyings-out, there are not above half a dozen really good families left in England.
lead_paragraph: THACKERAY has somewhere informed us that what with mesalliances and dyings-out, there are not above half a dozen really good families left in England. What with the searching and investigating of this curious age, aided by increased fearlessness in Courts, and, above all, by the daring publicity of the Press, it really seems as if no "good" families -- no real old blue blood -- will ere long be found unmixed anywhere. The unfortunate Miss RYVES seems to be coming to her rights -- "Plon-Plon" and MATHILDE are effectually spoiled in legitimacy -- or, in heraldic phrase, have had "fitz" emphatically given to them by the American Bonapartes -- and now the Comte de CHAMBORD is again being entertained by stories chronicling the existence of a first wife in 1816, when his father married the Duchesse DE BERRY. We are told that during the Patterson trial it came to light that the register of marriages had been tampered with, "doubtless by the Ambassador of Lours Dixhuit, the mutilated record of Miss BROWN'S union with the Duke DE BERRY, in 1806, bearing evidence of the alarm a discovery might cause."

abstract: When the Egyptians could do nothing else whereby to express their "despise" for conquerors or races who had brought them to grief, they painted their pictures on the soles of their boots and strutted around, proud to
lead_paragraph: When the Egyptians could do nothing else whereby to express their "despise" for conquerors or races who had brought them to grief, they painted their pictures on the soles of their boots and strutted around, proud to be able to, at least symbolically, tread their enemies under foot. The Charlestonians are becoming quite as dignified in the divers details of vengeance, and, as we learn, are searching carefully the names of their streets, in order to scratch from the lists all northern names whatever. "When such an unlucky circumstance is discovered as a Yankee name, it is immediately obliterated and some one full of the peculiar melody, pertaining to all things in the soft and sunny South, is substituted." The Common Council of Mobile have, however, actually acted on the hint, changing Maine to Palmetto-street, Massachusetts-street to Charleston, New-Hampshire to Augusta, Rhode Island to Savannah, Connecticut to Louisiana, New-York to Elmira, Vermont to Texas, and Pennsylvania to Montgomery streets.

abstract: The two events of the English year are the opening of Parliament and its prorogation. The former of these has just occurred; and as Her Majesty delivered the speech from the throne in person, and not by the mouth of the Chancellor, the rite was maimed in none of its customary particulars. The speech itself is an unusually clear representation, of the state of the nation. The real value of the French alliance, as cemented by the Commercial treaties; the relation the English Government is disposed to maintain with the Italian question; a cheerful confidence in peace, notwithstanding the menacing aspect of affairs in the Continent; congratulatory allusions to Syria and China, and a less decided symbol of satisfaction touching the course of events in New-Zealand; are, with the standing recommendations of certain classes of legislation, the staple of the oral royal message.

abstract: Hon. HANNIBAL HAMLIN, the Vice-President elect, left Boston yesterday morning, and was expected to arrive in this City on the 4 1/2 P.M. train, but for some reason, not yet explained, he got off the train at a place called Windsor Locks, between Springfield and Hartford, where he will stop until the arrival of the Boston express-train to-day, when he will continue his journey to New York, arriving here at 4 3/4 o'clock. A Committee, representing the City Wide-Awakes and the Rocky Mountain Club of Kings County, were in waiting at the New-Haven Railroad depot yesterday to escort Mr. HAMLIN to the Astor House, but on the arrival of the train, they were informed, much to their disappointment, that the Vice-President elect was not on board.
lead_paragraph: Hon. abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMANN, George Miller and Thos. Killelea, who pleaded guilty, on the previous day, to petit larceny, were sentenced to the Penitentiary -- Miller for three months, and Killelea for six months. These boys were together, and had been drinking all day, when the brilliant idea flashed through their minds that a profitable speculation might be made by turning brokers, and breaking in a broker's window. This they did, and in, imitation of the great sovereignty of Louisiana, pocketed funds to which they had no legitimate claim. "Retribution follows crime."

abstract: If any doubt had previously existed of the steady loyalty and law-abiding temper of this City, it is set at rest by the welcome which yesterday greeted Mr. LINCOLN.
lead_paragraph: If any doubt had previously existed of the steady loyalty and law-abiding temper of this City, it is set at rest by the welcome which yesterday greeted Mr. LINCOLN. An immeasurable outpouring of the people flooded the avenues and streets through which the escort passed; those untold and perhaps fabulous thousands of idle and starving workmen were, doubtless for want of other employment, in curious attendance; and, in fact, New-York may be said to have waited in person upon the coming of the future Chief Magistrate of the nation. And certainly no welcome could have been more cordial or respectful. The harmony of incessant cheers was unbroken by indecent language, or gesture, or act of violence. Along the protracted route the President was encountered everywhere by indications of the most earnest good will and respect for his person, and for his high and momentous vocation; and if there lurked anywhere those feelings of discontent and malignity which a portion of the City Press has been accustomed to dilate upon, they had the rare courtesy to mask themselves perfectly for this occasion.
headline: {'main': 'The Reception of the President Elect.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Reception of the President Elect.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: New-York policemen will be glad to know that Samuel Sprince, the well-known receiver of stolen goods, who was convicted of that offence in this City about a year ago, and fined six cents by Judge Russell, has been arrested in Canada, charged with burglary. Sprince, who had frequently been in the hands of the police during his residence here, always found some means of escaping the proper penalty of his crime, no matter how certainly they could be proved against him. Within a few weeks of his conviction and nominal fine, he was again caught in dishonest practices, but fearing to risk a trial, even before Judge Russell, so soon after the former affair had been disposed of, he fled to Canada, taking up his residence at Hamilton. Recently the police authorities became satisfied that Sprince purchased the proceeds of the numerous burglaries committed here, and Detective King was sent to watch his house. On making a search of the premises the officers found a lot of property which was identified as having been stolen the night before from a store in Hamilton. The evidence being conclusive against the accused, there is no doubt he will have justice meted to him.
lead_paragraph: New-York policemen will be glad to know that Samuel Sprince, the well-known receiver of stolen goods, who was convicted of that offence in this City about a year ago, and fined six cents by Judge Russell, has been arrested in Canada, charged with burglary. Sprince, who had frequently been in the hands of the police during his residence here, always found some means of escaping the proper penalty of his crime, no matter how certainly they could be proved against him. Within a few weeks of his conviction and nominal fine, he was again caught in dishonest practices, but fearing to risk a trial, even before Judge Russell, so soon after the former affair had been disposed of, he fled to Canada, taking up his residence at Hamilton. Recently the police authorities became satisfied that Sprince purchased the proceeds of the numerous burglaries committed here, and Detective King was sent to watch his house. On making a search of the premises the officers found a lot of property which was identified as having been stolen the night before from a store in Hamilton. The evidence being conclusive against the accused, there is no doubt he will have justice meted to him.

abstract: The Court-martial assembled to try Lieut. BARBOT, of the United States steamer Mohawk, met again yesterday at the Lyceum of the Brooklyn Navy-yard, Com. STRINGHAM presiding. The accused was assisted as before by Messrs. JOHN R. TARINGTON and GEO. W. GREENHOW, Paymaster CALHOUN acting Judge Advocate. JOHN BENSEN Master at-Arms on the Mohawk, was the first witness examined on the part of the prosecution. He deposed generally to the parts of the case. Surgeon STEWART gave evidence as to the injury inflicted on BENNETT, and M. MORRISON, Third Assistant Engineer, testified generally as to what he knew of the matter.
lead_paragraph: The Court-martial assembled to try Lieut. BARBOT, of the United States steamer Mohawk, met again yesterday at the Lyceum of the Brooklyn Navy-yard, Com. STRINGHAM presiding. abstract: Deputations from the Old and Young Men's Central Committees, the Wide-Awake Central Committees, (English and German,) the Central Campaign Club, and various other Republican organizations in the City, numbering altogether one hundred or over, met
lead_paragraph: Deputations from the Old and Young Men's Central Committees, the Wide-Awake Central Committees, (English and German,) the Central Campaign Club, and various other Republican organizations in the City, numbering altogether one hundred or over, met at the rooms of the Young Men's Central Committee, No. 618 Broadway, last evening, preparatory to visiting Mr. LINCOLN at the Astor House. Arrangements had previously been made at Albany for Mr. LINCOLN to receive delegations from the various Republican organizations at 8 o'clock in the evening. At 7 3/4 the delegates formed in line, and marched down Broadway, two abreast, to the Astor House, where they were ushered into the large dining room, on the north, end of the Hotel.

abstract: There is much wisdom, no doubt, in proverb's, but the profitable use thereof, it should be remembered, is largely contingent upon the discretion of those who employ the same.
lead_paragraph: There is much wisdom, no doubt, in proverb's, but the profitable use thereof, it should be remembered, is largely contingent upon the discretion of those who employ the same. We will, all of us, admit, for instance, that "too many cooks may spoil the broth," and yet nothing can be more certain than that a culinary revolution in the midst of a banquet, would probably be fatal to the success of the feast, even if it replaced an incompetent directory of fanatical SOYERS, by a single NAPOLEON of the stew-pan. Our Legislators at Albany, need to bear this in mind when they approach that chronic temptation of experimental Solons, the Central Park Commission. The Central Park as it is, involves the whole future of the Central Park as we hope to have it. Nobody seriously objects to the actual operation of the system now in force for its government and direction; everybody is beginning to enjoy the benefits it is already conferring upon the Metropolis; why not then, let well enough alone?
