abstract: It is always a recommendation that oil-paintings, from Italy, offered for sale in this City, were not collected for that express purpose; when such is the case, trash and imposition, may be confidently asserted to enter largely into the enterprise. Indeed, so much as a matter of course is this inference, that lovers of art and judges thereof seldom trouble themselves to examine the pictures advertised as "Old Masters just imported from Italy." Quite a different sale is advertised by LEEDS & Co., to take place to-morrow, the 21st inst., at 11 o'clock, at their gallery No. 23 Nassau-street. Both on account of the works themselves, and of the estimable owner there of, we desire to call special attention to this sale. JAMES E. FREEMAN, a native of this State, and a painter of established reputation, during a residence of twenty years at Rome, has collected between two and three hundred pictures, sketches and studies, chosen either because of their intrinsic merit, the fame of the painters or interesting historical association. It is just such a collection as an artist and a lover of art would enjoy. Some of the pictures are old and some quite new -- some are by Italian, some by German, and some by American artists -- among the latter, several good things, by FREEMAN himself, and one admirable picture by COLEMAN -- so famous for his Campagna, and Buffalo scenes. Many of the architectural pieces are of great local interest to those familiar with Italy. The original sketches are full of character; there are many small pictures which are perfect gems of color and composition. The last two Winters have been very unprofitable to foreign artists in Rome; and only necessity induces FREEMAN to part with these pictures; we hope, for his sake, they will bring good prices; and, for the sake of art, that they will be examined and appreciated by collectors of judgment and taste.

abstract: The President-elect reached this City, yesterday afternoon, after being greeted at every station this side of Albany, by enthusiastic crowds to whom he made two or three short addresses. The reception in this City must have been peculiarily gratifying to him, and was also well worthy of the Metropolis. Mr. LINCOLN arrived promptly at 3
lead_paragraph: The President-elect reached this City, yesterday afternoon, after being greeted at every station this side of Albany, by enthusiastic crowds to whom he made two or three short addresses. The reception in this City must have been peculiarily gratifying to him, and was also well worthy of the Metropolis. Mr. LINCOLN arrived promptly at 3 o'clock, and was escorted to the Astor-House by the Common Council in carriages. The line of the route along Ninth-avenue, Twenty-third-street, Fifth-avenue, Fourteenth-street and Broadway was crowded with spectators, almost equaling the turnout to witness the Japanese and Prince of Wales pageants. At the Astor-House Mr. LINCOLN was waited upon by various delegations of Republicans, and made several brief speeches. The ships in the harbor, particularly those of the London. Liverpool and Havre lines, were handsomely decorated with bunting, and the Stars and Stripes waved from many flag-staffs, on the New-York, Brooklyn, and New-Jersey sides of the river. To-day the official reception by the Mayor, and Mr. LINCOLN'S response, and the reception of the people at large, takes place at the City Hall.

abstract: The Joint Committee of the Common Council and citizens of Jersey City, have completed their arrangements for the reception of President LINCOLN. The President elect will be received on board of a ferry-boat, provided for the purpose, and while crossing the river, a salute of thirty-four guns will be fired on the dock, by the Hudson County Artillery. Upon reaching the wharf, the President elect will be escorted to a platform in the depot of the New-Jersy Railroad Company, and introduced to the citizens by His Honor, Mayor VAN VORST. The balcony in the interior of the depot, will be reserved exclusively for the ladies, who will be admitted at 8 A.M., and gentlemen will be admitted at 9 1/4 o'clock. The depot will accommodate from 8,000 to 10,000 persons, and all who gain admission, will have a good opportunity of seeing and hearing Mr. LINCOLN.
lead_paragraph: The Joint Committee of the Common Council and citizens of Jersey City, have completed their arrangements for the reception of President LINCOLN. abstract: Mr. LINCOLN'S arrival at Washington is awaited with, eagerness and anxiety. His presence there has become a necessity, not only to the success of judicious efforts for preserving the Union, but to the peace and
lead_paragraph: Mr. LINCOLN's arrival at Washington is awaited with, eagerness and anxiety. His presence there has become a necessity, -- not only to the success of judicious efforts for preserving the Union, but to the peace and harmony of the party which is responsible for the administration of the Government. The Peace Convention is making but little substantial progress. It will have great difficulty in reaching any harmonious conclusion, and still greater in securing for its action, the approval or even the serious attention of Congress. The fact, upon which we have so often insisted, -- that the whole responsibility of meeting the crisis devolves upon the incoming Administration, seems now to be gradually recognized: and all parties, and all men, who desire the preservation of the Union, are looking forward with eager anticipation to the day when the policy of that Administration shall be disclosed.

abstract: It Will be seen from our telegraphic reports that the State of Arkansas, so far as heard from, casts her vote against holding a Convention for the purpose of linking her destinies to the seceded Cotton States:
lead_paragraph: -- It Will be seen from our telegraphic reports that the State of Arkansas, so far as heard from, casts her vote against holding a Convention for the purpose of linking her destinies to the seceded Cotton States; and that upon the raising of the national flag over the Court-house in Fayetteville, the enthusiasm of the people broke forth into one of those spontaneous ebulitions of patriotic sentiment -- such as the politicians, who are usually in control of popular assemblages, have neither the art to stimulate, when the public pulse is apathetic, nor to restrain, whenever the general heart feels warmly enlisted in any cause.

lead_paragraph: Such a wonderful stir in the market as the advent of Prof. WOOD'S RESTORATIVE CORDIAL AND BLOOD RENOVATOR. In it we have all the Scientific Medical Skill acquired in a close study of thirty years or more. The cures it has performed are so numerous and striking as to arrest the attention and confidence of the most intelligent all over the country, and thousands will bless the day that their attention was called to such an article. But, as the reader will see is our habit, we prefer to let others, and those who are disinterested, tell the story. We cannot publish all, so we select the following, and say read, and doubt if you can.

abstract: There was a handsome display of bunting upon the shipping which lined the East River. Conspicuous among the vessels thus decorated, were the ships Isaac Webb and Neptune, of CHAS. H. MARSHALL's Liverpool line; the New-World, belonging to CORNELIUS GRINNELL; the Liverpool, of GRINNELL, MONTURN Co.; the John Bright, belonging to WILLIAMS GUION;...
lead_paragraph: There was a handsome display of bunting upon the shipping which lined the East River. Conspicuous among the vessels thus decorated, were the ships Isaac Webb and Neptune, of CHAS. H. MARSHALL's Liverpool line; the New-World, belonging to CORNELIUS GRINNELL; the Liverpool, of GRINNELL, MONTURN & Co.; the John Bright, belonging to WILLIAMS & GUION; A.A. LAW's ships; the Asa Eldridge, of H.L. HALLETT's London line, and also several vessels in the Havre trade. All these craft displayed a profusion of bunting, everywhere prominent being the American ensign; the ROGERS, international, and other codes of signals, serving to set off the general effect. The John Bright also displayed the English Jack at the fore. The Texas, New-Orleans and other Southern lines of vessels hoisted no colors. HECKER & BROTHERS' large establishment, the Seaman's Home, the different Bethels, and many private establishments along the the river, both on the New-York and Brooklyn side, flung their colors to the breeze, in honor of the President elect of the United States.

abstract: A correspondent of the New-Orleans Picayune, writing on board the steamboat Fulton near Donaldsonville, under date of Feb 10, gives the particulars of the destruction by fire of the steamboat Charmer. She caught fire in the after part of the engine-room, among a quantity of cotton. The boat was immediately headed for the bank of the river, but despite the greatest exertions six or eight passengers were lost. Among the number were three negro women, Dr. MILLIKEN and wife, Mr. AMBROSE DAVIE, of Tennessee, and wife; a Mr. GREEN, thought to have been a merchant of New-Orleans, and one of the cabin boys. The charmer was owned by Captains WILSON and HOLMES -- the latter being in command at the time of the accident. She was valued at $115,000, and was insured in Western offices for about $35,000.

abstract: Senator JOHNSON, of Arkansas, is no believer in the right of popular petition. Not so much that he objects to memorials, with many thousand names attached, being prepared and sent to either branch of Congress; but it rouses his wrath to have any notice taken of these documents when received, or to hear any attempt made towards explaining them on the part of the Senators or other representatives to whom they have been intrusted for presentation. In the opinion of Senator JOHNSON, of Arkansas, our citizens "might as well sing psalms to a dead horse," as spend their time in submitting petitions to the honorable body of which he is so distinguished a member -- no matter from what quarter said popular petitions may emanate -- no matter how numerously or influentially they may be signed.

abstract: During the evening, Mr. LINCOLN was waited upon by delegations from the Electoral College; from Kings County, headed by Mayor POWELL; from the various Clubs of New-York doing service in the Republican cause; and by a host of friends. At 9 o'clock, the order was given to let all out and nobody in, and shortly after Mr. LINCOLN was left to the bent of his private inclinations.

abstract: J. Brice Smith, Appellant, vs. Wells, Fargo & Co.'s Express Company. -- This action was originally brought in the Marine Court of this City, for the purpose of recovering the dividend upon a certain certificate of stock which the plaintiff had in his possession. The plaintiff claims that he was entitled to ten shares in the stock of the said Joint Stock Company; and that on or about the 2d day of August, 1860, the defendants declared a dividend of five per cent, upon their capital stock. That when he demanded his share of the dividend so declared, he was refused payment. on the ground that be was not the owner of the stock. On the trial of this cause, the plaintiff testified, that in May last, he purchased of Thomas G. Coleman, a broker in Wall-street, and that such broker, then and there, produced a certificate or Irving A. Simmons, and a power of attorney for the shares, with a blank for the name of the transferee and attorney. This certificate the plaintiff took to the office of defendant to make inquiry respecting it, and was there told that it was all right. He then went to Coleman and told him that it was all right, he would take the stock. It appears, however, from the evidence of J.H. Wells, that this stock originally belonged to him, and he alleges that thecertificates therefor were stolen from his office; that as soon as he missed them he went directly to the office of the Company where he found that his certificate had been surrendered and a new certificate issued to living N. Simmons, which certificate had also been surrendered and another issued in lieu to the plaintiff. The Court found, on the trial of this cause, for the defendant. An appeal was therefore brought to this Court, and now comes on to be heard. This Court decides, that as there was sufficient evidence to warrant the Court below in believing that such certificates were stolen, the judgment will not be disturbed -- as even a bona fide holder of stolen property can have no title to it as against the rightful owner.
lead_paragraph: J. abstract: The news contained in our Mexican correspondence and the official documents of the Constitutional Government, which appear in the TIMES this morning, are of very great interest and importance, as indicating the quiet, dignified and successful manner in which the Juarez Government is establishing its authority and power in the capital of the Mexican Republic,' and restoring the country to tranquility, that the people may enjoy the prosperity and happiness which for centuries, we may say, have been denied to them.

abstract: Ex-Gov. Wise is determined to distinguish himself in the Virginia Convention.
lead_paragraph: Ex-Gov. Wise is determined to distinguish himself in the Virginia Convention. On the 16th he had quite a spirited altercation with Mr. MOORE, of Rockbridge, a conservative delegate. In reply to some conciliatory remarks made by the latter, the doughty Governor declared that he would have his own way first or last, "so help me God," and that way he defined to be to fight the real Disunionists, whom he did not think were the statesmen in the South who had been driven to do what some called wrong. The Republicans and Abolitionists are the real Disunionists, and they, exclaimed the Governor, are marching on the Capital. He implored Virginians not to wrangle among themselves, if they did cheap lands would lie open in the State for the Goths and Vandals of New-England to rush down and occupy. He had been accustomed to hear the sunrise gun at Fortress Monroe, when peace dwelt upon their shores and smiled within their homes. Now at every hour of the day he heard the booming thunder of practicing artillery -- practicing artillery for excellence to drink their blood. Before long, said he, they might expect to have a Black Republican garrison at Gosport to rob their hen-roosts and steal their peculiar institutions. In reaching this climax the Governor had so wrought himself up that his gestures assumed rather a personal direction, in the opinion of Mr. MOORE, so that gentleman requested him not to be quite so fierce, as he did not admire that style of gesture. This had the effect of modifying Gov. WISE'S enthusiasm, and he proceeded to explain his position with less emphasis. Mr. MOORE followed in a few conciliatory remarks, and, if the reports be not impartial, rather got the better of his fiery antagonist.

abstract: While the merchants and importers of Kentucky, Tennessee, Missouri, Arkansas and the Great West, are quite willing to continue the payment of duties to the United States on goods sent direct from foreign countries up the mouths of the Mississippi River, it is ...
lead_paragraph: While the merchants and importers of Kentucky, Tennessee, Missouri, Arkansas and the Great West, are quite willing to continue the payment of duties to the United States on goods sent direct from foreign countries up the mouths of the Mississippi River, -- it is quite a different thing for them to find these goods taxed in transitu at the New-Orleans Custom-house, and the proceeds of such revenue collections applied to the maintenance of the revolutionary, secession Government now in control of the State of Louisiana. Such collections of revenue under the laws and for the exclusive benefit of the Pelican State, are clearly an interference with the free navigation of the Mississippi River, and practically amount to a tax levied by the State of Louisiana, solitary and alone, upon all the foreign commerce of the Mississippi Valley.

abstract: George C. Jordan, plaintiff, vs. Laura Keene, defendant. -- Two actions, which were brought by the plaintiff against the defendant, in the Marine Court of this City, and on the trial of which a judgment was rendered for the plaintiff, now come before this Court upon appeal, by the defendant. The first action was brought to recover $200, alleged to be due for two weeks' salary, ending on the 24th of December, 1859. The second action was for one week's salary, due Jan. 7, 1860.

abstract: Conrad Schleig vs. John Harrington and Ellen Kent. -- An application was this morning made for a perpetual injunction against the defendants to restrain them from using the premises known as No. 39 First-street, in this City, as a slaughter-house. Several witnesses have been examined who testify that quantities of offal were cast into the alley-way and yard of the said slaughter-house, in a very offensive state, ad that the place was kept in an offensive condition; that some two hundred sheep have been slaughtered there daily, including Sundays, and at all seasons of the year. The case is still on.

abstract: Gorham D. Abbott vs. The American Hard-Rubber Company, William Judson et al. -- This was an appeal on the part of the defendants from an order made by Judge SUTHERLAND, granting an injunction and appointing a receiver in the above entitled action, concerning certain property and patent rights, sold by the Rubber Company to Popenhusen and Konig, two other defendants, in February, 1860, for the sum of $120,600. The plaintiff, a stockholder, claims that this sale was void as against him to the amount of $62,000; that by the laws of Connecticut, under which the defendants were organized, such sale was invalid, unless with his assent, and that such sale was made with intent of destroying the value of his stock. The defendants, however, claim that the business was unprofitable; that the Company had always been on the verge of insolvency, and that the sale was made to liquidate pressing debts, and was so done as well for the benefit of stockholders, and that the sale was made with the assent of all the stockholders except the plaintiff. Decision reserved.
lead_paragraph: Gorham D. Abbott vs. The American Hard-Rubber Company, William Judson et al. -- This was an appeal on the part of the defendants from an order made by Judge SUTHERLAND, granting an injunction and appointing a receiver in the above entitled action, concerning certain property and patent rights, sold by the Rubber Company to Popenhusen and Konig, two other defendants, in February, 1860, for the sum of $120,600. The plaintiff, a stockholder, claims that this sale was void as against him to the amount of $62,000; that by the laws of Connecticut, under which the defendants were organized, such sale was invalid, unless with his assent, and that such sale was made with intent of destroying the value of his stock. The defendants, however, claim that the business was unprofitable; that the Company had always been on the verge of insolvency, and that the sale was made to liquidate pressing debts, and was so done as well for the benefit of stockholders, and that the sale was made with the assent of all the stockholders except the plaintiff. Decision reserved.

abstract: Great excitement was created, yesterday, in City Hall circles, by the report that the Board of Aldermen, at its session, this evening, will remove Capt. G.W. SMITH from the office of Street Commissioner, and confirm in his stead Judge CAPERS, of Queen's County, now holding a subordinate position in the Custom house. This removal of Capt. SMITH -- an accomplished engineer officer, and the very best Street Commissioner our City ever had -- and the appointment in his stead of a gentleman having no knowledge of, or experience in, the business to be transacted, will prove a fit following up of the late monstrous contract for cleaning the streets of our City, and will, doubtless, be actuated by similar motives. Should the Street Commissioner be carried off under the new Aldermanic storm that is brewing, the City Inspector's official life will not be worth many days' purchase; nor will the Croton Board be long allowed to remain under is present dynasty. The "inducements" offered for these contemplated changes are said to be very large; but as the Legislature is still in session, our tax-payers may congratulate themselves that they are still not left without promise of a sufficing remedy. The admirable working of the Commission of Charities and Correction, furnishes an example to which we must look for an abatement of the evils consequent on Aldermanic control of the City Departments.
lead_paragraph: Great excitement was created, yesterday, in City Hall circles, by the report that the Board of Aldermen, at its session, this evening, will remove Capt. G.W. Should the Street Commissioner be carried off under the new Aldermanic storm that is brewing, the City Inspector's official life will not be worth many days' purchase; nor will the Croton Board be long allowed to remain under is present dynasty. The "inducements" offered for these contemplated changes are said to be very large; but as the Legislature is still in session, our tax-payers may congratulate themselves that they are still not left without promise of a sufficing remedy. The admirable working of the Commission of Charities and Correction, furnishes an example to which we must look for an abatement of the evils consequent on Aldermanic control of the City Departments.

abstract: Greatly as the country stands indebted to such men as Senator JOHNSON and EMERSON ETHERIDGE, of Tennessee; SHERRARD CLEM ENS, of Virginia; Col. FLOURNOY, of Arkansas;
lead_paragraph: Greatly as the country stands indebted to such men as Senator JOHNSON and EMERSON ETHERIDGE, of Tennessee; SHERRARD CLEMENS, of Virginia; Col. FLOURNOY, of Arkansas; REVERDY JOHNSON, of Maryland; Gov. MOOREHEAD, of Kentucky, and the many other single-minded and devoted patriots who have successfully battled for the Union in the late Convention elections, there is yet a gentleman with higher claims upon the esteem and gratitude of all lovers of the Union -- all men who are anxious to see the Constitution respected and restored to its normal supremacy without resort to violence and the shedding of fraternal blood. We refer to Hon. JOHN E. BOULIGNY, of Louisiana, the only Representative from a seceded State who has had the moral and physical courage to repudiate the revolutionary action of his State Convention, and to maintain his seat in Congress despite all the threats that were hurled in advance against any Representative who should so dare to act.

abstract: There was not a quorum of the Commissioners of Emigration present yesterday. The weekly report showed the number of emigrants arrived during the present year to have been 3,476. The number arrived during the same time last year was 3,092. The number of inmates in the various institutions at present is 1,243. The balance of the commutation fund in bank is $3,627,82. The Board will have a special meeting on Friday.

abstract: The regular monthly meeting of the Young Men's Republican Central Committee was held last evening at No. 618 Broadway, Mr. STEWART L. WOODFORD, the President, in the Chair. The Committee on By-Laws made a report which was received and laid over for consideration at a special meeting to be convened for the purpose. Some other routine business was transacted, and it was then voted to wait on HANNIBAL HAMLIN. Vice-President elect, and tender him their congratulations, and the Committee adjourned for that agreeable duty.

abstract: A special dispatch from Charleston to the Augusta (Ga.) Constitutionalist, date Jan. 12, states that a report was current in the former city that soon after Lieut. HALL (Maj. ANDERSON'S...
lead_paragraph: A special dispatch from Charleston to the Augusta (Ga.) Constitutionalist, date Jan. 12, states that a report was current in the former city that soon after Lieut. HALL (Maj. ANDERSON's messenger to Washington) returned to Fort Sumter, Maj. ANDERSON sent a communication to Gov. PICKENS, stating that he expected reinforcements in a few days, and notifying the Governor at the same time that if the vessel bringing them was fired upon, he would return the fire on the forts.

abstract: The reception of Mr. LINCOLN at the City Hall, yesterday, was a most flattering testimonial of respect to the elect Chief of the Nation.
lead_paragraph: The reception of Mr. LINCOLN at the City Hall, yesterday, was a most flattering testimonial of respect to the elect Chief of the Nation. Mayor WOOD, in a short speech, welcomed the President, and hoped he would prove equal to the crisis, and Mr. LINCOLN replied, modestly, wishing he could bring as good a head as heart to the work, and expressing his devotion to the Union. About six thousand citizens were admitted to the Governor's room, and either shook hands with or bowed to Mr. LINCOLN. The crowd seemed to be still almost as great as ever, so that after two hours the doors were closed, and Mr. LINCOLN made a brief address from the balcony. The Police arrangements were excellent. In the evening, Mr. and Mrs. LINCOLN visited the opera, and subsequently Mrs. LINCOLN had a reception at the Astor House. The Presidential party will leave the City this morning.

abstract: It seldom happens at the present day that we realize the existence of those clerical knights who nurse in cloisters and studies their religion, until it becomes something as near and dear as the Virgin Mary was of old to the members of the Church militant. One of these extraordinary cases has, however, of late occurred in England, in the person of Rev. J. SUMNER BROOKHURST, of Emmanuel College -- a gentleman whose singular zeal has at least had the effect of conferring upon him a three days' notoriety of the most extensive description. Rev. Mr. BROCKHURST, a man of known piety, suddenly astonished the University world in which he dwelt by a violent personal assault, seasoned with horsewhipping, upon Rev. EDWARD DODD, Fellow of Magdalen College and Vicar of St. Giles, Cambridge. When duly arraigned before the College Court, Mr. BROCKHURST not only avowed the assault, but gloried in it, giving it as his reason and defence that the reverend DODD had in asking a grace, omitted from it the name of Jesus Christ, so that the blessing might without offence include a Jew who was present. "For," said Mr. BROCKHURST, "as any gentleman would have acted in this manner if the honor of his wife or daughter had been brought into question, how much more reason had I for acting as I did when my Lord and Saviour was insulted." And, full of enthusiasm, he forthwith attacked the too liberal DODD, inflicting upon him a chastisement which certainly ought to have the effect of making him both gracious and grace-ful in his graces from this time, ad finem.
lead_paragraph: It seldom happens at the present day that we realize the existence of those clerical knights who nurse in cloisters and studies their religion, until it becomes something as near and dear as the Virgin Mary was of old to the members of the Church militant. SUMNER BROOKHURST, of Emmanuel College -- a gentleman whose singular zeal has at least had the effect of conferring upon him a three days' notoriety of the most extensive description. Rev. EDWARD DODD, Fellow of Magdalen College and Vicar of St. Giles, Cambridge. When duly arraigned before the College Court, Mr. BROCKHURST not only avowed the assault, but gloried in it, giving it as his reason and defence that the reverend DODD had in asking a grace, omitted from it the name of Jesus Christ, so that the blessing might without offence include a Jew who was present. "For," said Mr. BROCKHURST, "as any gentleman would have acted in this manner if the honor of his wife or daughter had been brought into question, how much more reason had I for acting as I did when my Lord and Saviour was insulted." And, full of enthusiasm, he forthwith attacked the too liberal DODD, inflicting upon him a chastisement which certainly ought to have the effect of making him both gracious and grace-ful in his graces from this time, ad finem.

abstract: John D. Phillips Co. vs. Russel Benedict Ethel J. Farnam. This was an appeal by the defendants from the order of Judge INGRAHAM, denying the application of the defendant Benedict for a discharge of the order of arrest under which he was held to bail in $6,000.
lead_paragraph: John D. Phillips & Co. vs. Russel Benedict & Ethel J. Farnam. This was an appeal by the defendants from the order of Judge INGRAHAM, denying the application of the defendant Benedict for a discharge of the order of arrest under which he was held to bail in $6,000. It was claimed on the part of the plaintiffs that the defendants' firm, in the year 1857, owed to creditors in New-York, for goods purchased for their Chicago store, $200,000; that subsequently an extension, then a compromise for 50 cents on the dollar, and then another extension, had been granted to the defendants and that the defendants had, in September, 1859, after buying what goods they could in August, 1859, on representations of their perfect ability to pay, made a pretended sale of all their stock of goods, and then subsequently set up that they were unable to pay 37 1/2 cents on the dollar of the compromise, and had never as yet paid anything to their New-York creditors, among whom were the plaintiffs to the amount of $15,000.

abstract: Mr. FENTON, of New-York, has introduced into Congress a resolution for a National Convention to revise and amend the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: Mr. FENTON, of New-York, has introduced into Congress a resolution for a National Convention to revise and amend the Constitution. This is intended to provide for the existing discontents. The present Constitution having failed to satisfy the people of all sections, and preserve the "more perfect Union" which it was intended to form, the people are summoned to make a new one which shall better fulfill those conditions.

abstract: In the late grumble of the Charleston Mercury at the proceedings of the Montgomery Convention, great sorrow was expressed that that body had been so "short-sighted, weak and sentimental as to reject a policy" that may become essential to our successful competition with the hypocritical nations of Europe." These hypocrites -- England and France are the special Tartuffes in question -- import, it seems, thousands of coolies and black apprentices, while the South, it is urged, has, in addition to much unoccupied real estate, the prospective "silver mines of Arizona and the teeming States of Mexico to populate."

abstract: The Tribune, the other day, denounced the proposition of Mr. ADAMS to pass an enabling act for New Mexico, as a base surrender to Slavery. The reason it gave for this position was that it was a "distinguishing principle of the Republican Party, that Slavery shall never be permitted to extend the length of a man's shadow at noon-day over the border line between the Territories and the States."

abstract: Gustav Lindenmuller vs. The People -- This action, which was some time since tried in the Oyer and Terminer, and which resulted in the conviction of Lindenmuller for a violation of the Sunday laws, now comes before this Court on a writ of error. It is contended by the plaintiff's counsel that the act of April 17,1860, is unconstitutional and void, it being a violation of section 6, article 1, of the Constitution of this State, which provides that "No person shall be deprived of life, liberty or property without due process of law." It is contended that the effect of this law is to deprive the citizen of his property without such process, and that the Question is one of legislative authority. This case was fully reported at the time of the trial. It is the leading case upon which the constitutionality of the Sunday act of 1860 is to be tested.
lead_paragraph: Gustav Lindenmuller vs. The People -- This action, which was some time since tried in the Oyer and Terminer, and which resulted in the conviction of Lindenmuller for a violation of the Sunday laws, now comes before this Court on a writ of error. This case was fully reported at the time of the trial. It is the leading case upon which the constitutionality of the Sunday act of 1860 is to be tested.

abstract: The general reply to all propositions for conciliation has been, "We cannot compromise with traitors."
lead_paragraph: The general reply to all propositions for conciliation has been, "We cannot compromise with traitors." It was assumed that the whole South had resolved to repudiate the General Government, and it seems useless as well as degrading to offer terms to men who had decided in advance upon their rejection.

abstract: An inquest was held, yesterday, upon the body of James Hogan, late an employe of Messrs. Lord & Taylor, who died from injuries received at their establishment a few days ago. It appears that he was leaning over the railing around the hoistway, when the elevating platform descended rather rapidly, and struck him upon the head, causing fatal injuries. A verdict of "Accidental Death" was rendered.

abstract: Every country has, like every individual, what the French call a bete noir a black haunting bugbear which, takes a sort of memento mori glory out of its triumphs. Ours in America is with fearful literalness, black enough in every respect for it is the Irrepressible Negro. But John Bull's is called Reform, and is seen in different shapes and shades, the most provoking of all being that which just now afflicts him as Retrenchment.
lead_paragraph: Every country has, like every individual, what the French call a bete noir -- a black haunting bugbear -- which, takes a sort of memento mori glory out of its triumphs. Ours in America is with fearful literalness, black enough in every respect for it is the Irrepressible Negro. But John Bull's is called Reform, and is seen in different shapes and shades, the most provoking of all being that which just now afflicts him as Retrenchment.

abstract: Mr. J.A. BROWN, recently a professor in an institution of learning at Newberry, S.C., publishes a card in the Philadelphia Press, in reply to one from a "Lutheran Pastor," denying that he was obliged to resign his position, in consequence of threats made against him, because of his Northern sentiments. Mr. BROWN affirms most positively that he was threatened with a coat of tar and feathers; that he offered to remain in Newberry if his friends would sustain him; that they refused to do so, and that he was eventually obliged to come North with out twenty-four hours' notice.

abstract: The official correspondence of Senator CLAY, of Alabama, and Hon. THOS. J. JUDGE, Commissioner from that State to Washington with President BUCHANAN, has been published. In No.1 Senator CLAY notifies Mr. BUCHANAN OF Mr. JUDGE'S arrival, and states that the object of his mission is to treat with reference to the forts, arsenals and Custom-houses in Alabama. Mr. BUCHANAN on the ...
lead_paragraph: The official correspondence of Senator CLAY, of Alabama, and Hon. THOS. J. JUDGE, Commissioner from that State to Washington with President BUCHANAN, has been published. In No.1 Senator CLAY notifies Mr. BUCHANAN OF Mr. JUDGE's arrival, and states that the object of his mission is to treat with reference to the forts, arsenals and Custom-houses in Alabama. Mr. BUCHANAN on the day succeeding the receipt of this note, Feb. 2, wrote to Senator CLAY declining to receive Mr. JUDGE save as a distinguished citizen, and then Mr. CLAY forwarded a letter addressed to him by Mr. JUDGE. That gentleman assumed that the President, by refusing to recognize him as a Commissioner, had abandoned all claim to the United States property in Alabama, or that repelling an offer of peaceful settlement, he had determined to retake it by force. Whichever of these positions the President had taken, Mr. JUDGE felt it to be his duty to return home, inform Governor MOORE of the result of his mission and let negotiations be reopened by the United States Government, if they were reopened at all. Mr. CLAY concludes the correspondence with a letter to the President, expressing surprise that he should not have referred the subject to Congress rather than have taken the responsibility upon himself of rejecting these peaceful overtures. He vindicates the course of Gov. MOORE in seizing the forts, assures Mr. BUCHANAN that the men of the South will not long endure the menace involved in the retention by the Government of Forts Sumter, Pickens and McHenry, but will take them at every hazard and at any sacrifice if they are not soon surrendered; asserts that the idea of a reconstruction of the Union is preposterous and the hope groundless, since the two sections are at variance in morals, manners, religion and politics, as well as in social institutions and habits; and in conclusion advises President BUCHANAN to give heed no longer to the counsel "of a superannuated soldier, whose vanity and ignorance have never failed to provoke contempt whenever he essayed to play the statesman," or to those of "a mere jurist and scholar who has lived a recluse, and knows less of living and feeling men than of dead languages and abstract sciences."

abstract: There is not the slightest doubt that, in its origin and its political aspect, the pesent crisis is what Mr. LINCOLN styled it, an artificial one, got up by demagogues for selfish and partisan purposes. It has now grown to dimensions which render it far more formidable than it seemed likely to become at the outset, and the dangers it involves demand a graver treatment than its intrinsic' character deserves.
lead_paragraph: There is not the slightest doubt that, in its origin and its political aspect, the pesent crisis is what Mr. LINCOLN styled it, an artificial one, got up by demagogues for selfish and partisan purposes. It has now grown to dimensions which render it far more formidable than it seemed likely to become at the outset, and the dangers it involves demand a graver treatment than its intrinsic' character deserves. But it began and was nursed into its present proportions by the extravagant demands which the South has made upon the North. Those demands have increased year by year during a quarter of a century; and in proportion as the Slave interest becomes relatively weaker in the national councils its spirit becomes more haughty, and its exactions more unreasonable and inadmissible.

abstract: WASHINGTON's BIRTHDAY. -- No very extensive arrangements have been made to celebrate WASHINGTON's Birthday in this City. A ball, a short military parade and a turn out of the O.U.A.'s is all that has been announced for the Western District. In the Eastern District the farewell address of WASHINGTON will be read at the Odeon, and several national airs will be sung by a volunteer choir, and an address will be delivered by C.R. MILLER, after which a collection will be taken up for the benefit of the wives or the soldiers now in Fort Sumter. The usual patriotic exercises in commemoration of WASHINGTON's Birthday took place in several of the Public Schools yesterday -- when spirited addresses were made and patriotic songs were sung.

abstract: The Republic of St. Patrick was inaugurated last evening with great enthusiasm at the Astor House, -- RICHARD BELL, Esq., being its Provisional President, with Messrs. JAMES STUART and DANIEL DEVLIN as its Secretaries pro tem. This temporary organization, however, was soon made permanent by the election of T.F. MEAGHER to the office of President, DANIEL DEVLIN his Vice, Judge O'CONOR to the Lord Chief Justiceship of the Court of No-Appeals, JOHN B. FOGARTY to the Attorney-Generalship, and JAMES STUART to the office of Post Laureate. Telegraphic dispatches announcing the secession of Connaught, Ulster, Munster and Leinster from the main body of the Republic were received; but it was resolved that no notice should be taken of these irregular proceedings. Mr. CHARLES STETSON, as Ambassador from the Republic of the United States, was very cordially received, and discharged his functions in that capacity most diplomatically -- while in his office as Commissary-General displaying even more than his usual taste and liberality. Excellent and very humorous speeches were made -- some capital ballads given by Dr. CARMICHAEL, and the whole affair passed off to the high satisfaction of those interested. Several similar meetings will be required before due selections can be made for the important trusts of the Society during the ensuing year. Mr. BOYLE, we should add, though formerly an Engineer and City Surveyor, was elected to the office of Archbishop of the new Republic, or some other post not exactly specified, destined to make him a moral exemplar to the rising generation of Irishmen.

abstract: The United States vs. The Mark Kate and her cargo. -- This was a libel filed to forfeit the bark and her cargo, on the ground that she was fitted out with, the intent to engage her in the Slave-trade. The libel was filed Oct. 1, 1860. On the 3d of July previous, a libel had been filed against her and her cargo, claiming her forfeiture on the same ground. On the 6th of July, Charles P. Lake intervened in that action, and filed a claim to the vessel as owner, and to the cargo as common carrier thereof. On the 12th of July, the libelants excepted to his right to intervene, and nothing further was done with that issue, which still remains undisposed of on the record. Subsequently the claimant in that case gave bonds for the the vessel and cargo, which were thereupon discharged from custody, and the vessel remained in this port till this libel was filed, claiming her forfeiture a second time. Mr. Lake again intervened as claimant of the vessel as owner, and of the cargo as common carrier thereof, and filed an answer taking a general issue to the allegations of the libel.

abstract: AN IMPORTANT IMPROVEMENT. The new and magnificent buildings recently erected in Greenestreet, in this City, by our enterprising fellow-citizen, Mr. H.J. HOWARD, is certainty the chief architectural pride of that active business locality. With the shrewdness of well-informed business men, TROW and ...
lead_paragraph: AN IMPORTANT IMPROVEMENT. -- The new and magnificent buildings recently erected in Greenestreet, in this City, by our enterprising fellow-citizen, Mr. H.J. HOWARD, is certainty the chief architectural pride of that active business locality. With the shrewdness of well-informed business men, TROW and others have established their printing and other business in a portion of the building, and is there as none so eligible in the whole street, it will not be surprising if their example be followed by others who are desirous of locating themselves in time in a district of New-York destined to become at no distant day, famous for its expensive manufactures. To those who have known Greene-street in former years, the change which has taken place in its appearance must appear little less than the work of magic. Where small buildings formerly stood, having no attractions whatever, there now loom up fine structures, embellished with all the skill of mechanical art, and affording to merchants and manufacturers advantages which can nowhere be surpassed. Greene-street will, in fact, shortly become a street of merchant palaces, in the same way as other parts of the City have been already transformed.

abstract: Mr. LINCOLN quietly left the Astor House yesterday morning shortly after 8 o'clock, and without formal adieu left for Washington via Jersey City. He was met on the boat by a deputation from the Jersey City Common Council, and welcomed by Alderman HARDENBERGH. The vast depot was ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. LINCOLN quietly left the Astor House yesterday morning shortly after 8 o'clock, and without formal adieu left for Washington via Jersey City. He was met on the boat by a deputation from the Jersey City Common Council, and welcomed by Alderman HARDENBERGH. The vast depot was crowded to excess, and resounded with cheers as Mayor VAN VORST received Mr. LINCOLN on behalf of the city, and Hon. WM. L. DAYTON received him on behalf of the State. Mr. LINCOLN received the ovation with becoming modesty, and spoke briefly as usual. The Jersey police were utterly incapable of protecting the President from the pressure of the crowd. The train started at exactly half-past nine for Newark, at which place also his reception was enthusiastic, though his stay was necessarily short. At Trenton he visited the State-house, and made speeches before the Senate and House -- the latter of which, especially, was significant and important. It was the longest which he has yet made, and contained allusions to the national troubles, which called out the most decided demonstrations of approbation. The Presidential party reached Philadelphia at 4 o'clock P.M., and was escorted in procession to the Continental Hotel, where Mr. LINCOLN was introduced to the people by the Mayor, and made a brief speech.

abstract: The Vice-President-elect remained at the Astor House yesterday, and was visited by a number of personal friends. It was erroneously supposed that Mr. HAMLIN would accompany the Presidential party, and repeated calls were made for him at the Jersey City Depot. He remained, however, in the City, and will leave for Washington to day -- probably overtaking Mr. LINCOLN en route. Immediately after the departure of Mr. LINCOLN, Mr. HAMLIN was ensconced in parlors Nos. 39 and 41. Among others who called were Col. FREMONT and THURLOW WEED.

abstract: Elisabeth Dietz vs. Frederick Dietz. -- In this case the plaintiff originally brought an action for divorce against the defendant, charging him with extreme cruelty, and obtained an allowance of alimony in the sum of $2 per week pending the result of the action. When the suit was tried the plaintiff was unable to show more than one instance of cruelty, and the Court (Justice MONCRIEF, of the Superior Court,) held that one act of cruelty was not sufficient to constitute a cause for divorce, and rendered judgment for the defendant. The plaintiff then offered to live with the defendant, but he refused to allow her to do so, and also refused to pay the $2 per week alimony. The plaintiff then entered a complaint against the defendant for abandonment, and upon that charge caused him to be locked up in the Tombs. Justice STEERS giving him the alternative -- go to the lock-up or pay $3 per week to his with for her support -- for which latter performance, bends were required. Defendant went to the Tombs, and this was a writ of habeas corpus, seeking to discharge him.

abstract: From the reports of the proceedings of the two Boards of the Common Council, published elsewhere, it will be seen that the combination of interests, by which it was proposed to capture the Street Department last evening, has thus far failed of its mission.
lead_paragraph: From the reports of the proceedings of the two Boards of the Common Council, published elsewhere, it will be seen that the combination of interests, by which it was proposed to capture the Street Department last evening, has thus far failed of its mission. The Board of Aldermen met amidst the most intense excitement, all the lobbies and corridors of the City Hall being densely packed for an hour in advance of the appointed time of meeting. It soon became whispered about, however, that the new Custom-house combination had not its expected strength -- that some of the men whose votes were necessary, had either never really "gone in," or had found it prudent to retire at as early a moment as possible, in view of the dangers threatening them. Certain it is, that the battle was declined on behalf of the Capers Party, who found in the lamented death of Ex-Mayor LAWRENCE an admirable pretext for postponing the fell issue of combat to another day. The Queen's County men, nevertheless, have not abandoned hope of securing the prize originally contemplated, -- its prospective rewards being large enough to justify very extensive operations, in the politico-financial line; and the certain sacrifice of patronage being fully compensated -- so far, at least, as those who will have to vote on the question are concerned, -- by the liberal arrangements understood to be promised in certain experienced quarters.

abstract: The Peace Conference, after a stormy debate, fixed upon 1 o'clock to-morrow as the time to commence voting, but another effort will probably be made to postpone the vote until Monday, in consequence of the absence of some of the delegates. The general impression among the Commissioners to-night is that something like the old Missouri Compromise will be adopted by one majority.

abstract: Sir JAMES EMERSON TENNANT, stimulated no doubt, by the extraordinary success of his "Ceylon," has in press a partially new work, an enlargement, in fact, of one of the departments treated of in that encyclopedic view of the Island. It is called " The Natural History of Ceylon, with Anecdotes Illustrative of the Habits and Instincts...
lead_paragraph: -- Sir JAMES EMERSON TENNANT, stimulated no doubt, by the extraordinary success of his "Ceylon," has in press a partially new work, an enlargement, in fact, of one of the departments treated of in that encyclopedic view of the Island. It is called " The Natural History of Ceylon, with Anecdotes Illustrative of the Habits and Instincts of the Mammalia, Birds, Reptiles, Fishes, and Insects of that Island, with a Monograph of the Elephant, and description of the modes of catching and taming him, with Copious Additions and Now Illustrations from Original Drawings." It will be published by Messrs. LONGMAN & CO., during the coming Spring, and will command a popularity of the most extensive character, judging from the numerous editions which have been demanded of the prior larger and somewhat cumbersome book.

abstract: Chas. Whelpley, residing at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, was arrested on Thursday, by officer Holland, of the Lower Police Court, charged with having forged the name of Dr. Thos. Tumblety, residing at the same hotel to a check for $400 on the Chemical Bank, and crawing the money for the same. The accused, it appears, filled up a check for $100 at the request of Dr. Tumblety, which check that gentleman signed and got cashed. Three days afterwards the accused, as alleged, drew up a check for $100, forged the name of Mr. T. to it and got the money. The hand-writing in both checks is very similar, and the signature is an imitation of the genuine. This is all the proof that appears thus far against the accused. He was taken before Justice OSBORN, and locked up to await examination.

abstract: Bright and early yesterday morning Mr. LINCOLN arose, and rapidly disposed of his early callers, his TIMES and his breakfast, for he was to start en route at 8.15. It was deemed necessary to depart from the original programme in order to avoid interference. Mrs. LINCOLN and children reached the special train by a private conveyance.

abstract: The City authorities have made no arrangement for the observance of the day which gave us WASHINGTON. It is probable, therefore, that the celebration in the Metropolis will be conducted with unusual spirit and propriety. Aside from this, recent public events, which all remind us of the wisdom and the teachings of the Father of his Country, and of the want of such a man in these soul-trying times, will call forth in all parts of the country which are loyal to the nationality that he founded an expression of reverence for his hallowed memory far more general and hearty than in the piping periods of past prosperity, has been customary. In this City the feature of the day's proceedings will be the military parade, which bids fair to be the largest and finest that the First Division has made in many a day. Business is dull and clerks can be spared from the stores, as they could not have been at this season but for he coming of the crisis, and those of them who are of the uniformed militia will for the most part be in the ranks. Business men generally who are soldiers will have nothing to deter them from parading. The Division line will be formed in Fourteenth-street, the right resting on Broadway, at 2 P.M. and Gov. MORGAN and staff will review the troops at a quarter part 2 o'clock. This over the column will march down Broadway, around the lower end of the Park, up Chatham street, and through the east gate into the Park, where in front of the City Hall at 3 1/2 P.M., the Mayor and Common Council will be honored with a marching salute. A salute of five hundred guns will be fired from the Battery at noon. In the evening several Associations will celebrate the occasion with bells, suppers, and in listening to addresses. "Washington Chapter No. 2 of the Order of United Americans will give a grand ball; so will the "Washington Association," and the Young Men's Democratic Union Club. An oration on the "Character of Washington." will be delivered at Niblo's Garden in the afternoon, by Hon. J. MORRISON HARRIS, of Maryland. Ex-Judge EDMONDS will deliver an address before the Republican Central Committee, at Hope Chapel, in the evening. The second annual reception of the Eighth Regiment, Washington Grays, will take place in the evening, at the armory of the corps. The splendid portrait of WASHINGTON, by REMBRANDT PEALE, will be formally presented to the Seventh Regiment, at its armory, in the evening. The Courts will not be in session, and most of the public offices and many private places of business will be closed.

abstract: At 10 o'clock, yesterday morning, I had the honor of witnessing the inauguration of our State Government. Gov. ROBINSON and two of the District Judges were sworn in at that time, and, believe me, it was a sweet sound to my ears to hear them pledge themselves to support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Kansas.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE, Sunday, Feb. 10, 1861.

abstract: -- The New-York correspondent of the New-Orleans Delta states that Lola Montez's last love was a young man named Follen, whom she picked up in San Francisco, and took to Australia. He had two girls under his charge, and bearing his name. Who they were no one knows. They could not have been his daughters, unless he married at the early age of ten. Lola and Follen quarreled like cat and dog, and he committed suicide, they say, in order to get rid of her. This was in 1856. Lola returned to the United States in 1857-'58, with the girls. She called the elder one Minnie Montez, and, as she was very pretty, put her on the stage, and made money by the operation. More than two years ago, this girl was married, not to an officer of the Navy, but to a gentleman who was once our Minister to Nicaragua. So there could have been precious little education for her at a seminary in Troy, as the story goes, where the term is four years! Lola did tell her doctor that Minnie -- had cut her, and that she had had hysterics and smoked a great deal too much in consequence. Probably the romantic incident which the Philadelphia Press started on its travels some weeks since originated in these facts.

abstract: On Thursday night, Mr. John Labaste, a Frenchman, keeping a wine-cellar at No. 193 Fulton-strset, made an attempt to stab Mr. August Sherman, of No. 166 William-street, with a small sword or dirk, but was prevented by the by the bystanders, and arrested by Officer Black, of the Second Ward. Labaste had been transacting some business with Mr. Sherman, at the store of the latter, and a difference arising with reference to it, he lost control of himself, and rushed upon his opponent with the weapon. Justice OSBORE yesterday held him in bail for trial.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, William Robinson, previously convieted of forgery in the second degree, was sentenced to the Penitentiary for five years. The Court, in passing sentence, expressed its regret that a young man of such good character as the prisoner had previously borne, should be brought into such a position. To save him from the infamy of a State Prison confinement, the Penitentiary had been substituted instead.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The seventh performance of VERDI's "Masquerade Ball," last evening, attracted a fine audience. The artists were in capital voice, the orchestra admirable, the chorus all that could be desired. It generally happens, in this country, that when a work is in the best trim for enjoyability and the certainty of execution, it is withdrawn, and so it will astonish no one to hear that the "Masquerade Ball" is to be given but once more -- on Monday next. Before the opera commenced, the orchestra played the national anthem, "Hail Columbia," and subsequently the artists sung "The Star Spangled Banner" beneath a magnificent specimen of the same, which descended opportunely from the skies. There was much excitement, and the song was repeated.

abstract: In 1811, when the late Nestor of the medical profession, Dr. JOHN W. FRANCIS, received the degree of M.D. from the College of Physicians and Surgeons, the state of medical science was such that the President of the L.I. College stated, at its opening session, "that the Professors of the Institution enjoyed less advantages at that time during the whole course of study than was at the command of the student now in a single day." In spite of these increasing advantages, it has often been thought that physicians wrangled, as of old, over technicalities, contended for priority among each other, and urged a favorite theory, while the patient died ere the consultation was at an end.

abstract: Hon. THOMAS D. ELIOT, of Massachusetts, publishes an address to his constituents in the Boston papers. From the very nature of the compromises which have thus far been proposed he says he can support none of them.
lead_paragraph: Hon. THOMAS D. ELIOT, of Massachusetts, publishes an address to his constituents in the Boston papers. From the very nature of the compromises which have thus far been proposed he says he can support none of them. All involve some surrender of principle; all are concessions without any equivalent; they are asked for by the order States as a condition of remaining in the Union, which their obligations to the Constitution oblige them to do in any event, and a preliminary which is uniformly insisted on is that the Government shall not attempt to enforce the laws in the States which have already seceded. To this Mr. ELIOT says he can never consent. A firm adherence to the principles of our present Constitution he believes will restore to us a more perfect Union, establish justice and insure domestic tranquility.

abstract: The United States vs. The bark Weatherguage and her cargo. This was a libel of information, to forfeit the bark, as being engaged in the slave-trade. The libel, claim and answer corresponded with those in the case of the Kate.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The bark Weatherguage and her cargo. -- This was a libel of information, to forfeit the bark, as being engaged in the slave-trade. The libel, claim and answer corresponded with those in the case of the Kate. The libel was filed Oct. 1, 1860. The vessel was offered for clearance at the Custom-house for a voyage to Hong Kong, China, via Ambriz, on the coast of Africa; but a clearance was refused her, and she was thereupon seized and libeled. She was claimed by one John Morris. The cargo of the vessel was one which, in the words of the main witness for the Government, was "as likely to go for legal as illegal purposes."

abstract: A SCHEMS OF GENERAL EMANCIPATION. Somebody, stimulated by Lord BROUGHAM'S letter to the Boston John Brown Committee, sends the Ex-Chancellor a report of a conversation with the late Dr. CHALMERS, in which that learned and eloquent divine detailed his plan for abolishing Slavery.
lead_paragraph: A SCHEMS OF GENERAL EMANCIPATION. -- Somebody, stimulated by Lord BROUGHAM'S letter to the Boston John Brown Committee, sends the Ex-Chancellor a report of a conversation with the late Dr. CHALMERS, in which that learned and eloquent divine detailed his plan for abolishing Slavery. It consisted in buying from the masters one day each week of the slaves' time and labor, with the proper and industrious use of which the negro might gradually earn enough to buy another day, and so on until his emancipation should have been entirely purchased. A questionable assumption of the negro's interest -- industry -- lies at the foundation of this scheme.

lead_paragraph: There was rather more notice than usual taken of the day in this city, yesterday. A national salute was fired at sunrise, noon and sunset from Fort Greene, and also in the Eastern District, by detachments from the Seventieth Regiment, Col. GRAHAM, The Twentyeighth Regiment, Col. BENNETT; a battalion of the Fourteenth Regiment, and an independent company of Washington Continentals paraded through the principal streets. Seventeen guns were fired from the North Carolina at the Navy-yard. The public offices were closed, and the National flag was displayed on the shipping, and all public and many private buildings throughout the city.

abstract: The celebration of WASHINGTON'S Birthday in this City yesterday was characterized by a popular participation rarely witnessed. The First Division paraded in unusual strength; the line of march teemed with spectators in holiday attire, and the City assumed an appearance worthy of a gala day. The troops were reviewed by Gov. MORGAN, and the Police arrangements reflected the usual credit upon the Superintendent.
lead_paragraph: The celebration of WASHINGTON's Birthday in this City yesterday was characterized by a popular participation rarely witnessed. The First Division paraded in unusual strength; the line of march teemed with spectators in holiday attire, and the City assumed an appearance worthy of a gala day. The troops were reviewed by Gov. MORGAN, and the Police arrangements reflected the usual credit upon the Superintendent. The Order of United Americans celebrated the day by an oration from Hon. H. MAYNARD, of Tennessee, and by other appropriate exercises at Niblo's Garden. Mr. MAYNARD reviewed the causes which have led to the present unhappy crisis in our national affairs, attributing it entirely to the mischief-makers, backbiters and slanderers of both sections of the country, who make it their business to misrepresent and abuse the people of the opposite section, and to excite ill feeling and hatred between the North and South. Ex-Judge JOHN W. EDMONDS delivered an interesting address before the Republican Central Committee, in the evening -- speaking in reference to the political crisis of the country. He cited the action of WASHINGTON in quelling rebellion by force of arms, but argued that, under the circumstances, we could neither concede to the South nor coerce them. He favored the middle ground of letting the South alone. Mr. E. DELAFIELD SMITH, who presided, spoke in favor of compromise, and a firm but temperate enforcement of the laws. A resolution of thanks was passed to Judge EDMONDS. The day was probably more generally celebrated throughout the country than ever before.

abstract: WASHINGTON'S birth-day having been legalized as a holiday by the New-Jersey Legislature, a year ago, this anniversary was more generally observed in Jersey City yesterday than on any previous occasion for many years past. The Banks, public offices and many business places were closed. Flags were displayed from the public buildings, hotels, ferry-boats, shipping, and especially the English steamers, were profusely decorated with flags and bunting.

abstract: There was a general display of flags upon all the shipping, both along the East and North Rivers, which, in the stiff Northwester that prevailed, was exhibited to the best possible advantage, and gave a most animating appearance to the harbor. All the ships of the different Liverpool, London and Havre lines, and the vessels, large and small, composing the various Southern lines, were dressed out in the gayest holiday attire.
lead_paragraph: There was a general display of flags upon all the shipping, both along the East and North Rivers, which, in the stiff Northwester that prevailed, was exhibited to the best possible advantage, and gave a most animating appearance to the harbor. All the ships of the different Liverpool, London and Havre lines, and the vessels, large and small, composing the various Southern lines, were dressed out in the gayest holiday attire. Always prominent at the main-peak the Stars and Stripes waved its ample folds, while private signals, the flags of all nations, and the International Code flaunted pendant from every mast-head, or was strung from truck to rail, to set off the general effect. The steamers of the Stonington and Norwich lines, the Hudson River boats, those of the California and North Atlantic Company, as well as all the foreign steamers and ships lying on both sides of the City, were profusely decorated. The two Cunard (English) steamers at Jersey City, always prompt to respect our national holydays, on this occasion were handsomely decorated, the American ensign alongside the English jack, sharing the most honored places at their masthead, while vari-colored bunting was strung from their trucks to the ends of the topsail-yardarms, and from the jibboom ends to the main peak.

abstract: Brightly rose the sun yesterday morning, and as its first beam gilded the tips of countless mastheads in the harbor and many a flagstaff throughout all the City, the flag of the Union leaped forth upon the westerly breeze and fluttered with joy at the omen. Never, we venture to say, were so many American banners hoisted in the Metropolis.
lead_paragraph: Brightly rose the sun yesterday morning, and as its first beam gilded the tips of countless mastheads in the harbor and many a flagstaff throughout all the City, the flag of the Union leaped forth upon the westerly breeze and fluttered with joy at the omen. Never, we venture to say, were so many American banners hoisted in the Metropolis. Not only on the roofs of the public buildings and hotels, but on those also of other places of business, without number, and where-ever elsewhere there was a pole to fling it forth from, our flag was there. And never was the beauty of the Stars and Stripes so fully recognized, and loyalty to the "land of the free," which it floats over, so generally given a public expression as by those who composed the crowds that thronged the streets. Crowds? -- that is not the word. London, it has been said, is not a city, but a province covered with houses; our thoroughfares, yesterday, were not streets, but acres alive with people, and the people were achers too, before they were through with it. The procession did not move so early as there was reason to believe that it would. Still, nobody has a right to grumble this time, for in the published general order, no hour for its starting was designated. But it was known that the line was to be formed at 2 o'clock P.M. precisely, and they who sallied forth to see the display, did so at a much earlier hour than they might have done had they not hence inferred that soon after the hour named, the pageant would begin to pass; and so they waited and waited, -- men, and women and children, welded in masses on the sidewalks, standing in squads in the middle of the streets, blockading the entrance of every dwelling-house, rising in human terraces on the door-steps, displaying themselves in shop-windows, watching from the upper stories and house-tops.

abstract: In Parliament, Lord PALMERSTON stated that instructions had been sent to the Governor-General of Canada not to give up ANDERSON without express orders from the Imperial Government, and there was, therefore, no chance of his being surrendered without the point being fully discussed. He could not say whether at habeas corpus writ would be obeyed in Canada, but it could not be executed immediately ...
lead_paragraph: In Parliament, Lord PALMERSTON stated that instructions had been sent to the Governor-General of Canada not to give up ANDERSON without express orders from the Imperial Government, and there was, therefore, no chance of his being surrendered without the point being fully discussed. He could not say whether at habeas corpus writ would be obeyed in Canada, but it could not be executed immediately as the St. Lawrence River was blocked up with ice, and it was impossible to take ANDERSON through American territory. He believed the case, according to the treaty, was quite clear, and that the claim of the United States must be established by showing that ANDERSON was guilty of murder according to the laws of England. No English jury would convict ANDERSON of murder, and the claim was not likely to be substantiated.

abstract: Matter of Nathan Brown, Jr. -- In this case the petitioner was recently committed to the custody of the Sheriff on a Stillwell warrant. He now applied for his discharge upon a writ of habeas corpus. Counsel for the Respondent, the Sheriff, Messrs. Oakey Hall and Courtney, moved that the writ be granted, as it appeared to have been issued by a Justice of the Supreme Court, and was returned in the Superior Court. It was claimed by counsel that there was no authority for a return to a writ of this sort to be made before a Commissioner other than the officer issuing the writ, except in cases where the custody was in an adjoining county. In support of this position reference was made to [3 Hill 656, Hill's notes. Barry & Marcine's case.

lead_paragraph: MORTALITY. -- During the week ending Saturday last, there were 106 deaths in Brooklyn, classified as follows. Men, 20; boys, 26; women, 23; girls, 36. Adults, 42; children, 64. Males, 48; females, 58. Colored persons, 3. Diseases. -- There was 1 death each by angia, bleeding from stomach, brain, cancer, casualties, cirrhosis of liver, colic, compression of brain, congestion of kidneys, cyanosis, debility, (adult,) diabetes, diarrhoea, dropsy in the head, dropsy in the ovaries, erysipelas, exposure, gastric fever, typhus fever, disease of heart, valvula of heart, inflammation of throat, inflammation of womb, disease of kidneys, lockjaw, old age, difficult parlurition, premature birth, rheumatism of heart, small-pox, sprue; 2 each by apoplexy, bronchitis, congestion of brain, congestion of lungs, infantile debility, dropsy, fever, intemperance, disease of liver; 3 each by infantile marasmus and scrofula; 4 each by infantile convulsions and inflammation of the brain; 6 each by croup, scarlet fever and inflammation of the lungs; 7 by diphtheria, and 18 by consumption. 51 of those who died were under five years of age, and one was over 100 years old; 77 were natives of the United States. The deaths occurred in the several Wards as follows: First, 3; Second, 3; Third, 3; Fourth, 5; Fifth, 7; Sixth, 8; Seventh, 7; Eighth, 3; Ninth. 7; Tenth, 12; Eleventh, 11; Twelfth, 5; Thirteenth, 6; Fourteenth, 2; Fifteenth, 6; Sixteenth, 11; Seventieth, 1; Eighteenth, 3; Ninteenth, 3.

abstract: The Peace Conference succeeded, at a late hour last evening, in getting a vote on the proposition of Mr. FRANKLIN, of Pennsylvania, offered as a substitute for Mr. GUTHRIE'S. This substitute provides that involuntary servitude shall not exist in the present territory North of 36 30' while it is in a territorial condition.
lead_paragraph: The Peace Conference succeeded, at a late hour last evening, in getting a vote on the proposition of Mr. FRANKLIN, of Pennsylvania, offered as a substitute for Mr. GUTHRIE's. This substitute provides that involuntary servitude shall not exist in the present territory North of 36° 30′ while it is in a territorial condition. South of the line, in the "present" territory, settlers with persons held to service shall not be prohibited by territorial or other laws from entering while in a territorial condition, and the status of persons held to service shall be cognizable in the Federal Courts under the rules of the common law. It will be perceived that this makes no provision for the admission of States, nor does it give to Slavery the benefit of a recognition by the laws of the State from which it emigrated, as did Mr. GUTHRIE'S proposition. It only allows slaveholders to go into the Territory south of the line while it is territory and look to the common law for both their rights and their remedy. This substitute was adopted by a vote of seventeen to five, two of the seven Slave States, Maryland and Kentucky voting with the North. The vote to-morrow will be on the passage of the substitute as adopted. This may be defeated by a proposition to call a general Convention of all the States. The Virginia, North Carolina and Missouri Commissioners profess to regard Mr. FRANKLIN'S proposition as a mockery to the South, and say that the Convention is played out.

abstract: We copy in another column a letter from Washington in the Evening Post, which merits the attention of all who prize the integrity of the Republican Party above the gratification of selfish and malignant faction. It relates to the intrigues which have been for some time on foot to drive Gov. SEWARD from Mr. LINCOLN'S Cabinet, and sets forth, with great clearness and force, the motives of those engaged in it, and the disastrous results which would follow their success.

abstract: The Charleston Mercury has a long article on the organization of the Navy of the Confederate States. The Navy of the North, it says, is only fit to protect the commerce of the North. Its inefficiency, more than Mr. BUCHANAN's good will towards South Carolina, has, the Mercury thinks,...
lead_paragraph: The Charleston Mercury has a long article on the organization of the Navy of the Confederate States. The Navy of the North, it says, is only fit to protect the commerce of the North. Its inefficiency, more than Mr. BUCHANAN's good will towards South Carolina, has, the Mercury thinks, secured that State such perfect immunity since its secession. Then having hastily sketched the various attempts which have been made to increase the naval force, and declared nearly all the vessels which have recently been constructed miserable failures, the Mercury congratulates the Southern States that they "are rid of a precious lot of old lumber, that decorates with high bows and sterns, and blistered sides the several Navy-yards. Not one of the old line-of-battle ships has been sent to sea within the last twelve years, and even the steam-frigates are driven into ordinary by the superior availability of the light steamers. There is not a frigate in the United States Navy that could stand against an iron-clad ship armed with ten rifled cannon." Since the South has to begin de novo in constructing a Navy, it is urged first that the unfortified entrances of harbors should be protected by floating batteries, and that swift end shot-proof gunboats should be provided for the defence of the intermediate sea coast.

abstract: Judging from the editorial correspondence of the Charleston Mercury, dated from the seat of Government of the new Southern Confederacy, the Palmetto patriots are beginning to realize, that in severing their connection with the United States, they may possibly have done the reverse of improving their...
lead_paragraph: Judging from the editorial correspondence of the Charleston Mercury, dated from the seat of Government of the new Southern Confederacy, the Palmetto patriots are beginning to realize, that in severing their connection with the United States, they may possibly have done the reverse of improving their condition. They are already called upon to "prepare their minds for a failure in the future permanent Southern Constitution;" they are told that "surely MCDUFFIE lived in vain and CALHOUN taught for naught;" they are warned that "the fruit of the labors of thirty odd long years, in strife and bitterness, is about to slip through their fingers;" -- and finally their dismal epistolary prophet winds up the first part of his picture by the declaration that, "South Carolina is about to be resaddled with almost every grievance except abolition," of which she had reason to complain while still a member of the United States.

lead_paragraph: In December last a statement was published to the effect that Mrs. Jane Sparks, of No. 645 Greenwichstreet, had lost a $1,000 bill and $500 bill, on the Chemical Bank, which she had pinned to the undermost of all her garments for safe keeping; and afterwards, neglecting to remove the bank-notes, gave the soiled men to her washerwoman. Mary Moran, the laundress, was arrested at the time, on suspicion of having found and appropriated the money. She was committed for trial at the Jefferson Market Police Court; but some time afterwards her case was brought before Justice SUTHERLAND, who released her because of insufficiency of evidence. Meanwhile, Mrs. Sparks has been looking up other testimony, and on Saturday a young woman named Mary Ann Murphy, living at No. 70 Morton-street, made affidavit before Justice CONNOLLY that one Maria Leach had told her that Mary Moran had brought her (Leach) the two bank notes, and asked her to have them changed. Mrs. Leach then gave the bills to her husband, Michael Leach, who had them changed for small notes, paying for the accommodation, as the affidavit sets forth, the trifle of $1,000 as brokerage.$300 of the remaining $500, Mrs. Leach put in the Savings Bank, but how the balance was disposed of did not appear. Justice CONNOLLY has the case under consideration, and it is probable that upon the strength of this new evidence he will issue a warrant for the re-arrest of Miss Mary Moran.

abstract: In this Court, on Saturday, Justices CONNOLLY, BROWNELL and STEELE disposed of the Calendar as follows: Of forty-three persons charged with assault and battery, twenty were discharged on account of...
lead_paragraph: In this Court, on Saturday, Justices CONNOLLY, BROWNELL and STEELE disposed of the Calendar as follows: Of forty-three persons charged with assault and battery, twenty were discharged on account of non-appearance of witnesses, three by request of complainant, two were remanded, five obtained postponement, six were fined, five were imprisoned and two were acquitted. Of thirty-two persons charged with, petty larceny, five were discharged by non-appearance of witnesses, two obtained postponement, twenty-one were imprisoned, and four were acquitted. Two persons were charged with keeping disorderly houses. One was discharged by request of complainant, and one was sent to the General Sessions.

abstract: We respectfully ask the attention of our neighbor, the Tribune, to a letter from Mr. S.B. WATROUS, dated at Barclay's Fort, New Mexico, Jan. 22, and published is that excellent Republican journal, the Missouri Democrat.
lead_paragraph: We respectfully ask the attention of our neighbor, the Tribune, to a letter from Mr. S.B. WATROUS, dated at Barclay's Fort, New Mexico, Jan. 22, and published is that excellent Republican journal, the Missouri Democrat. It contains information which may possibly dispel some of his illusions concerning the terrible hold of slavery upon that Territory. He thought the other day that it would be absolutely necessary to keep it in Territorial subjection for at least four years of Republican rule, in order to undo the mischief which eight years of Democratic ascendancy have effected.
