abstract: The City was startled on Saturday by the intelligence, contained in an extra edition of the TIMES, that the President elect, instead of proceeding on his journey to Washington from Harrisburgh, in accordance with the published programme, on Saturday morning, had left the latter city secretly, on...
lead_paragraph: The City was startled on Saturday by the intelligence, contained in an extra edition of the TIMES, that the President elect, instead of proceeding on his journey to Washington from Harrisburgh, in accordance with the published programme, on Saturday morning, had left the latter city secretly, on a special train, on Friday night, and returning to Philadelphia, had passed thence, unrecognized, through Baltimore, and was already in the Federal Capital. This step, it appears, was induced by the desire to avoid threatened trouble in Baltimore, and was taken at the earnest solicitation of his friends and leading Republicans in Washington, who had received authentic information that an organized demonstration would be made against him in Baltimore -- if, indeed, he were allowed to reach there alive; for it was also feared that an attempt would be made to throw the Presidential train from the track on the Northern Central Railroad. This information, it appears, was imparted to Mr. LINCOLN on Thursday night at Philadelphia, and he consented, after considerable hesitation, to the private arrangement which was subsequently carried into effect. He reached Washington early on Saturday morning, and proceeded quietly to his hotel, his arrival being known to but few. He soon afterwards, in company with Senator SEWARD, paid a visit to President BUCHANAN, and interchanged civilities with him and with other gentlemen of distinction. His presence in the city then became generally known, and he received many callers during the day, including the President and Cabinet, the members of the Peace Conference and others. Mrs. LINCOLN and the other members of the Presidential party left Harrisburgh at the appointed time, and reached Washington on Saturday evening. The Baltimoreans, some of whom professed great indignation at the course pursued by Mr. LINCOLN, expressed their disapprobation by insulting the party as they passed through.

abstract: THE SOUND STEAMERS. The Spring business on the Eastern steamboat routes is already beginning to show considerable activity. The steamers of the Stonington line are carrying a fair amount of both freight and passengers, as compared with former seasons. The [Commonwealth has] had a thorough...
lead_paragraph: THE SOUND STEAMERS. -- The Spring business on the Eastern steamboat routes is already beginning to show considerable activity. The steamers of the Stonington line are carrying a fair amount of both freight and passengers, as compared with former seasons. The [Commonwealth has] had a thorough overhauling; has been recaulked, newly coppered, and repainted. She will probably take her place on the Boston route, via Groton, during the coming week. In addition to her other attractions she has been fitted up to be lighted with gas, which is to be supplied from the City mains, thus giving to passengers the advantage of a brilliant and ready light in the saloons and in every stateroom. The Plymouth Rock has been similarly overhauled, and is to be placed on the route about the middle of March.

abstract: The present week promises to be an interesting one at the Academy of Music. To-night we are to have VERDI'S new opera, "Un Ballo in Maschera," for the ninth and last time; on Wednesday, "Rigoletto," with Miss KELLOG as Gilda, and Signor STIGELLI as the Duke. Expectation is always pleasantly excited at the approaching debut, of a young artist, and never more so than when it is whispered by those who know the fair debutante that, in addition to the best musical culture that wealth can give her, she possesses also every graceful and social recommendation to the appreciation of her countrymen. The opera selected for Miss KELLOGG'S debut is VERDI'S best, and without overtaxing the lady's powers, will display them to good advantage. One of the most fashionable houses of the season will undoubtedly be present on Wednesday. At Brooklyn, to-morrow evening, BELLINI'S "Puritani" will be played with Miss HINKLEY, and Messrs. STIGELLI, BARILI and SUSINI in the cast.

abstract: It is easy to declare that a particular Government exists, and for its members to assume all its functions; but providing the ways and means whereby to support such assumptions is quite a different affair. This is the difficulty which the "Confederated States" are soon to encounter in fact, the great difficulty in the way of realizing their plans.
lead_paragraph: It is easy to declare that a particular Government exists, and for its members to assume all its functions; but providing the ways and means whereby to support such assumptions is quite a different affair. This is the difficulty which the "Confederated States" are soon to encounter -- in fact, the great difficulty in the way of realizing their plans. Money is now the sine qua non of political existence. Power is measured by the amount that can be commanded. LOUIS NAPOLEON wields the destinies of Europe, but to enable him to do so the debt of the Empire has to be increased at the rate of $80,000,000 annually. For a purely pacific establishment, the annual expenses of the United States have now run up to some $75,000,000. It would, therefore, be the height of folly for the "Confederated States" to assume a position among the nations of the world, without a plenty of money. How much must they have, and where is it to come from?

abstract: The facts connected with the seizure of a large consignment of arms and munitions intended for persons in Georgia and Alabama, on the 9th instant, by the Police authorities of this City, are still fresh in the public mind. It will also be remembered that twentyeight cases of Mini Muskets, intended for Montgomery, Alabama, were replevined and given up by the Superintendent of Police, and afterwards were shipped to their destination.
lead_paragraph: The facts connected with the seizure of a large consignment of arms and munitions intended for persons in Georgia and Alabama, on the 9th instant, by the Police authorities of this City, are still fresh in the public mind. It will also be remembered that twentyeight cases of Mini Muskets, intended for Montgomery, Alabama, were replevined and given up by the Superintendent of Police, and afterwards were shipped to their destination. As this surrender of the Alabama muskets was supposed to virtually release the ten cases which were consigned to Georgia, Mr. LAMAR, President of the Bank of the Republic, acting for the Georgia authorities, informed Gov. BROWN, of that State, that the muskets had been returned to the custody of the claimants. Upon this information, the four vessels which had been seized in Savannah the same day, as reprisals, were given up to their respective commanders. At that time it was reported that the only matter in dispute between Mr. KENNEDY and the claimants of the Georgia muskets, was as to who should pay the law expenses. It afterwards, turned out that the Superintendent reconsidered the matter, and decided to hold the Georgia muskets until his authority to make the seizure should be decided by the courts.

abstract: for his departure from the programme of the journey which he had marked out. As to the motive which induced this departure, there seems to be some discrepancy in the accounts thus far received. The first report ascribed it to the receipt of information, from a source entitled to credit, that a secret plot had been formed to assassinate him on the way to Baltimore, or during his passage through that city. This is the statement that reaches us from Harrisburgh, and it comes with so much of detail as to leave no room to doubt that it was the prevailing belief of those connected with the Presidential party.

abstract: George W. Stevens el al. vs. The Brig Roseway Belle. This was a motion to dismiss an appeal. The action was for sailors' wages. No one appeared in the action for the vessel, but other parties who had filed libels against the vessel to recover claims against her, intervened, and answered in this cause, which went to a hearing, and was decided in favor of...
lead_paragraph: George W. Stevens el al. vs. The Brig Roseway Belle. -- This was a motion to dismiss an appeal. The action was for sailors' wages. No one appeared in the action for the vessel, but other parties who had filed libels against the vessel to recover claims against her, intervened, and answered in this cause, which went to a hearing, and was decided in favor of the libelants. The final decree was entered on Oct. 30, 1860. On Nov. 9, a notice of appeal was left in the office of the Clerk of the Court, but he, by mistake, omitted entering it in the registry of the Court within ten days from the final entry, and thereupon this motion was made.

abstract: The opposition to Senator CAMERON'S occupying a place in the Cabinet was formally withdrawn at Philadelphia while Mr. LINCOLN was there. He will go into the Treasury or War Department, if he chooses probably the latter.
lead_paragraph: The opposition to Senator CAMERON's occupying a place in the Cabinet was formally withdrawn at Philadelphia while Mr. LINCOLN was there. He will go into the Treasury or War Department, if he chooses -- probably the latter. This is generally understood now. The charges against him have been all retracted. Two Ohio members inform me that Senator CHASE probably will accept the position of Secretary of the Treasury. It is rumored that fourteen Republican Senators signed to Mr. LINCOLN a protest against Senator SEWARDS appointment to the Cabinet, which Mr. LINCOLN cooly consigned to the flames.

abstract: The owners of the bark Adjuster Messrs. FUNCH MEINCKE of No. 41 Beaver-Street, have received no intelligence concerning the seizure of their vessel, either from the Captain or the authorities of Savannah.
lead_paragraph: The owners of the bark Adjuster Messrs. FUNCH MEINCKE of No. 41 Beaver-Street, have received no intelligence concerning the seizure of their vessel, either from the Captain or the authorities of Savannah. The vessel had discharged her cargo, and had received on board between 900 and 1,000 bales of cotton for Havre when she was seized. Messrs. F. & M. do not manifest the slightest anxiety on the subject, evidently believing that somebody will have the vessel to pay for as soon as there is a Government to look to for redress.

abstract: Mr. LINCOLN'S presence in Washington is having a decidedly good effect upon all parties there. He yesterday visited both Houses of Congress, and was received with respect and cordiality by all the members, with the exception of two or three whose good opinion is scarcely worth having. He also made calls upon the Judges of the Supreme Court and other distinguished personages.
lead_paragraph: Mr. LINCOLN's presence in Washington is having a decidedly good effect upon all parties there. He yesterday visited both Houses of Congress, and was received with respect and cordiality by all the members, with the exception of two or three whose good opinion is scarcely worth having. He also made calls upon the Judges of the Supreme Court and other distinguished personages. His rooms during reception hours were thronged, by an eager crowd, and the Foreign Envoys and the Secretaries of the various legations left their cards with him. It will be seen from the dispatches of our correspondent that further developments relative to the alleged plot for Mr. LINCOLN'S assassination have been made. The matter, however, is now before the proper authorities, and will undergo a rigid investigation.

abstract: Great as are the evils of secession, they are not wholly without compensation. To the disunion spirit we are indebted for the clearance of the Cobbs, the Floyds, the Thompsons and the Drinkards out of public office; and to the same treasonable conspiracy we must acknowledge our obligations for the withdrawal of such men as Col. HARDEE, Gen. TWIGGS, Lieut. HAMILTON and Cammodore ...
lead_paragraph: Great as are the evils of secession, they are not wholly without compensation. To the disunion spirit we are indebted for the clearance of the Cobbs, the Floyds, the Thompsons and the Drinkards out of public office; and to the same treasonable conspiracy we must acknowledge our obligations for the withdrawal of such men as Col. HARDEE, Gen. TWIGGS, Lieut. HAMILTON and Cammodore ARMSTRONG from the army and navy of the United States. It is well that anything occurred to make these unworthy wearers of epaulettes show their hands before serious dangers threatened the stability of the Union; it is well that they have retired, not before a foreign foe, but from an inherent laxness and disregard of their oaths and duty, -- further instigated, we may believe, by not only prospects, but positive assurances of higher pay and rank in the land and sea services of the Southern Confederacy.

abstract: An influential deputation from the African Aid Society waited upon Lords PALMERSTON and JOHN RUSSELL, on the 6th inst., for the purpose of urging their lordships to appoint a Consular-Agent at Abbeokuta, the capital of the greatest cotton-producing country on the West Coast of Africa, and to adopt ...
lead_paragraph: An influential deputation from the African Aid Society waited upon Lords PALMERSTON and JOHN RUSSELL, on the 6th inst., for the purpose of urging their lordships to appoint a Consular-Agent at Abbeokuta, the capital of the greatest cotton-producing country on the West Coast of Africa, and to adopt measures to induce the King of Dahomey, the great feeder of the Slave-trade, to abandon his slave-hunting expeditions, and devote his own attention and the industry of his people to the cultivation of cotton, as a more profitable as well as a more honorable business. The interview with Lord PALMERSTON was a private one, but Lord JOHN RUSSELL, without binding himself, to any definite course of action, indicated his willingness to consider the matter favorably. Great efforts, said his lordship, had been made in this country, at considerable cost, with a view to the suppression of the Slave-trade, and they must always recollect that efforts had been made in other directions, under the sanction of the various Powers, to endeavor to keep it up. With regard to the appointment of a Consul, the cotton district of Abbeokuta was a very good province, and it was very gratifying to find that palm oil and various other productions had so considerably increased for some years past; and if the appointment of a Consul could promote the interests of its commerce, the Foreign Office would inquire into the particulars respecting it. They were obliged to look with a view to the public service, and the various reasons and regulations by which we are generally bound; but supposing there was no objection to that course be should certainly be most happy to fall in with their views. With regard to the King of Dahomey, he was sorry to say it was not the single obstacle. They found in several parts of Africa that efforts were mace to carry on Slavery. But that was only a part of the question, and with regard to the general question he should be most happy to assist them. Perhaps they would believe him when he said, if in any way he could make the smallest advance towards the extinction of the Slave-trade, he should be most happy to do so. [Cheers.]
headline: {'main': 'Suppression of the Slave-trade.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Suppression of the Slave-trade.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The sloop Motto, hailing from some place up the North River, and lying at the foot of Perry-street, was the scene of considerable excitement yesterday morning, occasioned by some fanatical fool having suspended from her masthead a hideous effigy of the President elect, having the superscription "Lincoln is dead and gone to h-ll."
lead_paragraph: The sloop Motto, hailing from some place up the North River, and lying at the foot of Perry-street, was the scene of considerable excitement yesterday morning, occasioned by some fanatical fool having suspended from her masthead a hideous effigy of the President elect, having the superscription "Lincoln is dead and gone to h-ll." Sergeant De Voursney, and other officers of the Ninth Ward Police, having been attracted to the vessel, by the hooting and jeers of a crowd of men and boys who had assembled upon the pier, and deeming the effigy subversive of public decency, went on board for the purpose of removing it. In this, however, they were opposed by the captain, named William Skipworth, who threatened if any man placed a finger upon the repulsive object to stab him with a marlingspike. He was consequently taken into custody, and conducted before Justice CONNOLY, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, where a charge of having been guilty of a misdemeanor was preferred against him. Upon his promising to have the obnoxious figure taken down, the magistrate dismissed him, and, followed by a large number of people who had gone with him to the Court to learn the result of the affair, as well as by the police, who wished to see that the pledge was fulfilled, he returned to the sloop, and lowered the effigy. It was then surrendered to the boys, who quickly tore it to pieces, scattering to the winds the straw and the rags of which it was composed.

lead_paragraph: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, the trial of Shepherd, for arson, was concluded. Mr. Asomead, for the prisoner, summed up at great length, claiming that as eight Judges of the Court of Appeals, had decided that there was no proof of the prisoner's guilt, the jury could not hope to bring better cultured or more matured understanding to the consideration of the testimony. And therefore, guided by that judicial light, should acquit the prisoner.

abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 8th inst., Mr. H.B. SHERIDAN addressed the following questions to Lord PALMERSTON: Whether, in the case known as the Canadian extradition case, Her Majesty's Government have any doubt that the writ of habeas corpus issued by the Court of Queen's Bench in this country, ...
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, on the 8th inst., Mr. H.B. SHERIDAN addressed the following questions to Lord PALMERSTON: Whether, in the case known as the Canadian extradition case, Her Majesty's Government have any doubt that the writ of habeas corpus issued by the Court of Queen's Bench in this country, requiring that the body of one J. ANDERSON should be brought to that Court will reach Canada in time to prevent the judgment of the Canadian Court ordering the surrender of the prisoner from being acted upon; and whether Her Majesty's Government have any count that the writ, on its reception by the Canadian Court, will be attended to and obeyed; and whether any steps have been taken to secure the safe passage of J. ANDERSON through American territory, if that route should be selected, to reach this country; and it Her Majesty's Government are aware whether or not the said J. ANDERSON is now in prison in any of Her Majesty's jails in any part of Her Majesty's dominions as a felon or otherwise, and subject to the ordinary treatment of persons who have broken the laws; and whether Her Majesty's Government, finding that it is the opinion of certain British Judges that there exists a treaty with the United States of America by the terms of which Great Britain has declared that there are some men who have no neutral or legal right, have taken any and what steps to revise or to put an end to and dissolve such treaty, in order that for the future no misunderstanding shall exist as to the meaning of such treaty, or as to the intention of the British people with reference to the question whether one man has or has not the power to enslave another.

abstract: If the former policy is pursued, ANDREW JOHNSON, of Tennessee, and Mr. GILMER, of North Carolina, would seem to be the men for the emergency; and their selection for Cabinet positions would at once and forever settle and dissipate the disunion excitement. Everybody is waiting in almost breathless anxiety to see whether the Administration is to become powerful and successful by allying itself with the Union sentiment of the country, or is to be broken down and ruined at the very outset, and rendered utterly powerless for any good. With such men as JOHNSON and GILMER in the Cabinet, the Administration party would command the support of the next Congress, instead of being -- as has been anticipated -- in a decided minority in the lower house. No sacrifice of principle is required to satisfy our Southern friends; and, for one, I cannot doubt that much more will be conceded to their fidelity than would ever have been yielded to the impotent threats of the Secessionists, per se.
lead_paragraph: If the former policy is pursued, ANDREW JOHNSON, of Tennessee, and Mr. GILMER, of North Carolina, would seem to be the men for the emergency; and their selection for Cabinet positions would at once and forever settle and dissipate the disunion excitement. Everybody is waiting in almost breathless anxiety to see whether the Administration is to become powerful and successful by allying itself with the Union sentiment of the country, or is to be broken down and ruined at the very outset, and rendered utterly powerless for any good. With such men as JOHNSON and GILMER in the Cabinet, the Administration party would command the support of the next Congress, instead of being -- as has been anticipated -- in a decided minority in the lower house. No sacrifice of principle is required to satisfy our Southern friends; and, for one, I cannot doubt that much more will be conceded to their fidelity than would ever have been yielded to the impotent threats of the Secessionists, per se.

abstract: Our readers doubtless remember the arrest, trial and conviction of RANNEY, the proprietor of the "Broadway Gift Book" establishment, some months since, on the charge of having perpetrated a gross fraud on one JOHN HOCK. He was tried before Judge RUSSELL, in the Court of Sessions; the judgment was subsequently confirmed by the Supreme Court, and he was sentenced to the State Prison for two years.

abstract: Yesterday the steam gunboat Pawnce was to have gone from Philadelphia, on her third trip. She and the Pensacola are the only newly built steamers that have never done any duty. The Pawnee has broken down twice; and constructors call her a failure. She is over 1,200 tons burthen; and carries over a hundred men. The Department anxiously awaits the report of her next trial.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. Miss CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN, whose recent triumphs at this theatre are fresh in the public memory, made her reappearance last evening, and was welcomed, as herebefore, by a crowded house. As a concession to public clamor we will not suppose that it was a matter of art choice the part of Nancy Sykes, in the drama of "Oliver Twist," was selected for the occasion.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- Miss CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN, whose recent triumphs at this theatre are fresh in the public memory, made her reappearance last evening, and was welcomed, as herebefore, by a crowded house. As a concession to public clamor -- we will not suppose that it was a matter of art choice -- the part of Nancy Sykes, in the drama of "Oliver Twist," was selected for the occasion. A certain class of critics have persistently claimed it as one of the lady's finest impersonations, and, rejecting all that intellect and elocution usually bring to the stage, perhaps it is. The unfortunate associate of the brutal and surly burglar, Bill Sykes, is realized in a way which cannot fail to horrify the spectator. It is a muscular exhibition of a woman's last purpose; of her final determination to do a single kindly act at any hazard. All that relates to the will and energy required for this, Miss CUSHMAN depicts with wonderful force. Her watchfulness and bravery are demonstrated in every glance and movement, but we look in vain for that thread of womanly tenderness, which gave birth to so many strong traits. Hence it seems to us that Miss CUSHMAN'S impersonation is less remarkable than Miss HERON'S; for in the latter lady's rendering, a large, although lost womanhood, was constantly confronting us and demanding a share of our sympathy. In obsolute vigor, Miss CUSHMAN'S Nancy deserves to rank with her Meg Merrilies, but only in this respect. We are surprised at the courage she displays, and at the end cannot account for her rapid dispatch by Bill, feeling in our hearts, that any man would have a pretty hard job to get rid of so powerful a will, and so strong an arm.

abstract: Gentlemen from the Border States which have slaves for sale and need a market for them are beginning to get over their scare lest they should lose their market by refusing to go into the Southern Confederacy.
lead_paragraph: Gentlemen from the Border States -- which have slaves for sale and need a market for them -- are beginning to get over their scare lest they should lose their market by refusing to go into the Southern Confederacy. Certainly they have no reason to fear such a result, if they examine the question with a little sagacity. The Southern Confederate States have, in their Provisional Constitution, prohibited the African Slave-trade. Having thus cut themselves off from a foreign supply of labor, as a bid to the Slave-breeding States to come and unite their fortunes with theirs, the Southern Confederacy proceeded to reserve to itself the power of prohibiting, by statutory enactment only, the importation of slaves from the Border States. Now, as the members of the Confederacy claim slaves to be "property," and as the rights of use and free transit of property of all kinds must be protected by law, it is difficult to see how they can ever prohibit Southern planters, who want slave labor, from coming to the Border States to buy and take the desired "property" home with them. If there is a demand for slave labor in the Gulf States, the "Southern Congress" must allow the necessary supply to reach them from the only source which they have left open for themselves. Virginia then may follow out her disposition to stand by the Union, confident that by so doing she does not shut herself out from South Carolina, Georgia or Alabama as a market for her surplus crop of negroes, and this very natural conviction is beginning to force itself upon the understandings of the Border State men here.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors held a special meeting yesterday, for the purpose of considering the Mayor's veto on the County Tax levy. Mr. PURDY moved that this levy be passed, notwithstanding the objections of the Mayor.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors held a special meeting yesterday, for the purpose of considering the Mayor's veto on the County Tax levy. Mr. PURDY moved that this levy be passed, notwithstanding the objections of the Mayor. After the budget and ordinance accompanying it had been read, Mr. BLUNT called attention to the remark of the Mayor, that the Board would be likely to override all his objections, and said he thought the Mayor's presumption unfair, as vetoes of hit, had been sustained by the Board. As to the Mayor's objection to the $50,000 for a new Courthouse, His Honor ought to be satisfied that the money would be spent properly. The Board did not put in $150,000 for building the new Harlem Bridge, became they thought the contracts for it had been made extravagantly; and he (Mr. BLUNT) knew that matters with which the Mayor had been connected had been managed extravagantly.

abstract: The people of Charleston celebrated WASHINGTON'S birthday with great enthusiasm. The Pickens Cadets, a company of boys who have taken to playing soldier, paraded for the first time, and were presented to Gov. PICKENS by Lieut MAGRATH. The Governor made the company a brief address, urging upon its members the bright and shining example of WASHINGTON as deserving imitation.
lead_paragraph: The people of Charleston celebrated WASHINGTON'S birthday with great enthusiasm. The Pickens Cadets, a company of boys who have taken to playing soldier, paraded for the first time, and were presented to Gov. PICKENS by Lieut MAGRATH. The Governor made the company a brief address, urging upon its members the bright and shining example of WASHINGTON as deserving imitation. Subsequently a banner was presented to the Washington Light Infantry, and in the evening the company reassembled in Hibernian Hall, where it was addressed by Col. EDWARD CARROLL, in an oration of a rather sanguinary hue. Other companies also celebrated the day in their own way.

abstract: Less than a week will elapse before the Government of the United States of America will be called upon, not only to unfold its principles of action and policy to the world, but also to vindicate them in the personnel of its officers at home and its representatives abroad. It will be called upon to act with ...
lead_paragraph: Less than a week will elapse before the Government of the United States of America will be called upon, not only to unfold its principles of action and policy to the world, but also to vindicate them in the personnel of its officers at home and its representatives abroad. It will be called upon to act with promptitude; for when treachery and treason infect the army and navy, where devotion to flag, obedience to discipline, esprit du corps, and all the conventionalisms of honor, to say nothing of patriotic impulses, tend to an unhesitating support of the Constitution and laws, and are yet openly violated by refractory lieutenants and unprincipled captains, then it becomes doubly important for the Government to be sure of the fidelity as well as of the capacity of its servants in other departments, but particularly of those to whom are confided our relations with foreign countries. It is of vital importance in this our hour of trial, when the integrity of our Government is tested to the utmost, and when all that it posseses of intellect and patriotism ought to be exerted for its safety and vindication as a system, that we should present to other nations a front as firm and serene as that of the Roman Senate when the Vandal hordes poured through the streets of Rome, and invaded the halls of the Capitol. In simple words, our ministers abroad, whether to nations which rejoice in our calamities, or which await in painful and sympathizing suspense the solution of our present difficulties, should now, above all other periods in our history, be men rising above the paltry passions and miserable localisms of the hour, and capable of representing the principles and policy of a Government which has effected more for the welfare and glory of its people, in the short space of eighty years, than any other which has been organized since the world began.
headline: {'main': 'The Foreign Policy of the New Administration.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Foreign Policy of the New Administration.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: The Albany Argus affects to discredit the statements made concerning the plot against Mr. LINCOLN'S life, on the ground that "assassination is not congenial to the American character." As a general statement, this is perfectly true, -- but it is none the less true, that in a time of excitement there are many men quite forgetful of their "American character," and ready for any act of crime which the perverted sentiments of a large portion of the people are ready to cover with the garb of patriotism. We have not the slightest doubt that the project of assassinating Mr. LINCOLN has been seriously canvassed by very many persons in different sections of the country, -- nor that plans have been laid for its accomplishment.

abstract: You will please to take notice of the C.S.A. which heads my letter, and request the typos not to omit it, hereafter. Yesterday we were officially born, and the 22d of February will henceforth be the 4th of July of the "Confederate States of America." The Courier comes out under the new head, and I follow, as is my duty.

abstract: Passing through the parlor this morning I heard a lady say, " Poor LINCOLN, how he is to be pitied." Not having the pleasure of the fair one's acquaintance, I could, of course, take no notice of the remark at that moment, but through the columns of THE TIMES I say to her, Madame, your head is right; you are worthy of your sex.

abstract: On Saturday night the furnished dwelling No. 50 West Twenty-second-street, recently occupied by Mrs. Ella Hall, was visited by burglars, who carried away a mantel clock, sawed off the water-pipes, and did other damage. The same night three lads, named Patrick Farrell, Michael Farrell and Patrick McDonnell, were observed by Officer O'Connor, of the Twenty-first Ward, with the time-piece in their possession, and believing they had stolen it, he arrested them. The fact of the burglary, however, was not made known until yesterday, when Mrs. Hall appeared before Justice Connolly, and made an affidavit against the prisoners. The boys owned their fault, stating that they had entered the building by sliding down the coal-hole, not to steal but merely to have a slide for the fun of it, and as they could not got out again without going up stairs, they went up. Then they found the clock and took it away. All of them were held for trial.

abstract: Everybody professes to hope that the Union may yet be preserved, but there seems to be some difference of opinion as to the means most, likely to bring about that result. It is agreed on all sides that no effort to "compromise" with the States that have seceded would either be of the slightest practical use, or would be consistent with the honor and sovereignty of the Government.
lead_paragraph: Everybody professes to hope that the Union may yet be preserved, -- but there seems to be some difference of opinion as to the means most, likely to bring about that result. It is agreed on all sides that no effort to "compromise" with the States that have seceded would either be of the slightest practical use, or would be consistent with the honor and sovereignty of the Government. But a large portion of the Republican Party is in favor of a policy which shall be conciliatory towards the Border States, so as to retain them in the Union, -- believing that with such a basis for future action a popular movement would soon be started in the seceded States in favor of reunion, and that in due time it would control the policy of these States and eventually bring them back.

abstract: Mr. LINCOLN was yesterday formally notified of his election to the Presidency, by the Joint Committee of Congress, appointed for that purpose. During the day he again visited the Capitol, in company with Senator TRUMBULL and others, and exchanged courtesies with a number of Senators.
lead_paragraph: Mr. LINCOLN was yesterday formally notified of his election to the Presidency, by the Joint Committee of Congress, appointed for that purpose. During the day he again visited the Capitol, in company with Senator TRUMBULL and others, and exchanged courtesies with a number of Senators. Gov. HICKS, of Maryland, was among the many visitors who called upon him. The Governor congratulated him upon his safe arrival in Washington, and upon the apparent good feeling with which he had generally been received. Mr. LINCOLN is, of course, overrun with office-seekers and their emissaries, but appears to bear the infliction with commendable equanimity.

abstract: By a decision of the Court of Common Pleas, delivered yesterday, the injunction restraining the Mayor and Common Council from completing the contract with ANDREW J. HACKLEY, for cleaning the streets of our City for the five years next following, was dissolved; and at a late hour yesterday afternoon the contract was duly signed, sealed and delivered -- the Mayor approving of the bondsmen offered for the due performance of the work, and the Corporation Counsel having drawn up the terms of the contract so as to protect the interests of the City, in so far as may be possible under the new arrangement.

abstract: In the Court of General Sessions yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, the Jury in the case of JAMES SHEPHERD, on trial for arson in the first degree, came in, after an absence of twenty hours spent in deliberation, with a verdict of guilty, accompanied by a recommendation to mercy. Let us hope that this ...
lead_paragraph: In the Court of General Sessions yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, the Jury in the case of JAMES SHEPHERD, on trial for arson in the first degree, came in, after an absence of twenty hours spent in deliberation, with a verdict of guilty, accompanied by a recommendation to mercy. Let us hope that this may be the last of this apparently interminable case, the prisoner having been in custody more than three years, and three times placed on trial -- the Jury in one instance having failed to agree; but on the two other trials finding him guilty, under which verdicts he was twice sentenced to be hung.
headline: {'main': 'End of the Shepherd Arson Case.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'End of the Shepherd Arson Case.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Evening Post, the last journal in the country which can fairly be suspected of a disposition to "compromise with traitors," gives its hearty assent to the passage of an Enabling act for New-Mexico, as the best possible means of ending the sectional controversy and restoring peace to the country.

It quotes the paragraphs we have already copied from the St. Louis Democrat, which render it almost certain that the existing slave-code in the Territory will be abolished, and that whenever a State Constitution is formed it will be on the basis of freedom, -- and remarks:

abstract: The City Authorities of Washington yesterday took formal leave of the outgoing President, and paid their respects to the incoming one. Mr. LINCOLN, in his reply to the address of the Mayor, took occasion to say that he thought much of the bad feeling which existed between the two seetions of the country grew out of misunderstanding,...
lead_paragraph: The City Authorities of Washington yesterday took formal leave of the outgoing President, and paid their respects to the incoming one. Mr. LINCOLN, in his reply to the address of the Mayor, took occasion to say that he thought much of the bad feeling which existed between the two seetions of the country grew out of misunderstanding, and he assured his visitors that he had never had any other feelings than those of kindness towards his fellow citizens of the Southern States, and had no desire or intention to interfere with their rights. Mr. LINCOLN during the day again visited the Capitol, and received a call from the Supreme Court Judges. The impression created by his presence in Washington continues to be most favorable.

abstract: A great deal of sport was anticipated last Tuesday evening by men about town in attending a "Macintosh ball," given by a class of persons addicted to a disgusting vice, of which the existence is probably unknown to nine-tenths of the community. The affair was to have taken place at a public hall in Thirty-third-street, near Sixth-avenue, and by 10 o'clock the company began to arrive. It consisted of sporting men, police detectives, abandoned females, and the degraded characters whom the sporting men, police detectives and abandoned females aforesaid had assembled to see. The detectives, however, were there on business, the others merely to gratify curiosity. Capt. Speight, of the 21st Ward, had been apprised of the affair several days before, and made arrangements to arrest the parties engaged in it. The fun was fast and furious about 12 o'clock, and yet carriages continually arrived with additional company. The feature of the occasion was the fact that the male dancers were appareled in female attire, and the latter donned the habiliments of their opposite sex. In the midst of the hilarity a whisper went round the room that the Police were coming to break up the ball. Instantly a rush was made to escape, and in the greatest confusion the company made their exit. The carriages were taken possession of, without ceremony, and driven rapidly away, many of the counterfeit women having gladly seated themselves on the box with the drivers. This movement was not premature, as the police came up in time to arrest nine of the offenders, whose trepidation had rendered them helpless. Seven of the prisoners proved to be men, although they were got up regardless of expense in female apparel, ringlets, rouge, and everything excepting jewelry, of which about $6,000 worth, principally in diamonds, was distributed upon the person of one of them. The police conducted the whole party to the Station-house, where by this time a large crowd had assembled to learn the cause of the excitement. The men gave the names of James Peters, John Jackson, Charles Warner, George Livingston, John Moulton and Julius Vogel. The women called themselves Catharine Anderson and Elizabeth Campbell. After spending the remainder of the night in the cells, all of them, still wearing their ball dresses, were taken yesterday morning to the Jefferson Market Police Court, where their appearance excited much merriment. Justice CONNOLLY exercised compassion, and instead of sending them to prison as vagrants, as was generally expected, merely required a surety from each of them in the sum of $500, to keep the peace for six months. Two or three of them found bondsmen, but the others, not being so fortunate, were imprisoned.

abstract: A country where white men get the kicks and negroes the candy where the black man gets the oyster and the white man the shell where the Anglo-Saxon has no rights which...
lead_paragraph: A country where white men get the kicks and negroes the candy -- where the black man gets the oyster and the white man the shell -- where the Anglo-Saxon has no rights which the African is bound to respect -- where are black Senators, Judges, Generals and Editors -- where the ideal of female loveliness is not in the carnation tinge on the lily cheek, nor the nicely-turned arm or ankle, but in the blackness of the gloss and the size of the malleolus; -- what darkey, as he dreams of Paradise, has not had glimpses of some such Isle of the Blest and the Black? Now, even while they have been dreaming of it, just such a happy isle -- only more so -- has been rapidly preparing itself for the imparadisement of all good American negroes. Not on the outskirts of the world, in a far-off Liberia, nor amid the hyperborean rigors of Canada -- not under the rule of a black savage or a white tyrant -- but beneath the tropic warmth which the African loves so well, and under the benignant constitutional sway of a genuinely Black Republican President.
headline: {'main': 'A Paradise for Negroes.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Paradise for Negroes.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- One of the most fashionable houses of the season, assembled last evening to witness the debut of Miss KELLOGG -- a lady whose ill-luck it was to be announced last season, and good fortune to come out this, when we have at least a gentlemanly management. The opera selected for the occasion, was VERDI's "Rigoletto" -- a circumstance which will, in itself, suggest the style of the young artist. We do not regard the role of Gilda as an absolutely safe one for debutantes, but its selection suggests at least a bold and praiseworthy deviation from the beaten track, and indicates also the first condition of success -- self-reliance. Our American prime donne usually begin with Luciu, and end somewhere in the immediate vicinity.

abstract: A gentleman who arrived here by the steamer Columbia, and who professed to be well informed on the subject, states that shortly after the arrival of Hon. JEFFERSON DAVIS at Charleston, it was quietly arranged for him to pay a visit to Fort Sumter, which was accomplished privately. The interview is represented to have been an earnest and prolonged one, but all not immediately in the secret were left wholly to conjecture as to what took place between him and Major ANDERSON, it has, however, been knowingly given out at Charleston that there will be no fight at Fort Sumter -- great stress evidently being placed upon the fact that these two old acquaintances in the Army cannot be brought into bloody conflict with each other. On the other hand, it is believed that if the alleged visit had elicited any particular comfort for the great leader of the secession movement, such good news would not have been kept for private consumption merely.

lead_paragraph: A COMMENDABLE CHARITY. -- By advertisement published in another column, it will be seen that the Board of Managers of the Nursery and Child's Hospital hold their annual meeting next Friday forenoon, at the Institution, situated on Fifty-first-street, near Third-avenue. All friends of the objects for which the charity has been founded, are requested to attend. This Institution aims to relieve the humbler classes of women, who are obliged to work during the day, of the cares of attending to their infants during certain hours, the little ones being received in the morning when the mothers are going to work, and carefully tended and nursed until called for in the evening. Sick children are also received into the Hospital, and provided with excellent medical attention, the Institution thus performing a most necessary duty, and saving many hundred children annually from these soporific drugs and cordials which are so commonly used to quiet infants during the compulsory daily absences of their mothers.

abstract: If the Emperor of France was unduly concise, as the majority of English journals declared, in his late address to the Chambers of Deputies, the very unusual defect has...
lead_paragraph: If the Emperor of France was unduly concise, as the majority of English journals declared, in his late address to the Chambers of Deputies, the very unusual defect has certainly been atoned for by the exposition of the situation of the Empire, subsequently presented to the Senate and Legislative Body. A remarkable interest attaches to this document as a rather substantial proof of that advance in constitutional liberty which the Emperor has so frequently both directly and indirectly promised, and for which he appears to have at heart a hankering, which contrasts strangely enough with the absolutism of iron and blood on which his power rests. It is in the nature of certain minds to attempt great difficulties -- possibly the Emperor is daring to dabble with the delicate problem of advancing a fiery nation like the French on the road of progress, and of retaining his own power at the same time.

abstract: The movements at Washington in favor of Peace are drawing to their natural close. The Peace Convention adjourned yesterday sine die, having first adopted the plan reported by Mr. GUTHRIE, as amended by Mr. FRANKLIN, of...
lead_paragraph: The movements at Washington in favor of Peace are drawing to their natural close. The Peace Convention adjourned yesterday sine die, having first adopted the plan reported by Mr. GUTHRIE, as amended by Mr. FRANKLIN, of Pennsylvania. The essential feature of this plan is its restoration of the Missouri Compromise line, with added securities for Slavery in the Southern portion of the Territory thus divided. This action of the Convention was transmitted to the Senate, and ordered to be printed, and referred to a Select Committee, with instructions to report to-day at 1 o'clock.

abstract: MEETING FOR THE RELIEF OF THE POOR. Pursuant to a call signed by influential citizens, a meeting for the relief of the poor was held Tuesday evening in the City Mail.
lead_paragraph: MEETING FOR THE RELIEF OF THE POOR. -- Pursuant to a call signed by influential citizens, a meeting for the relief of the poor was held Tuesday evening in the City Hail. The attendance was limited. Ex-Mayor HALL, President of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, was called to the Chair, and Mr. ROLLIN, chosen Secretary. The Chairman explained the objects of the meeting. He stated that the funds of the Association were exhausted. The number of families assisted since October 1, 1860, is one thousand three hundred and forty. Of the number, five hundred and twenty-five were American. The average number weekly for the last six weeks was four hundred and ninety, of whom one hundred and ninety were American. The average expenditure for the six weeks was $600. The whole amount expended to date is $5,022. The amount collected is $3,724, making, with the amount of subscriptions estimated as collectable, $5,175. A surplus of $152 remains, but returns net yet made, it is thought, will exhaust the sum, Mr. HALL further stated that facts daily transpired, showing the prevalence of destitution and suffering, Mr. EAMES, Secretary of the Association, followed, and said the class of persons heading assistance were not seen in the streets They were those who were not accustomed to apply for charity. He cited numerous cases in support of his position. Mr. CHITTENDEN referred to the suffering among certain classes incident to political disturbances, and said the urgent claims of the people of Kansas should not be disregarded, but at the same time the poor at home should be cared for. Rev. Drs. FARLEY, BAYLIS, CUTTER and other gentlemen made remarks, and a resolution providing for an immediate collection was adopted. By another resolution the clergymen of the city were requested to raise collections in their churches to promote the objects of the meeting. The collectors of the Association for the several districts were also requested to canvass again for contributions. Subscriptions to the amount of $1,020 were then received, Mr. SPROTT, baker, corner of Jay and Concord streets, agreed to bake into bread a barrel of flour weekly, to be distributed by the Association, and also to bake, without charge, any flour that might be contributed for that purpose. Messrs. Thos. Messenger, A.W. Benson, A.C. Hull, S.B. Chittenden and Poole were appointed a Committee to solicit subscriptions, and the meeting adjourned.

abstract: The New-Orleans papers of a recent date,notice the arrest of an individual who was suspected of having attempted to...
lead_paragraph: -- The New-Orleans papers of a recent date,notice the arrest of an individual who was suspected of having attempted to enter the United States Mint in that city at unseasonable hours. The incident is only another illustration of the countless inconsistencies into which the Secessionists are continually betrayed. Undoubtedly the hapless prisoner had determined to secede from the State, and desiring to enter upon his independent career fully prepared for all pecuniary contingencies, in imitation of the example of Louisiana herself, made up his mind to appropriate whatever was left of the five or six millions which were in the Mint when the the State threw off her allegiance to the Federal Government.

abstract: The correspondent of the Missouri Republican, writing from Tucson on Feb. 1; gives the following abstract of a decree issued by Gov. PESQUEIRA, in relation to the transit premium of goods to Arizona via Guaymas: It is intended that all importations for Arizona shall pay 10 per cent. on the duties imposed by the Mexican tariff of 1856, which average about 30 per cent. There are, however, additional duties, amounting in all to 15 per cent. on the thriff, and the percentage on this, with warehousing, will probably bring our share up to 20 per cent. on the tariff price, or an average of 6 per cent. ad valorem Most articles, the correspondent writes, can be brought to Tucson much cheaper, under this regulation, than via Texas or Fort Yuma, and as long as this liberal policy prevails, both Arizona and Sonora will benefit by it. The measure will undoubtedly greatly assist in developing the resources of Arizona, and with the increased demand for Sonora produce, the farmers and traders of that country will share its advantages.

abstract: Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest yesterday upon the body of Mr. NATHAN H. SMITH, a native of New-Haven, Conn, 20 years of age, who lost his life on the 18th of last January, while hunting for amusement at Goodalooke County, Texas, by the accidental discharge of his fowling piece. Deceased was the son of Mr. NATHAN SMITH, of No. 33 West Twentyseventh street, this City, and his remains were brought here for interment.

abstract: Lieut. VIELE, late of the United States Army, and Captain of the Engineer Corps of the Seventh Regiment, delivered a very entertaining and instructive lecture at Irving Hall, Tuesday evening, on "Field Fortifications." The lecture was the first of a course, given under the auspices of the Twelfth Regiment, of which the second and third are to delivered by Gen. YATES and Capt. LOVELL. Lieut. VIELE dwelt upon the conduct of troops in the field, giving some interesting details, especially of the manner of managing volunteer troops, with frequent illustrations drawn from incidents which came under his observation in Mexico, where he earned his name in the regular service.
lead_paragraph: Lieut. abstract: The Boston Atlas must be laboring under some strange hallucination with reference to the Democratic Party in the Northern States, for...

abstract: The People ex rel. Savage vs. The Board of Health. -- The relator in this case had possession of dumping grounds at the foot of Thirty-eighth-street. Upon complaint that manure was allowed to rot thereon, the Board of Health compelled its removal. This was a certiorari for the review of the proceedings of the Board of Health, the relator claiming that they had exceeded their powers. The Commissioners deny that such was the case, and contend that the Court is without jurisdiction to review their proceedings. Decision reserved.

abstract: PEDESTRIAN FEAT. MICKEY FREE, the great pedestrian, left Jersey City, yesterday forenoon, for a walk to the City of Washington, intending to arrive there on Sunday evening, in order to be present at the inauguration of the President on the following day.
lead_paragraph: PEDESTRIAN FEAT. -- MICKEY FREE, the great pedestrian, left Jersey City, yesterday forenoon, for a walk to the City of Washington, intending to arrive there on Sunday evening, in order to be present at the inauguration of the President on the following day. MICKEY, who is an enthusiastic Republican, was attired in a Wide-Awake cap and Continental coat, the same as when he introduced himself to the President elect, at the reception in the depot in Jersey City.

abstract: The second injunction upon the proceedings being taken to conclude the Hackley contract for cleaning the streets having been dissolved, Tuesday morning, the contract was signed at 2 o'clock on the same afternoon. The contractor, Andrew J. Hackley, is bound in two sureties, (Messrs. Thomas and Anthony S. Hope,) in the sum of $100,000 each, to clean all the streets and avenues for five years, at the price of $279,000 per annum, and he will commence work to-day. The contract, approved by the Corporation Counsel, had been in readiness and in the hands of the City Inspector for several days past.
lead_paragraph: The second injunction upon the proceedings being taken to conclude the Hackley contract for cleaning the streets having been dissolved, Tuesday morning, the contract was signed at 2 o'clock on the same afternoon. The contract, approved by the Corporation Counsel, had been in readiness and in the hands of the City Inspector for several days past.

abstract: Southern merchants are making good use of the brief time allowed them for the introduction of goods "free of duty," which, under the ordinance of the "Confederate States," expires during the current week. There is fully the usual number of Southern ...
lead_paragraph: Southern merchants are making good use of the brief time allowed them for the introduction of goods "free of duty," which, under the ordinance of the "Confederate States," expires during the current week. There is fully the usual number of Southern purchasers in town, as compared with previous years, at the corresponding season, and all with the view of replenishing their exhausted stocks of merchandise. In Warren, Murray and Chambers streets, as well as other business localities, unusual activity was yesterday noticed in the shipment of goods; carts were observed with full loads of boxes of dry-goods and other merchandise, on their way to the various Southern steamers, which are loading for Norfolk, Savannah and Charleston.

abstract: Baltimore City, some two years ago, was, and anterior to that time had been, the scene of many a cruel and wicked outrage. The KnowNothing party controlled the City Government,...
lead_paragraph: Baltimore City, some two years ago, was, and anterior to that time had been, the scene of many a cruel and wicked outrage. The KnowNothing party controlled the City Government, and, under its rule, lawlessless and violence usurped our streets, and the most public thorough-fares were disgraced by open and deliberate violations of order and decorum. Assassination and murder invaded the fireside and selected its victims from among the executive officers of the law. Men, bodly eminent, in talent and position, winked at and tolerated this state of affairs, through partisan motives and for party purposes. But while their sway in Baltimore seemed absolute, the effect upon the rest of the State produced disgust and vigorous condemnation, resulting in a return to the Legislature, which convened last December twelvemonth, of a large majority opposed to the Know-Nothing Party, and ready to aid that respectable body of our fellow-citizens, here known as Reformers, in any remedial measures they might propose. Such measures were carefully prepared by a Committee of the latter gentlemen; and, in the face of every sort of opposition and mischievous influence, professional and otherwise, from this city, were adopted by the Legislature, giving to Baltimore its present most effective and valuable police system, superior for all purposes of order and protection to any elsewhere to be found in the United States.
